) faults. All these veins are being displaced or stopping at the bedding parallel fault zone. As part of the faults, these veins are featuring a varying thickness across short distances and often split into several branches. Calcite veins can be traced over several metres and some of them show well developed drag folds indicating a dextral shear direction (Fig. 9).






2.2
Geodetic and geotechnical measurements
In the context of the CD-A experiment, different kinds of geodetic and geotechnical measurements are used. While this paper focuses on the deformation measurements, the investigations concerning the water content and the pore pressures will be discussed in accompanying publications (in preparation). Further information concerning the installation and the set-up of the measuring program can also be found in Refs. 30, 35. Concerning the convergence of the niches, the laser scans provide detailed information at each point of the surface of the niches, while the extensometers measure deformations within the host rock and the 3D-convergence measurements provide precise information of the convergence of the niches with regard to defined anchor points and dates. The different kinds of measurements are summarised in Table 1 and introduced in this section while a discussion of the results can be found in Section 3.




2.2.1
Laser scans
Within the first year after the excavation of the niches, laser scans with a resolution of 1 mm and an accuracy in the order of 2 to 3 mm have been carried out at seven different days during the whole year and introduced in Ref. 36. The measurements are related to fixed points in Gallery 18, known to be stationary and located in the niche area. Within and in front of each niche, various targets have been positioned for the calibration of the point clouds. About 6 scans per niche were performed for pre-calibration on site to obtain the highest accuracy for the measurements on the rock. The distance of the targets, the resolution and the angle of impact of the laser on the measured element were taken into account to guarantee the quality of the measurements. First results indicate that both niches are very stable with small deformations in a range of millimetres. Fig. 11 (top) presents the results of the laser scans for the initial measurements, carried out on September 13, 2019. Within the context of the CD-A experiment, the temporal evolution of the deformations at different locations is of particular interest. The results indicate areas where the surface of the host rock moves towards the central axis (convergence) of the niche or in the opposite direction (divergence) as it is presented in Fig. 11 (bottom). A cylindrical coordinate system has been used for calculation and evaluation of the changes.



Fig. 12 shows the deformation of the closed and open niches at different dates after postprocessing. The visualised measurements have been carried out in winter 2019 and summer 2020 during the first year after excavation and are evaluated with regard to the initial measurement in September 2019. Both niches are very stable but are also characterised by an ongoing convergence process with deformations in the range of tenth of millimetres as indicated by the yellow areas. These measurements indicate a convergence of the niches in the vertical direction, while the horizontal deformations show no clear trend for this short time period since excavation. In the open niche (blue frame), the pictured deformations depend significantly on the distance to the Gallery 18. A possible reason might be the geological characteristic of the host rock in this area. Judging the influence of seasonal changes of the climatic conditions is currently not possible. This is due to the fact that the available measurements correspond to a single year after excavation. Further observation of these effects within the next years will provide important information to answer some of these questions and will be part of the long-term investigation program within the CD-A experiment.


2.2.2
3D-convergence measurements

Convergence measurements are carried out within both niches and are described in detail in Ref. 30. The prisms for the convergence measurements are located at three different profiles within each niche. They are fixed in a depth of 5 cm at niche meter 5.5m and at a depth of 20 cm at 5.0m and 6.0m, respectively. This kind of measurements focuses on the long term evolution of the niches and provides periodic information regarding the displacement of the prisms. Measurements during the first months after excavation are depicted in Fig. 13 for the vertical direction and in Fig. 14 for the translatoric direction. The results for the positions in the upper part of the niches are presented at the top, the lower positions at the bottom. The vertical displacements indicate an uplift of the ground and a subsidence of the roof which is consistent with the expected convergence of the niches. This trend can be seen at all measured positions of the closed twin. Differing results are measured only for upper region of the SW-oriented (“left”) part of the open twin which exhibits different results compared to the NE-oriented part of this niche.


Fig. 14 shows the translatoric displacements within the niches. While all positions indicate displacements up to a maximum of 2.5 mm, there is one outlier in position 60. This point shows higher values up to 3.0 mm. Nevertheless, all measurements indicate a trend of the displacements towards the NE-direction. Furthermore, the measurements in the open twin indicate a slight influence of the seasonal variations of the climatic conditions of the niches. This is a preliminary assumption based on very few measurements carried out until now.
As expected, the measurements indicate a convergence of the niches. This trend is even clearer for the vertical direction than for the horizontal direction, which can also be seen in Fig. 15. Here, the displacements measured in February 2021 are visualised with regard to the initial state measured by the laser scan. While the colour code represents the amplitude of the displacement, the radius of the coloured dots provides information about the depth of the anchor (big sphere: anchor depth of 5 cm and small sphere: anchor depth of 20 cm). Outliers are located in the NE-part of the open twin and the SW-part of the closed twin, which could be caused by the geologic heterogeneities in these zones.






2.2.3
Extensometer measurements
Extensometer measurements are used to get information about the deformation behaviour around the niches. The extensometer measurements are located in boreholes around the niches as depicted in Fig. 4 and as it is carried out similarly in Ref. 15. Each niche accommodates a vertical and a horizontal borehole with a length of 4m each. Two additional boreholes have been drilled from the gallery and end up at about 1m below the niches respectively. They have a length of approximately 12.5m each. Within the boreholes, chain extensometers have been installed. They consist of anchor-elements connected to each other by glass fibre rods and measure the unidirectional displacements of the anchor points relative to each other. The measuring range of the displacement sensors is 100 mm and provides an accuracy of 0.0015% of full scale (FS). The sensor is also equipped with a temperature measurement device and provides information about the length of each segment continuously. Further information is summarised in Ref. 37.

As the chain extensometers provide measurements of the change of the length of a segment between two anchor points, there is no fixed point which could be used as a static reference. Consequently, the evaluation of the displacements contains uncertainties as every point might be subjected to possible movements. As a consequence, the interpretation of the measured values in the following section is carried out with two different approaches, namely the segmental interpretation and the fixpoint interpretation. The segmental interpretation gives information about the strains of each single segment and indicates directly the segments which are characterised by compression or extension. In contrast to that, the fixpoint interpretation of the measurements is characterised by the assumption that the point with the largest distance to the niche is fixed. This gives the opportunity to indicate the displacements of each anchor point relative to the fixpoint. One has to keep in mind that especially for the boreholes, which are drilled from the gallery, this approach neglects displacements near the gallery.
The temporal evolution of the segmental strains is presented in Fig. 16 (top) for both niches while Fig. 16 (bottom) shows the situation for the last measuring date in a 3-dimensional view. Here, the colour code of the segments represents the strains of each segment. The fixpoint interpretation is pictured in Fig. 17. The colour code of the measuring points indicates displacements with regard to the fixpoint. Positive values suggest an increase of the distance to the fixpoint while negative values indicate a movement of this point towards the fixpoint. Generally, the order of magnitude of the measured deformations is in the range of tenths of a millimetre. This order of magnitude of deformations seems to be in line with other tests, such as mine-by tests in different kinds of shales,
15

,

23
 which yield deformations in the range of a few millimetres up to some centimetres. The measurements in the vertical boreholes indicate an uplift of the ground in both niches as expected, but the deformations around the open niche are generally larger. Finally, the interpretation of the measurements yields the following assumptions:



•
Movements around the open niche (BCD-A2 and BCD-A6) are significantly higher than at comparable locations at the closed niche. This can be seen clearly in both interpretations (Figs. 16 and 17). The measurements along the borehole BCD-A2 are characterised by heterogeneities which lead to differing results for the different measuring points and segments. This effect might be due to heterogeneities and fractures in this area.


•
The vertical deformations are characterised by positive strains (extension) – they indicate an uplift of the ground of the niches. Remarkable in this context are the results of the segments near the twins (darkest lines). As expected, these points show the highest values. Furthermore, they show significantly different behaviour, which might be due to the different climatic conditions within the niches and will be part of further investigations.


•
Horizontal displacements are significantly smaller than vertical displacements.


•
While the deformation around the open niche tends to continue, the measurements in the closed niche seem to be characterised by reduced deformation after the first years. This might be a result of the climatic conditions within the closed niche and should be part of further long-term investigations.






2.3
Numerical modelling
At this early state of the CD-A experiment, the model set-up aims for a basic understanding of the prevailing processes. Heterogeneities as they are discussed in this paper as well as more complex constitutive relationships like plastic or viscous behaviour, saturation dependent parameters, and swelling/shrinkage of the host rock are not captured in the model so far. To reproduce the cyclic deformation related to the coupled process induced by seasonal humidity changes, a three-dimensional model of the Opalinus Clay with the Gallery 18 and both twin niches has been set up using the Finite Element software OpenGeoSys (OGS).
38

,

39
 This modelling software is open-source, which is of great advantage in the research of numerical methods. In the geoscientific community, OGS is used to simulate thermal–hydraulic–mechanical and chemical processes in porous media. In this work, a macroscopic hydro-mechanical model consisting of the momentum balance equation of the solid and the mass balance equation of the pore fluid
18

,

39

,

40
 is used. The coupling between the hydraulic and mechanical processes is realised by the Biot’s effective stress law and a linear Bishop’s approximation.
40–42
 The main variables of the model are the solid displacement vector (deformation) and the liquid pore pressure. The hydro-mechanical coupled model takes into account variable saturation according to the Richards assumption
43
: The air pressure is considered constant and the liquid pore pressure drives the development of capillary pressure. The balance equations are complemented with constitutive laws such as the van Genuchten curve
44
 to compute variable saturation. The gas entry pressure, shape parameter and residual saturation for fitting the van Genuchten curve are displayed in Table 2. Fig. 18 shows different views of the modelled domain, which has dimensions of approximately 50 × 30 × 20 m



3


 and which is discretised by approximately 180 thousand tetrahedral elements for the computation with the Finite Element Method. Note that the air lock between the gallery and the closed niche are explicitly modelled, whereas the excavation damage zones are not. The material properties utilised in the simulation correspond to the sandy facies of the Opalinus Clay with anisotropic hydraulic and mechanical behaviours described in the literature.
4

45




Initially, an in-situ stress

0

MPa

 on the entire domain. The measurements of in-situ stress and in-situ pore pressure are challenging and change due to activities such as excavation and open conditions.
46

,

47

48
 to avoid numerical instabilities due to the boundaries (size) of the modelled domain. Since the focus of the current paper is a qualitative comparison between the model behaviour and measurements, the effect of initial conditions, excavation and selected heterogeneities will be considered in further investigations. Furthermore, the mechanical boundary conditions are assigned to avoid rigid body motion normal to the outer boundaries and the liquid pore pressure around the outer boundaries of the domain corresponds to the initial condition. In the experimental setup, the relative air humidity is monitored in the niches as depicted in Fig. 3. To reproduce the experiment and obtain input data for the numerical simulation, we calculate the pore pressure using the relative air humidity via the Kelvin equation. To reproduce the seasonal changes of relative humidity, a seasonal, sine shaped, time-dependent pore pressure is applied in the open niche and gallery walls (blue segments in Fig. 18). A constant pressure based on the average of the largest monitored air humidity values is applied in the closed niche (light red segments in Fig. 18).
The model is able to reproduce the expected coupled hydro-mechanical behaviour qualitatively, where changes in saturation lead to deformation (displacements). Desaturated zones are identified in the simulation after a few winter-summer cycles as shown in Fig. 19. These results are in agreement with the observations, since desaturation is recorded during winter, while a re-saturation is observed in the near field during the summer period.
18
 The low permeability of the rock does not allow for rapid changes in saturation and the material remains wetter, the further away it is from the open niche/gallery. To avoid repetitions, the results concerning the mechanical behaviour are discussed and compared with the experiments in Section 3. Further aspects regarding the modelled domain, influence of excavation and extension of constitutive laws to allow the modelling of shrinkage-induced cracking

2.4
Visualisation

To facilitate an improved understanding of the complex processes taking place inside the layer of Opalinus Clay surrounding Gallery 18 and the twin niches, a 3D scene has been set up using the OpenGeoSys Data Explorer.
50
 and ParaView
51
 Both programmes employ the VTK programming library
52
 for creating, modifying, and representing 3D objects and datasets. Structures such as the tunnel system, geological layers and faults are represented via triangulated surfaces of varying resolution, depending on the level of detail needed to adequately represent the data. Boreholes shown in Fig. 4 are represented via tubes with a diameter scaling corresponding to the size of the diameter of the drill bit used, with locations of sensor positions (e.g. extensometers) being enlarged for emphasis. The numerical model detailed in Section 2.3 consists of over 180.000 tetrahedra, including more than a dozen parameters assigned to either nodes or cells, including material parameters required for the simulation as well as values calculated during the process simulation. Colour look-up tables and parameters such as transparency, scaling, or lighting can be adjusted for each dataset individually, based on the requirements of the research. In addition, datasets can be post-processed by applying algorithms either modifying the geometrical structure of the data (e.g. clipping planes) or calculating representations on the node- or cell-based parameters (e.g. contour surfaces based on simulated saturation, as shown in Fig. 19). CAD-data, measurements, and simulation results are integrated within the same frame of reference, allowing for an interactive exploration of the setup of the experiment (Fig. 4). With the scene being fully interactive and the user being able to navigate freely and to adjust parameters as needed, it also becomes possible to thoroughly explore and assess the complex transient hydro-mechanical simulation results calculated via OpenGeoSys and compare them to observation data collected via sensors. In addition, the 3D scene gives a structural perspective of discontinuities within the domain of the experiment and where the experiment is located, both within the Mont Terri tunnel system (Fig. 1) and within the sandy facies of the Opalinus Clay layer as part of the complex stratigraphy of the Jurassic Mountains (Fig. 20).



3
Holistic interpretation and discussion of the results
The aim of the presented investigations is an increased process understanding of the hydraulic-mechanically driven effects around the niches and the understanding of the geological system. The derived information of geological investigations has to be interpreted regarding the impact of different heterogeneities in order to decide whether the detected fault zones have to be considered in the numerical modelling approach. The introduced approaches give complementary information on various scales of time and space. The expected coupled hydraulic–mechanical processes are characterised by the excavation effects as well as the initial desaturation of the claystone around the niches and the gallery. The host rock is characterised by heterogeneous claystone and a complex non-linear material behaviour. The coupled hydraulic–mechanical effects are influenced and controlled on the one hand by the heterogeneous material composition, mineralogical composition and geologic characteristics and on the other hand by the boundary conditions like the stress field, the water content, the temperature and the technical construction of the excavated areas. The presented methods of investigation give insights in the complex situation. Main outcomes are discussed in this section.

The convergence of the niches in the vertical direction can be clearly seen in the extensometer measurements and the laser scan data at the bottom of the niches. Furthermore, the laser scans and the convergence measurements confirm this trend at the top of the niches. In the horizontal direction, such a trend is not clear yet, which is consistent with results presented in Ref. 23 but might also be a matter of the short time period since the excavation of the niches. According to the laser scans, the trend of convergence is stronger in the closed niche than in the open twin. The overall trend of convergence in the measurements is also reflected by the numerical modelling results, where contraction and extension is calculated in the expected areas. The vertical strains are larger (absolute value) than the horizontal ones. Furthermore, the influence of the seasonal boundary condition is observed at the entrance of the closed niche and along the open niche. Fig. 21 provides a comprehensive overview of the deformation behaviour in the measured and simulated data.

The scale of the measured deformations is in a similar range for all types of measurements and also for the numerical results. In the latter, pre-calculations to evaluate the model parameters and its sensitivity were performed. As expected, the calculated deformations near the gallery are larger than in the surrounding area. The measured range of deformations lies in the order of tenth of millimetres near the niches. Nevertheless, it is important to notice that all types of measurements indicate outliers or irregular results which may result from different uncertainty sources. The treatment of these measured values has to be discussed on the basis of the individual case. A summary of these cases is presented in Table 3 and indicates that most of the deviating results are measured in the area near the open twin. This might be due to the geologic situation especially on the SW-side (“left side”) of the open twin as it is presented in Fig. 22. Here, an impression of the geologic situation around the niches in combination with a visualisation of the measuring positions is given (top) and fault zones of specific interest are highlighted (bottom). Another reason for irregular measurements at the open twin, especially in the near-field of the niche, might be the climatic situation of the open twin which is characterised by seasonal influences.

The interpretation of the laser scan data has to be carried out carefully as the measurements are restricted to the first year after excavation. Within this time period, the niches are very stable and the observed deformations are in a very small range, which is close to the accuracy of the measurement method. Nevertheless, the provided results are physically comprehensible as presented in Section 2.2.1. The comparison of scanned data of both twins indicates different behaviour along the niche axes. While the measured trend of convergence is nearly constant along the niche axis for the closed twin, the behaviour in the open twin varies significantly along the niche as shown in Fig. 12. The impact of the climatic conditions at this initial state seems to be low as the measured relative humidities show only minor variations along the niche axes. Nevertheless, the laser scan data will be in the focus of further interpretation and statistical evaluation aiming to better understand the impact of the climatic conditions.
In summary, the presented investigations of various kinds of measurements, geologic investigation and numerical modelling are demanding and difficult to communicate to non-experts. Each one has its particular advantages and disadvantages, and their accuracy and error-proneness have to be included in the interpretation of the results.
The measured values have to be checked for their physical plausibility. Do the different methods show different phenomena? Do they picture the same trend? And the same scale? Do they contain anomalies? Do the anomalies appear in more than one method? What are possible reasons? It has to be kept in mind that uncertainties due to the measuring method or inhomogeneities of the material may appear. A critical discussion of the measuring method and a suitable interpretation of the data is essential in this context.
For the interpretation of the numerical modelling results it has to be kept in mind that the claystone is characterised by a complex coupled thermal–hydraulic–mechanical–chemical–biological material behaviour as well as by geological heterogeneities and discontinuities on different length scales. Not all of these aspects have been taken into account in the current numerical model, since the latter is homogeneous. The consideration of the entire complexity – including all known fault zones – in the numerical model is not necessarily reasonable but potential impacts of some single fault zones have to be determined. The constitutive approach and the chosen material parameters have to be analysed in detail and possible sources of errors have to be taken into account by the interpretation of the results. Moreover, an extension of the modelling approach is required to account for more complex material behaviour, e.g. plasticity, cracking. The visualisation of the dominant fault zones in the near field of the niches is a valuable tool to increase the system understanding and investigate irregularities and outliers.
However, the usage of different methods and their combination in a comprehensive approach reduce the susceptibility to errors and increase the process understanding. Furthermore, it strengthens the interaction between different scientific disciplines and is an important basis for decision making and knowledge management.


4
Conclusions
The use of different types of investigation methods has significant advantages such as the increase of the process and system understanding. Sophisticated visualisation techniques give valuable support to interpret the results in a consolidating manner. The combined interpretation of the results with consideration of specific uncertainties and statements regarding the relevance of different physical effects is a challenging task, but also an important basis for the enhancement of numerical modelling approaches, which are used for the safety assessment of a potential repository.
The investigations carried out in the context of the CD-A experiment in the Mont Terri rock laboratory indicate the expected convergence of the niches: all measurement strategies and numerical model show this trend in a similar and a comprehensive scale. Geological investigations as well as measurements underline the heterogeneity which characterises the Opalinus Clay. Seasonal effects are of lesser importance for the deformation behaviour within this first period of investigation. Nevertheless, all types of measurements show outliers which might be a result of heterogeneities, the technical boundary conditions or due to uncertainties within the measuring methods. Also, the numerical modelling approach is characterised by uncertainties due to various required input parameters, simplifying assumptions within the model setup and the mathematical formulation itself, which will never cover the reality completely. The different CD-A experiment measurements produce outliers mostly in the same niche regions. We therefore assume that a common reason for these irregular results might be inhomogeneities in the host rock originating from faults or lithological variances. Visualisation techniques are used, which help us to combine the outcome of different kinds of investigation like geologic investigations, measurements and numerical modelling.
In principle, the investigations in the context of the CD-A experiment focus on long-term effects such as deformations driven by the very slow desaturation of the low permeable Opalinus Clay. The investigations presented in this article focus on the initial two years of the experiment and give some insights into the geologic situation as well as the impact of the excavation and the climatic conditions on the deformations around the niches during this phase. The detected and visualised fault zones advise on the geologic situation around the twin niches. The interpretation of these heterogeneities with regard to their relevance for coupled hydraulic–mechanical effects is a challenging task. Ongoing investigations aim to identify zones with stronger or weaker coupled HM effects.
Future work will also focus on the excavation induced and seasonal effects within the niches and their impact on the coupled hydraulic–mechanical processes. In this context, further hydraulic-mechanically coupled effects such as swelling and shrinkage, the evolution of desiccation cracks and their handling in a constitutive modelling approach are of specific interest. Furthermore, the continued detailed interpretation of the ongoing measurements and the reinforced use of visualisation techniques are foreseen. The well established multidisciplinary evaluation presented in this article will be continued.
The interpretation of the first data sets of the CD-A experiment in a holistic manner provides a diverse and detailed insight into the coupled hydraulic–mechanical effects around the twin niches in the Mont Terri rock laboratory. In summary, the presented research has shown that the multidisciplinary approach combining geological mapping, geophysical measurements, numerical modelling and visualisation techniques is a promising way to better understand complex mechanisms and the process behind them. Thus, it can be a valuable component for the safe construction and operation of a repository and for the long term safety assessment.

Introduction
Fault zones are widely present in the Earth’s crust. They are usually associated with complex internal structures involving fault core(s) and damage zones, rendering a hierarchically organised system of heterogeneous geological composites.
1–3
 The fault core accommodates most of the historical shear displacement and may consist of slip surfaces, unconsolidated gouges, cohesive cataclasites and/or breccia materials.

,

5
 Damage zones that bound the fault core are characterised by networks of off-fault secondary structures like fractures and veins.

,

 Extensive investigations have been done in the past to characterise the geological, mechanical, and hydrological properties of crustal fault zones,
8–12
 which reveal that their behaviour is highly controlled by their architectural features.
The understanding and prediction of fault zone behaviour is critically important for many geoscience and geoengineering problems, especially for those fluid injection-related applications,
13–16
 such as enhanced geothermal systems, unconventional oil/gas reservoirs, waste water disposal, and carbon sequestration. The injection of a large volume of fluids into subsurface geological formations at great depths may activate/reactivate some of the seismogenic faults through various mechanisms such as pore pressure diffusion,
17
 poroelastic stress transfer,
18
 and aseismic slip.
19
 The faulting process may produce large magnitude man-made earthquakes that can be felt by the public on the ground surface and provoke significant societal concerns.
13
 One typical example is the 2017 


M


w


 5.5 Pohang earthquake in South Korea, which occurred about two months after massive water injection into an enhanced geothermal system nearby. Whether this earthquake was induced by fluid injection or not has been hotly debated 
20

,

21
, and finally a detailed investigation by an international research advisory committee has led to a conclusion that it was triggered by fluid injection into a previously unmapped fault zone.
22
 Hence, it is essential to develop an improved understanding and predictability of injection-induced fault responses.
Over the past decade, a large body of academic research has been conducted to model fault behaviour in response to underground fluid injection. For example, Cappa and Rutqvist
23
 proposed a hydro-mechanical modelling approach for simulating injection-induced fault deformation and permeability evolution with the fault represented as either a zero-thickness interface or a finite-thickness layer. Rutqvist et al. 
24

,

25
 further used the finite-thickness layer model to perform two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) simulations of fault slip during hydraulic fracturing in shale formations and estimated the moment magnitude of potential induced earthquakes. Figueiredo et al. 
26
 combined this approach with a damage mechanics model to investigate the interaction between a hydraulic fracture and a nearby pre-existing fault. Zeng et al. 
27
 recently conducted numerical simulations based on the zero-thickness interface model and analysed the effect of reservoir permeability heterogeneity on the fault slip during fluid injection at different distances with respect to the fault. In addition, some efforts have also been devoted to study the role of fault architecture in injection-induced fault responses. Rinaldi et al. 
28
 analysed the influence of hydro-mechanical heterogeneities of a fault zone on the pressure diffusion and frictional slip along the fault subject to fluid injection, and reported that heterogeneities tend to inhibit upward fluid leakage and suppress seismic rupture. Yehya et al. 
29
 modelled the porosity/permeability evolution and poroelastic response of a fault zone consisting of a low-permeability fault core and a damage zone represented by an anisotropic high-permeability continuum, and observed a strong control by the fault architecture on the hydro-mechanical behaviour of the fault.
In these previous studies, the fault zone is modelled either as a single plane (conditioned with certain constitutive relationships) or a multilayer composite (with the fault core and damage zone represented as a sequence of continua). However, such treatments do not allow a full capture of the detailed processes operating inside the fault damage zone, which is usually characterised by a dense network of fractures. Some recent field experiments conducted at the Grimsel and Bedretto Underground Research Laboratories have revealed that mesoscale fracture systems in fault zones accommodates very rich and complex seismo-hydro-mechanical phenomena during hydraulic stimulation.
30–32
 In this paper, we present a modelling attempt to unravel this complexity based on a fully-coupled hydro-mechanical model
33
 that we have recently developed to simulate fluid injection-induced damage growth, fracture slip, poroelastic response, and seismicity occurrence in fractured rocks. We apply this model to analyse the seismo-hydro-mechanical processes in the fracture network of a fault zone. Section 2 presents the governing equations of our numerical model; Section 3 describes the model setup including the geometrical configurations, boundary conditions, and material properties; Section 4 shows the simulation results and detailed analysis, followed by a brief discussion in Section 5 and some conclusions in Section 6.

Results and analysis

4.1
Injection-induced pressure evolution
We present the spatial and temporal evolution of fluid pressure in the fault zone subject to fluid injection at different positions, where the in-situ stress field has an orientation of 
θ


=
 0°(Fig. 2), 45°(Fig. 3), or 90°(Fig. 4). We also analyse the temporal variations of fluid pressure at the injection point and six monitoring points (Fig. 5). It is useful to note here that the pressure evolution in Fig. 5 reflects both the effects of pressure propagation in the variable-density, anisotropic fracture network and of the pressure-induced fracture aperture changes and creation of new fractures (new damage elements) in the network. The latter effect will be presented in detail in Section 4.2.
For the case of 
θ


=
 0°, when the injection point is close to the fault core, i.e. 



x


inj


=
5

 m (Fig. 3, left panel), injected water flows mainly in the right portion of the fault zone and in general along the strike of the fault. This is because the fault core serves as a low-permeability barrier to prevent the injected water from migrating to the left space, while the high-density fracture zone surrounding the fault core acts as a highly-conductive corridor for fluid flow along the fault strike. Correspondingly, the pressure at the injection point experiences a progressive and moderate increase during the entire injection period (Fig. 5a). The monitoring points #1 and #2 (i.e.

This is consistent with the observation in Fig. 2 that the injected water first flows along the strike in the high-density fracture zone, and then later also diffuses towards right into the medium-density fracture zone. When the injection position is at

The pressure at the injection point quickly climbs up to about 55 MPa and then starts to decline after a short plateau, while the neighbouring monitoring point #3 left to the injection point shows a similar trend, indicating a preferential pressure diffusion towards the high-density fracture zone (Fig. 5b). Other monitoring points inside the high- and medium-density fracture zones also sequentially experience gentle pressure increases, while those inside the low-density zone witness insignificant variations (Fig. 5b). At the beginning, the pressure builds up only around the injection point, which is followed by diffusion into the medium- and high-density fracture zones in the later stage as more water is continuously injected into the system (Fig. 2, right panel). The pressure at the injection point shows a steep build-up in the early stage, and then a decline asymptotically reaching a stabilisation in the later stage (Fig. 5c). The monitoring points #1-#5 left to the injection point consecutively capture pressure responses, while the one (i.e. #6) right to the injection point only has a minor pressure variation (Fig. 5c). 5
Discussion
In this paper, we applied a fully-coupled hydro-mechanical model to simulate injection-induced processes in a mature fault zone characterised by a low-permeability fault core and a high-permeability damage zone bounding the fault core. Many essential multiphysical processes were modelled including pressure diffusion, poroelastic coupling, brittle failure, fracture slip, aperture variation, and microseismicity occurrence. Our model realistically captured the phenomena that the fault core prevents the injected water from flowing across it and that the damage zone promotes fluid flow along the fault strike, consistent with many field observations and other numerical simulations.
1

,

2

,

9

,

27–29
 Our simulations show that the injection-induced deformation/seismicity inside the fault zone is controlled by (a) the state of in-situ stresses and its orientation relative to the fault direction, (b) the distribution of fractures within the fault zone and the orientations of prevalent fracture sets relative to principal stress directions, and (c) the location of injection point within such a hierarchically-organised system. Injection-induced new damages tend to propagate along the maximum principal stress direction, while shear displacements and aperture enlargements are promoted when fractures are preferentially oriented for shearing under the in-situ stress condition. Constant-rate fluid injection into the densely fractured region close to the fault core results in relatively lower pressures and thus tends to produce little damage and insignificant connectivity change, while injection into a region of relatively low fracture density involves a higher injection pressure and seems to gain slightly increased connectivity accompanied by increased microseismicity. However, if the stress field is oriented to suppress the fractures for shearing, a significant connectivity enhancement may be gained with an insignificant level of microseismicity created, especially if the injection point is located away from the fault core (but still inside the fault zone). Great caution is also needed for such a scenario, which may generate a direct hydraulic connection linking the injection point to the main fault with a risk of eventually reactivating the main fault. The observations obtained from the current study may have important implications for the design and optimisation of hydraulic stimulation strategies for enhanced geothermal or hydrocarbon recovery. More specifically, our results suggest that a comprehensive site characterisation of the in-situ stress state and mesoscale damage zone structures is essential for evaluating and predicting the stimulation performance of rock volumes in natural fault zones.
Our research revealed the metre or decametre-scale complexity of injection-induced phenomena in fault zones, which are often neglected in most existing simulation studies 
23–28
 without considering the detailed distribution and behaviour of fractures inside the damage zone. Here, we conducted physics-based numerical simulations to show that the seismo-hydro-mechanical evolution inside the fault zone can exhibit qualitatively different regimes depending on the fracture-stress relative orientation, local fracture density, and the injection position, which may not be captured by commonly assumed constitutive relationships empirically relating fault zone porosity/permeability to local stress variation. 
23

,

29
 The conventional fault models that represent a fault as a single plane or a multilayer composite (see the review in the introduction section) are computationally efficient in capturing the overall reactivation behaviour of large-scale faults. However, we would like to emphasise that it is also fundamentally important to investigate the mesoscale physical processes and phenomena that occur within the fault in order to better understand the emergence of its macroscopic behaviour/properties. For example, it is of great interest to examine whether and how microseismic events developed in the damage zone could possibly cascade into a much larger event.
54
 In the current study, we mainly focused on the processes operating in the mesoscale fracture system of the damage zone and did not attempt to fully capture the reactivation of the main fault, for which a much larger modelling domain is needed — an aspect that will be explored in our future work. Our modelling results of injection-induced microseismic clouds are in a good consistency with the field observations obtained from decametre-scale in-situ hydraulic stimulation experiments at the Grimsel Test Site, Switzerland,
30

,

31
 where extensive microseismic events were found to occur in the off-fault damage zone. More specifically, at the Grimsel Test Site, the fault zones involved in the stimulation experiments were found to have a narrow (centimetre-wide) fault core,
11
 while the injection-induced microseismic clouds developed in the off-fault region with a lateral extent of several tens of centimetres to metres.
30

,

31
 These microseismic clusters tend to align the strike of the main fault plane,
30

,

31
 which is laterally bounded by a damage zone characterised by mesoscale fractures with a spatial decay of fracture density away from the fault core.
11
 The field experimental results have shown that the injection-induced seismicity neither occurred in the fault core nor on the interface between the fault core and the damage zone; basically, the seismicity occurred exclusively inside the damage zone,
31
 consistent with our model concept and simulation results.
It is worth mentioning a few limitations of the current work which require more efforts to overcome through additional studies in the future. In the current study, we mainly explored the effect of stress orientation and focused on a fracture system with a constant length; it would be interesting to also study the effects of stress magnitudes and variable fracture lengths on the seismicity in fault zones. It is also important to extend the current 2D model to 3D so that the role of the intermediate stress component can be explored. Furthermore, we hope to further develop and apply our model to study the phenomena of post-injection large magnitude earthquakes
55–57
 and Kaiser effect
58

,

59
 that have been observed in many previous injection projects.


6
Conclusions
To conclude, we have presented fully-coupled hydro-mechanical simulations of fluid injection into a fault zone consisting of a fault core and a damage zone characterised by an exponential decay of fracture density away from the fault core. We found that the injection-induced seismo-hydro-mechanical responses of the fault zone including pressure diffusion, damage growth, fracture deformation, and microseismicity emergence are interactively controlled by the in-situ stress field and its orientation relative to the fault, the fracture distribution within the fault zone and the prevalent directions of fracture sets, and injection position relative to the local fracture density in the fault zone. In general, a higher enhancement in connectivity as well as a greater potential for fracture slip in the network with a higher seismicity level is generated when injecting water into the damage zone at a location away from the fault core. If the injection location is very close to the fault core, the high local fracture density prevents high pressure build up, and if the injection is far from the fault core in the low-density fracture region, significant pressure build-up could occur. Furthermore, the seismicity may be suppressed if the fractures are unfavourably oriented for shearing under the in-situ stress field. Our results highlight the complexity of injection-induced metre-scale multiphysical processes in hierarchical fault zones, which were often overlooked in the literature. Our research findings may have important implications for optimising the stimulation strategy of enhanced geothermal systems and unconventional oil/gas reservoirs as well as forecasting the emergence of large man-made earthquakes during injection-related geoengineering activities.

1
Introduction
Rock fractures provide the main pathways for mass transport in natural fractured low-permeable rock systems, especially for crystalline bedrock where the permeability of rock matrix is negligible compared to the fractures.
1
 Modelling of fluid flow and solute transport in rock fractures is an important topic related to many geo-energy and geo-environment projects, such as geo-energy extraction and storage (e.g., Ref. 2), geological disposal of nuclear waste (e.g., Refs. 3, 4), and subsurface environmental impact assessment (e.g., Ref. 5). Particularly, a fundamental understanding of fluid flow and solute transport in single rock fractures is essential for analysing mass and energy transport in fracture networks at the field application scale.
Rock fractures are deformable subject to normal and shear stresses (e.g., Ref. 6). It is known that the transmissivity of rock fractures is determined by the structure of void spaces, i.e., fracture aperture (e.g., Refs. 7, 8). In the literature, numerous studies have revealed that mechanical processes, i.e., normal and shear displacements, significantly affect the fracture transmissivity because the mechanical displacements can change the fracture aperture structures (e.g., Refs. 7, 9–28). For instance, Yeo et al.
13
 conducted physical shear-flow experiments and found that with increasing shear displacement from 0 mm to 2 mm, the fracture becomes more permeable, and the flow becomes more heterogeneous and anisotropic. Xiong et al.
19
 conducted laboratory shear-flow tests and numerical simulations by solving the Navier–Stokes equation to study the changes of hydraulic properties of a single fracture during shear. It was found that the evolution of fracture transmissivity decreases before the peak shear stress and then increase after the peak shear stress. These studies generally demonstrated the significant impact of mechanical displacement on the changes of fracture transmissivity.
The changes of fracture transmissivity induced by mechanical displacements will subsequently affect solute transport processes in the fractures (e.g., Refs. 28–38). In particular, Koyama et al.
39
 and Vilarrasa et al.
29
 analysed shear-induced flow channels and their impact on solute transport in a fracture created from a laser scanned rock surface. It was found that fracture shear greatly increases the flow rate and particle travel velocity in the direction perpendicular to the shearing direction. The shear process is often numerically approximated by conducting incremental relative movement of the upper surface without considering normal loading. In reality, natural fractures are subject to complex mechanical conditions including both normal and shear stresses. Therefore, to understand the coupled hydromechanical and solute transport processes in rock fractures, it is important to quantify the normal and shear displacements in analysis of fluid flow and solute transport considering the more realistic mechanical conditions. Recently, Zhang and Huang
40
 and Liu et al.
41
 simulated solute transport in rough fractures by solving the advection–dispersion equation with consideration of more accurate shear displacement obtained from direct shear test of artificial rock fractures under constant normal loading boundary conditions. Their results showed that the shear displacements cause significant increase (in the magnitude) of flow rates and solute velocity. At present, the analyses of solute transport in sheared fractures are limited to a few direct shear test results without considering different mechanical boundary conditions. Meanwhile, modelling solute transport in rock fractures by solving the Reynolds equation and dimension-reduced advection–dispersion equation may contain important uncertainty because of the selection of constant values of longitudinal and transverse dispersivity.
In this work, we investigate the impact of shear displacement on advective transport in a single rough-walled fracture. We study different mechanical scenarios based on a set of high-resolution laboratory shear tests for a fracture with different replicas under constant normal load (CNL) and constant normal stiffness (CNS) conditions. The shear tests with replicas of the same natural fracture provides important advantages to study the effect of different mechanical boundary conditions on the shear-flow-transport processes in the fracture. The evolution of fracture aperture structures with different shear displacement conditions is extracted from measured normal displacements and the digitalized fracture surface. The fluid flow is simulated by solving the Reynolds equation. The Lagrangian particle tracking method is applied to model the advective transport in the fracture. The results from this study will help to improve our understanding of stress-dependent solute transport processes in natural rock fractures under different mechanical boundary conditions.

3.1
Shear test results

Fig. 2 illustrates the changes of shear stress and normal stress (Fig. 2a) and the averaged normal displacement (Fig. 2b) with the shear displacement during laboratory shear testing of the replica samples. The results show that the shear stresses increase dramatically with the increasing shear displacement until they reach the peak shear strengths when the shear displacements are around 0.24 mm, 0.32 mm, 0.32 mm, 0.4 mm, and 0.34 mm for the one CNL and the four CNS tests, respectively. Then, under the CNL condition, once residual state has been reached, the shear stress remains constant with increasing shear displacement. However, under the CNS condition, the normal stresses continuously increase with the shear displacement and the shear stresses gradually increase with the increasing shear displacement after a dropdown when the shear displacements are below 1 mm. Meanwhile, the averaged normal displacements obtained from four LVDT sensors show that the fracture slightly closes before the shear stresses approach their peak shear strengths. After that, the fracture gradually opens with increasing shear displacement due to shear dilation. These features commonly appear in direct shear tests of rock fractures (e.g., Refs. 15, 19).

In both directions, the flow streamlines show that the flow becomes less channelized when the shear displacement increases from 0.32 mm to 5 mm. When the shear displacement is relatively small where the shear stress is at the peak shear strength, flow is almost below the percolation threshold due to the fracture closure, where the void spaces are disconnected (see Fig. 3), especially in the 
y
-axis direction. This result indicates that relatively small shear displacements (when the shear stress approaches the peak shear strength) can significantly affect the hydraulic properties of mated fractures, where the fracture apertures are near or below the flow percolation threshold. After the peak shear strength, the flow and transport in the fracture will generally be enhanced with increasing shear displacement due to shear dilation for both CNL and CNS conditions.





3.4
Travel time distributions for advective transport
Based on the flow streamlines, the travel time for each particle is calculated based on Eq. (5). The distributions of the travel times are used to analyse the advective transport features. Fig. 6 illustrates the cumulative distribution functions (CDFs) and complementary cumulative distribution functions (CCDFs) of advective travel time for different shear displacements under different mechanical conditions.

As shown in Fig. 6a–b, the median travel times for the cases of shear distance 0.32 mm, 1 mm and 5 mm are around 800 s, 130 s and 13 s for flow in the 
x
-axis direction and 10060 s, 1458 s and 76 s for flow in the 
x
-axis direction, respectively. It shows that in both x- and 
y
-axis directions, the median travel times reduce dramatically when the shear displacement increases from 0.32 mm to 5 mm.
Meanwhile, the tail of the travel time distributions becomes less pronounced when the shear displacement increases from 0.32 mm to 5 mm (Fig. 6a–b). This result demonstrates that after the peak shear strength, the increasing shear displacements will dramatically affect advective transport in mated fractures by reducing the travel times. The main reason is that after the peak shear strength, the fracture opens due to shear dilation during the shearing process, which significantly increases the fracture transmissivity.
The mechanical conditions will affect the travel time distributions at the same shear displacement (Fig. 6c–d). Specifically, the travel time distributions for the fracture under the CNL condition has relatively smaller variability compared to the cases under the CNS condition, because it has relatively larger dilation when the shear displacement is relatively large (larger than 5 mm, see Fig. 2b). Under the CNS condition, the travel time distribution for the case

x

y

K

These results demonstrate that advective transport processes in rock fractures are sensitive to the fracture mechanical conditions. In general, the advective travel time is longer in the case with higher 


K


n


 under the CNS condition when the shear displacement is relatively large, because the higher 


K

However, when the shear displacement is less than 5 mm, the vertical displacement does not show a clear tendency among the different mechanical conditions (see Fig. 2b), which indicates that there are uncertain impacts of mechanical conditions on the advective transport in sheared rock fractures.
Moreover, by comparing the travel time distribution for flow in x- and y- axis directions, it is found that the transport along the shear direction (y-axis direction in this case) is more sensitive to the shear displacement, indicating that the shear displacement is a reason for anisotropic flow and transport in rock fractures.



4
Discussion
In this work, we demonstrated the impact of shear displacements on fluid flow and advective transport in a laboratory-scale fracture. The analysis of fluid flow and advective transport is based on measured mechanical displacements from a unique set of shear test data for fracture replicas. The fracture replicas made it possible to conduct shear tests under different mechanical conditions while maintaining similar geometrical conditions (i.e., fracture surface roughness). We demonstrated the impacts of normal stiffness on fluid flow and solute transport in rock fractures under the CNS condition, which is an advancement compared to previous studies that only considered a single case with one normal stiffness value (e.g., Refs. 40, 41). The aperture calculation method (Eq. (2)) has been frequently used in previous hydromechanical studies of rock fractures, such as by Xiong et al.
19
, Zhang and Huang
40
 and Liu et al.
41
 The flow and transport modelling method has also been adopted for studying fluid flow and advective transport in rock fractures (e.g., Refs. 29, 31). These previous studies have shown that the method can be successfully applied to analyse the flow and transport processes in shear-induced fractures. The demonstration results have important engineering implications even though many outstanding issues remain in the present study. The related engineering implications and remained outstanding issues are discussed below.

4.1
Engineering implications
Quantification of the influence of mechanical displacements on fluid flow and solute transport in fractured rocks is important for many geo-engineering projects, especially for geological disposal of nuclear waste (e.g., Ref. 4). Increases of fracture transmissivity and the associated decreases of advective travel times will cause adverse impact on the safety of nuclear waste isolation. For nearly mated fractures, the peak shear strength has a role as an important threshold for the impact of shear displacement on fluid flow and solute transport behaviour in the fracture. Before the shear stress surpasses the peak shear strength, the fracture can undergo even closure due to the negative shear dilation, as shown in the laboratory shear tests (Fig. 2b). The negative dilation has been widely observed in laboratory shear tests.
19
 In this case, the relatively small shear displacement has negligible effects on the flow and solute transport, where the flow is mostly below the percolation threshold.
14

,

48
 After the shear stress surpasses the peak shear strength, the advective travel time decreases with the increasing shear displacement. These results indicate that it is important to characterize the peak shear strength of rock fractures and the in situ mechanical boundary conditions (CNL or CNS) for predicting the changes of fluid flow and advective transport in practice. The present analysis of fluid flow and advective transport are generally consistent with studies by Zhang and Huang
40
 and Liu et al.
41
, where the transport processes were analysed by solving the advection–dispersion equation in sheared rough rock fractures.


4.2
Outstanding issues
The potential gouge particles from sheared-off asperities or broken grains/particles are ignored in determination of the fracture aperture structures in the present study. As a matter of fact, the gouge particles can affect the shear strength and dilation, which in turn, affect the aperture distributions and the flow and transport processes. Although the amount of gouge particles can be collected after the shear test for analysis (e.g., Refs. 35, 36) and the evolution of gouge particles can be observed in micro shear test using X-ray micro-computed tomography technology (e.g., Ref. 36), directly measuring the evolution of gouge particles in rock fractures with representative sample sizes during the shearing process remains a challenge, especially with the coupling of fluid flow and solute transport processes.
Despite this, Zhao et al.
35
 showed that the shear-induced asperity damage could reduce the dilation under relatively high normal stress levels (
∼
10 MPa) and increase surface areas, which could reduce the fluid flow and enhance the solute retardation. The reduced flow and enhanced retardation can play positive roles in avoiding the spreading of the leaked pollutants, e.g., radionuclides. More quantitative analysis of the impact of gouge particles induced by shear on flow and transport is needed to better understand the mechanical effects on transport in rock fractures.
Another drawback of the method in calculation of aperture based on measured normal displacement is that the local surface deformation and realistic contact conditions are not included. In addition, the fluid flow and solute transport processes directly depend on the changes of aperture structure. In the long-term, fracture apertures could also be altered by fluid flow and reactive chemical transport processes. To understand the detailed coupling between mechanical displacement and chemical transport processes, more sophisticated mechanical models need to be developed (e.g., Refs. 35, 49, 50), and more rigorous flow models based on the Navier–Stokes equations may need to be adopted (e.g., Refs. 26, 27), for the coupling analysis in the future studies.
Limited by the laboratory-scale fracture size, we only demonstrate the impact of shear displacement on advective transport in a relatively small fracture. To what extent these results are representative for a realistic rock fracture at the field scale remains unknown.
51
 Quantifying the potential scale effects requires laboratory shear-flow tests with much larger (e.g., at least at metre scales) fracture samples or reliable field tests, which remains an obvious challenge at present. Moreover, since the shear tests are conducted using high-strength concrete replicas, slight geometrical differences among the replicas may exist, which could introduce potential uncertainty in the shear test results. In addition, as a preliminary study, only a single nearly mated fracture and a single level of initial normal stress were considered in this work. The impacts of fracture roughness, fracture matedness and initial normal stress on the shear-flow-transport processes need to be comprehensively studied with a greater number of shear tests and/or numerical simulations, but also by using more sophisticated shear models.



5
Conclusion
Numerical modelling of fracture flow and transport has been carried out based on the results from laboratory shear tests on fracture replica samples under different mechanical boundary conditions. The main conclusions from the presented study are summarized as follows:



•
The fracture firstly closes before the shear stress approaches the peak shear strength and then opens after surpassing the peak shear strength during the shear process, which results in different flow channelling patterns and travel time distribution features.


•
When the shear displacement is relatively small before the shear stress approaches the peak shear strength, the flow and transport in perfectly mated fractures can be significantly affected because flow in the fracture is near the flow percolation threshold. After the peak, the flow and transport will be dramatically enhanced with the increasing shear displacement due to shear dilation.


•
At the same shear displacement, the fracture aperture is affected by the mechanical boundary conditions, which consequently affect the flow and transport processes. In general, the median advective travel time increases with increasing boundary normal stiffness (CNS condition). At the same initial normal stress, the median advective travel time under the CNS boundary condition is generally longer than that under the CNL boundary condition when the shear displacement is relatively large (larger than 5 mm).


•
The impact of shear displacement on the fluid flow and advective transport is direction dependent. The shear displacement has stronger influence on the flow and transport along the shear direction, by causing heterogeneous and anisotropic flow channels.



The impacts of fracture roughness, fracture matedness, initial normal stress and evolution of gouge materials on stress-dependent transport processes are important topics for future studies. Particularly, (ongoing) studies using larger-sized fracture samples are needed to comprehensively understand the mechanical effects on flow and transport processes in natural fractured rocks at the field scale.

Introduction
There is an increasing rate of greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere. This can have consequences for different ecosystems and human health.
1
 The carbon dioxide capture and storage (CCS) technology is an effective solution to reduce these emissions of CO



2


.

3

,

4
 It is important to know the storage capacity of the reservoir, but this highly depends on temperature and pressure. To store CO2 in a supercritical state (scCO2), deep reservoirs present considerably higher capacities than shallower reservoirs with similar pore volumes.
Furthermore, high pressures and temperatures just above the supercritical point considerably increase the fluid density, and therefore the amount of CO2 that can be stored.
2

The caprock formation is an impermeable barrier that covers the upper part of the reservoir and prevents CO2 leakage to other geological formations. However, during drilling, the zone near the well is damaged. Existing or drilling-induced faults/fractures in the caprock could turn into leakage paths of CO2 to upper environments. Fig. 2 shows the longitudinal cut of samples after 30 days of carbonation. Brown color represents the most degraded part of cement due to carbonation, the color probably being due to iron hydroxide released from chemical reactions.

The penetration depth had significant progress on the cement cured at 90 °C after 30 days of carbonation. These results are similar to observations obtained by other authors for curing and carbonation under similar conditions.

49
 There are some uncertainties based on studies by previous authors, mainly from the curing conditions before carbonation. Indeed, water to cement ratio, curing temperature, pressure, and duration will change the carbonation results, so different curing conditions and equal carbonation procedures will yield different results. Some previous experiences have short curing times for the cement,

,

49

; maintaining a high temperature during a short curing period will allow deeper CO2 penetration into the cement samples and more advanced chemical reactions.



In this work, carbonation led to an increase in the density of PC and BNC05 samples. Before carbonation, a slight difference is noted between PC and BNC05 samples, with densities of 1.89 and 1.87 g/cm3, respectively. Once the samples were carbonated, density increased until 2.13 and 2.11 g/cm3 for PC and BNC05 (Table 2). PC shows an average mass uptake of 13.2%, while BNC05 shows an average of 12.9%, meaning that fewer chemical reactions have taken place. The mass gain is similar to previous works under similar conditions

; however, the penetration depth is different. Our results are closer to the penetrations observed by Fabbri and co-workers,

The oven-drying conditioning for one week at 85 °C has not significantly affected the MIP porosity or the pore size distribution from non-conditioned samples (Fig. 3). MIP porosity performed on these samples increased for both cement types from 33.7% to 34.5%, before the carbonation test, and the characteristic peak is approximately 50 nm. Bacterial nanocellulose did not significantly modify the cement in terms of porosity or pore size distribution compared to PC cement cured at 90 °C. Likely, bacterial nanocellulose does not have the same effect in inhibiting the larger cracks produced by the high curing temperature.
Calorimetry tests have shown that BNC initially acts as a cement retarder.

,

μ

The MIP results after the carbonation of PC are presented in Fig. 4. Here we can observe that the porosity variation along the radial direction leads to smaller pores and smaller porosity values. At the same time, the characteristic peak is shifted to pores smaller than 10 nm. After carbonation, no significant change is observed due to the addition of BNC. Porosity decreased to 24.5% at the core and to 21.5% near the exposed surface. BNC05 shows similar results to PC (Fig. 5), and its porosity decreased at the core to 23.2% and near the exposed surface to 21%. The slight mass uptake is due to the consumption of CO2 by the occurring chemical reactions and is reflected by these small porosity variations. Reduced porosities lead to less diffusion of CO2 into the cement core and therefore increase the time to reach full carbonation of the samples.

In this analysis, cement with nanocellulose addition appears to have lower permeability than cement without additions. After carbonation, the permeability values of PC are reduced by one order of magnitude. In contrast, the permeability in cement with BNC addition is in the same order of magnitude as the initial value. Results on carbonated cement samples require experimental validation.

The analyses show the contents of portlandite, katoite, brownmillerite, magnesite, aragonite, and calcite. Portlandite is one of the main cement hydration products with high crystallinity. In contrast, CSH is a low crystallinity amorphous material. Brownmillerite is a phase of clinker denominated as

When the curing temperature is high, new crystalline phases such as katoite appear. Katoite is a calcium aluminate hydrate more stable at high temperatures than ettringite.


XRD results on cement before supercritical carbonation (Table 4) show approximately 60% hydrated material (portlandite and katoite), 25% carbonated material (calcite and magnesite), and 15% non-hydrated and non-carbonated material (browmillerite). It can be observed that 25% of crystalline material is already carbonated during the curing process before supercritical carbonation. The lack of crystals related to CSH is due to the insufficient intensity of reflection of this amorphous material.

XRD results on cement after supercritical carbonation show no cement hydration materials (portlandite and katoite). Therefore, it signifies complete carbonation. Magnesite also seems to have been consumed, allowing the formation of more calcium carbonates. Approximately 93% are crystalline carbonate materials; the remaining 7% is

PC strength initially was 31 MPa, and after the carbonation stage, it increased by 44%, while BNC05 started with 24 MPa of strength, which increased by 60% with carbonation. Alternatively, this effect appears later because of the retarder effect of BNC or the superplasticizer, which slow down the hydration rate of the modified cement, and thus the hydration degree at the end of the curing time.
It is well known that carbonation under atmospheric conditions tends to increase the mechanical properties of cement.

25

Therefore, the mechanical performance increment after carbonation will most likely be due to the cement matrix development by hydration acceleration imposed by temperature in the carbonation cell. The tested material’s mechanical properties will be a combination of the effects of cement hydration compounds and precipitated calcite produced during carbonation.
On the other hand, well-hydrated cement will only experience a drop in strength due to CSH degradation and porosity increase over time.

Indeed, if cement carbonation is imposed by a continuously renewed fluid, then the products of carbonation (mainly carbonates), will in turn dissolve and be flushed out, leading to a strong increase in porosity of the cement, and degraded mechanical properties. In the present experiment, CO2 penetrates the sample by dissolution and diffusion in the pore fluid, which is not renewed.
Since CC has better mechanical performance than CH, CC precipitation should increase mechanical performance and Young’s modulus of carbonated cement. This effect can occur here because of the continuous hydration of cement inside the reactor, which links the precipitated CC with the cement matrix. Numerical analysis of carbonated samples
In this section, the numerical analysis of the carbonated BNC samples is presented. A 2D analysis is performed simulating the experimental carbonation of the cylindrical samples. Calibration on the model is made by taking the porosity values obtained experimentally to estimate the intrinsic parameters of this cement.
70
 The initial volumetric proportions of the minerals in the cement are estimated from the literature. The calibrated model is extrapolated to simulate in 1D the cement carbonation in a wellbore system under downhole conditions.

5.1
Initial parameters and intrinsic properties of cement
Porosity is very variable for cement and depends mainly on the water to cement ratio and on the type of curing in which the specimen is placed. Some authors estimate porosities greater than 30%,

,

49

,

71

,

72

73–76
 Regardless of the kind of oil cement in question (G or H), it can be generalized that the porosities of oil cement are around 25% to 35%. The initial porosity of the samples in this work before carbonation is 34.5%, as indicated in Section 4.


The volumetric content of cement minerals depends substantially on the cement type, water to cement ratio, hydration degree, and curing temperature. So, it is necessary to estimate these proportions for the simulation. In some articles, the amount of Portlandite CH varies between 15 to 25%,

,

74

38
 In previous results, using the same cement and same water to cement ratio,

≤

≤

,

 Finally, the essential cement phase in terms of compressive strength, CSH, can vary between 60 to 27% in volume fraction.
38

,

77


The intrinsic permeability is independent of the conditions to which the material is initially subjected, at least directly. Since the cement is a heterogeneous material, there is no unique intrinsic permeability value for cement. Nelson et al.

The diffusivity of cement of class G and H has also been variable, as reported by different authors. Huet et al. 
80

79

The remaining compounds are classified as inert components, including amorphous silica, which is a carbonation product. Fig. 10 shows in more detail the dissolution and carbonation fronts. The blue line corresponds to the starting point of the chemical reaction of CH. In contrast, the red line is the limit between the carbonation process and the full carbonated zone. Some authors consider that the carbonation front or penetration depth follows a linear trend as a function of the square root of time (consistently because the chemical reactions are limited by the diffusion of CO2 within the fluid phase).

,

83
 Nevertheless, this is usually based on the phenolphthalein test, which only considers the pH below 9. With the present model, we can distinguish the two fronts. In a first contact between the cement and scCO2, there is a significant decrease in CH and CSH content that lasts for the first few days. After 10 days, the dissolution front reaches the center of the cement sample. The complete reaction of CH and CSH front advances almost linearly in time but, it does not reach the cement center. Calcite is mostly deposited in the material near the exposed surface, decreasing its porosity, while it has not yet wholly precipitated in the core.
Even though the dissolution front has reached the center, the chemical reactions between CO2 and CH/CSH, which produce CC and water, are still taking place in a region located 1 cm away from the center. This means that all CH and CSH leaching is not complete after 30 days in these conditions.


The calibrated parameters are extrapolated to the cement submitted under downhole conditions in the context of CO2 geological storage. We have to keep in mind that curing and carbonation conditions are unfavorable to cement in the experimental results. However, the numerical model can be adapted to any condition considered. From this approach, additional characteristics of the carbonation front variability using these transport parameters can be obtained: permeability (Fig. 11) and volumetric proportions (Fig. 12) variations throughout the sample. Carbonation advance forms calcite from CH and CSH, which grows inside the pores. This produces a reduction of the porosity and, consequently, a decrease in permeability and diffusivity, which slow down the entry of more CO2 to the cement core. In Fig. 11, this can be seen as a clogging effect. After 5 days of carbonation, we can observe a considerable CO2 penetration, but after 5 more days, the penetration rate has significantly slowed down. The calcite penetration in Fig. 12 starts with the CH area dissolution and continues with the CSH decalcification when there is no longer CH to consume. CSH decalcification continues creating CC and amorphous silica, which becomes part of the inert components.



6
Conclusion
The microstructure and mechanical changes of cement with bacterial nanocellulose additions and cured at 90 °C in the context of reservoir conditions were analyzed. Mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP), X-ray diffraction (XRD), ultrasonic wave measurements, and unconfined compressive strength (UCS) tests were performed on BNC-cement samples subjected to supercritical CO2 conditions to determine its behavior. In addition, a finite-element based numerical analysis of the cement–rock interface was presented.
BNC samples show a lower mass gain compared to PC, suggesting that fewer chemical reactions occurred. Nevertheless, the BNC-cement longitudinal sections present some small voids in their interior, which could allow further CO2 penetration.
The MIP results show that initially, the BNC samples have the same porosity as the cement without BNC addition. After carbonation, lower porosity is observed in cement with BNC, either in the core or near the exposed surface. From the MIP curves, a permeability analysis was performed. In this analysis, the samples with BNC show lower intrinsic permeability values than the cement without BNC.
The XRD results of the PC and BNC05 samples before and after carbonation show no difference from each other. After carbonation, the dominant crystalline phases are calcite and aragonite, which indicates the complete carbonation of the material near the surface exposed to the gas.
Unmodified samples show a better mechanical performance during carbonation. However, carbonation in samples with BNC indicates a higher increase in relative strength than in samples without additions due to the BNC effect of releasing water during hydration inside the carbonation cell.
A chemo-poro-mechanical model of scCO2 attack on a cement annulus of an abandoned oil well in the context of CO2 storage was presented. A modification on the formulation was implemented to add the nanocellulose characteristics. The experimental data and simulation results were back analyzed to determine the properties of the cement used. Once these properties were known, a simulation under downhole conditions in the context of CO2 geological storage was represented.
Results show a decrease in permeability and hydration products over time and the advance of the dissolution and carbonation fronts. The numerical study shows the advantage of using this type of tool to study possible real scenarios of CO2 injection processes in deep wells. It can be adapted to different systems under different established conditions.
