1
Energy geo-structures and soldier pile walls
Energy geo-structures are a relatively recent application of shallow geothermal energy, which can provide clean and renewable thermal energy for heating and cooling purposes and thus contribute to the world’s ever-increasing needs of ensuring energy supply and reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Unlike traditional shallow geothermal or ground source heat pump (GSHP) applications (such as purpose-built vertical boreholes or horizontal trenches
1–3
) energy geo-structures utilise underground structures primarily designed for stability (mainly foundations) to incorporate energy provision as an additional/secondary function.
4–8
 The implementation of the technology in foundation structures that are already planned to be constructed can significantly reduce capital costs and open new opportunities to further utilise this technology and increase the renewable portion of the world’s energy supply.
Structures that have been utilised as energy geo-structures so far consist of piles, retaining walls and tunnels, with piles having attracted most of the attention by the scientific community, likely due to their geometrical similarities to the well-studied traditional vertical boreholes. There have been a number of studies on energy piles with overall positive and encouraging results for the industry of shallow geothermal energy.
9–14
 Similarly positive results have been shown by some studies on energy tunnels
15–18
 and energy retaining walls, mainly diaphragm walls.
19–23
 Less attention, however, has been given to other possible geo-structures, particularly soldier pile retaining walls, which this work investigates.
Energy retaining wall design can be more challenging to design compared to the more thoroughly investigated energy piles. A main difference between them is the fact that a retaining wall is only surrounded by ground on one of its sides, where the other one (or part of it) can form the underground space of a building. This not only results in less thermal storage being available but, perhaps more importantly, means that heat transfer must be controlled to avoid impacting on the thermal comfort of the underground building (i.e., the inner built environment), for example, by the use of thermal insulation.
24
 While a recent study focuses on the impact of the wall boundary conditions on effective heat transfer yields and the potential repercussions of ill-defined boundary conditions,
24
 the impact on the thermal performance of the key design physical parameters, such as the pipe length, the soldier pile spacing and the pile depth has not been studied for this type of retaining walls. Energy retaining wall design needs to carefully consider all these aspects to ensure that the system can provide as much thermal energy as possible, without impacting on the otherwise construction and operation of the building.
The design of energy geo-structures has mostly focused around two areas: geo-mechanical and thermal design. The first area mainly investigates the mechanical/structural impact that incorporating the geothermal piping and operating the system can have on the underground structures.
25–32
 These investigations consider characteristic stresses, strains etc. and are essential to ensure there will not be any undesirable effects, such as settlement. The second area investigates the thermal performance of these structures, considering the heat transfer in the various media and answering the key question of how much energy can be provided by the system.
33–35
 The presented work is part of this second category, investigating the thermal design of energy soldier pile walls and considering the effect of important design parameters, such as the pipe configuration, wall depth and pile spacing on the thermal performance of the system.

2.1

This work investigates the thermal design of soldier pile retaining walls, adopting a typical geometry for the foundations of a high-rise building in Melbourne Australia. The investigation is undertaken using a finite element numerical modelling approach developed within the University of Melbourne implemented in the software package COMSOL Multiphysics. The approach has been thoroughly validated using traditional borehole GHEs as well as energy geo-structures including piles, walls and tunnels.

,

Given the location of the adopted geometry, the effect of groundwater flow is not considered in this study (even though the model can account for it if required). The thermal load utilised in this work is based on typical monthly heating and cooling requirements for a high rise building in Melbourne, Australia (the geothermal systems providing part of the overall building demand as part of a more complicated hybrid system

The unbalanced distribution represents the more typical commercial thermal needs, which are mainly in cooling. Understanding that these are unfavourable operating conditions for a GSHP, a balanced load distribution is also introduced, where equal amount of heating (to match the cooling demand of the building) is provided mostly over the winter months. On the other hand, spacing scenario 2, considers the case where, similarly, not all piles are thermally activated, but in order to satisfy the total thermal energy needs, one must exchange more heat with the ground per pile. In other words, in this second scenario, thermally activating less piles (such as every second/third/fourth soldier pile, instead of every single one) does increase their effective GHE pile ‘thermal’ spacing but also increases the thermal load per GHE and therefore more thermal energy is demanded by each pile GHE. This scenario may represent a more realistic case given the typically lower thermal yield of energy walls than that of energy piles, and a geothermal design decision is less constrained by the structural aspects. Even though increasing the thermal load per GHE can decrease their thermal performance, activating less overall piles could decrease (or eliminate) the thermal interference between the GHEs (which can be significant due to the typical short pile spacing), as well as result in less associated costs for materials and installation. 2.4
Adopted evaluation metrics
This work utilises numerical modelling to analyse the long-term thermal performance of energy soldier piles under a number of different conditions. Each such simulation considers 25 years of operation of the GSHP system. From the outputs of the numerical simulation of great interest are the temperatures of the carrier fluid, which can determine if the design is acceptable (i.e. if the considered thermal energy can be feasibly provided by the system) by inspecting the range of these temperatures over the 25-year period. Importantly, the temperatures of the carrier fluid (connecting to the GSHP) need to be within the operating range of the ground-source heat pump. Moreover, extremes should be avoided to prevent potential issues, such as freezing of the ground. This temperature range is typically about 0 °C to 40 °C, with more recent heat pumps being able to push these boundaries further (at the expense of efficiency). In reality the case specific application of the energy geo-structures can also affect this range and in certain conditions the temperature limits need to be stricter than others (to avoid for example heat leaking in the building

1
Introduction
Geothermal energy is among the most important renewable and sustainable energy sources on Earth
1
, and many different technologies exist for capturing this type of energy. This study focused on a particular type of shallow geothermal application: energy geostructures (EGs)
2
. EG, which are also called thermo-active geostructures, are innovative civil engineering geostructures that couple the structural role with a heat exchanger role. The transition from regular geostructures to EGs is simple, it only requires heat exchangers (HEs) to be installed and secured to the reinforcing cage whenever a new geostructure is needed. Some of the main advantages of this technology are that energy is continuously available, regardless of weather conditions, it is available almost everywhere and it is usable in a wide range of applications
3–10
. Possible applications of EGs and shallow geothermal systems include: (i) heating and cooling of civil engineering structures (residential and commercial buildings, industries, etc.)
11–14
, (ii) production of hot water for agricultural needs
15–17
, (iii) de-icing of deck, bridge and road pavements
18

,

19
. EG technology has been developed over the past decades
20
 and exhibits a good potential for energy production
11
, enabling the satisfaction of the heating and cooling needs of the built environment.

In this study, thermo-active walls, i.e., energy walls (EWs), are investigated. Typical examples of EW are single and multi-floored underground infrastructures (e.g., train stations, underground car parks, and basements of high-rise buildings) and shallow cut-and-cover tunnels
21–27
. Among the various types of EGs, EWs represent a relatively new technology; consequently, numerous challenges exist. First, the heat transfer modes and the interactions between the EWs and the surrounding materials are not fully understood. Second, there is a lack of methods and guidelines for the thermal and mechanical analysis and design of EWs.
This study focused on the definition of the thermal performance of EWs. The objective was to develop a methodology for early-stage thermal performance design based on analysis of the hydrothermal behavior of EWs implemented in a one-level underground infrastructure. Herein, the main characteristics of the hydrothermal behavior of EGs that must be considered in the thermal performance design are first outlined. Second, the features of a numerical model employed to investigate the hydrothermal behavior of EWs are presented. Then, the results of extensive numerical analyses (i.e., parametric analyses) are presented as charts that describe the thermal potential of installing EWs in different thermal environments and geometrical conditions. Finally, a design methodology with a sound theoretical basis that links the heat transfers, fluid dynamics, and seepage in porous media is developed and presented as a flowchart. This technique can easily be employed by designers to evaluate the thermal potential of EWs at a known site.

2.4
Definition and choice of thermal input
The choice of the thermal input is crucial for defining the thermal behavior of the HE. The selected numerical model includes the convective and conductive heat transfers within the fluid, pipe material, concrete, soil and air. In a real application, the thermal input imposed by the heat pump to the primary circuit satisfies the (total or partial) energy demand of the served superstructure. Because this study deals with the preliminary design stages of a project, there are numerous challenges related to the selection of the thermal input.
First, a broad variety of energy demand curves exist for different types of civil engineering structures and shallow geothermal applications. It is difficult to define a reliable thermal input that is representative of all the possible conditions, for winter and summer operations. Second, the elements constituting the EG exhibit a response that differs with respect to time and space
45

28

A trade-off can be achieved by using relatively short-time constant temperature inputs, to detect the response of the EG both in the transient and steady flux conditions, providing a comprehensive overview of the thermal behavior of the HE when either the short term (intermittent) or long term constant modes is selected
29

It is possible to evaluate the dynamic thermal behavior of the HE by applying the Duhamel principle: the dynamic problem can be solved by accounting for a sequence of infinitesimal impulses of different amplitudes, as shown in Ref. 45. Moreover, at the early stages of EG design, the energy demand curve may not yet be defined with sufficient accuracy. For these reasons, a constant with time temperature input was set. 3
Results and discussion
The results of the numerical analyses are presented in this section, with a focus on the HE scale and the thermal response of the HEs. The results are presented as charts corresponding to selected times, allowing the short-term and steady flux responses to be evaluated. The time dependent HE response is first described. Second, design charts aiming at highlighting the effects of soil thermal characterization are proposed. The subsequent section is dedicated to the structural thermal characterization. Additionally, a flowchart to be employed for early-stage thermal performance design is proposed. Table 5 presents the ranges of the parameters introduced in Section 2.2.

The HE’s thermal response was evaluated accounting to the power extraction/injection rate using Eq. (3). A fluid velocity and a temperature were imposed at the pipe inlet, while the fluid temperature at the outflow was monitored. According to the time dependency of the thermal response of the HE to a constant thermal input (Section 2.4), two zones were defined (Fig. 5): (i) an initial, time dependent portion (the duration depending on the fluid velocity, the pipe loop length and shape) in which the heat exchanges were governed by the heat capacity and the thermal conductivities of the involved materials (called “transient”), and (ii) a time-independent phase where the heat exchanges were governed by the thermal conductivities of the materials only (steady flux).

Under transient conditions, the volume of materials affected by the heat flow quickly increases with time: the portion of soil affected by the thermal exchange was on the scale of decimeters to meters. The groundwater flow presence (if any) interacts with the increasing soil volume in which the heat exchange occurs. Because of this interaction, for the short-term response, the seepage may not significantly enhance the behaviors of the HEs. The impact of the groundwater flow on enhancing the heat transfer process increases as steady flux conditions are approached. Owing to the spatial evolution of the heat exchange processes in the soil, the power injection/extraction rate decreases with time. The temperature distribution in the soil was hence transient, and the heat front moved in the direction of the seepage
28
.


Once the steady flux was reached, the thermal response of the HEs was time independent. This condition was reached after an activation time on the order of 

10

d

 and allowed us to define and analyze long term energy exploitation scenarios
29
. The soil volume involved in the heat exchange reached its definitive evolution and was recorded on the scale of a few cubic meters around the EG. If groundwater flow is present, the soil volume affected by the thermal exchanges was significantly larger depending on the direction and magnitude of the seepage. In this condition, mutual interactions among the seepage and the HE occurred: on one hand, the seepage affected the heat exchanges by moving the heat in the space, and on the other hand, the thermal activation induced local seepage variations
28
.
To study the time-dependent behavior of the HEs’ response, three time steps were examined, with the aim of comprehensively evaluating the time-dependent heat transfer rates. The selected timesteps were: 2, 5, and 50 d. The first aimed at defining the short-term response (e.g. representing highly intermittent heat pump functioning), the second provided an average value for the transient condition, and the third provided a measure of the long-term seasonal performance.

3.3
A flowchart for early-stage thermal performance design
This section aims at linking the subsoil characteristics and environmental air conditions to the energy quantities achievable with EWs by defining a flowchart that can be used not only for the preliminary thermal design of EWs but also for the decision-making process to decide whether to employ EGs in an infrastructure project. The required input parameters are related to the basic hydro-thermal properties of the site: estimations of the thermal properties of the involved materials and the possible presence and velocity of groundwater flow that may significantly interact with the infrastructure. The flowchart comprises two steps. First, according to the fluid dynamics theory, the main heat exchange mechanism is defined. Second, by selecting the input thermal properties, thermal performance of HEs embedded in EWs is estimated. The objective of this section is to propose a design methodology for energy evaluations at preliminary design stages, to address a frequently asked question: how much energy is achievable by using this technology at a known site?

4
Conclusions
This paper summarizes some concepts of hydro-thermal interactions applied to EWs and presented a methodology for the early-stage thermal performance design of such EGs.
A portion of an energy infrastructure was numerically modeled, and the thermal behavior was discussed with reference to different environmental conditions. Groundwater flow in the soil enhances the heat exchanges but induces adverse hydraulically induced thermal interactions among adjoining pipe loops. The performance of one HE loop under parallel groundwater flow conditions is higher than that for a perpendicular groundwater flow. Within this framework, the time-dependent nature of the HEs response is highlighted. The structural thermal characterization plays a significant role, and precise quantification of the thermal conductivity is hardly feasible, owing to the broad range of values available in the literature, the dependency on many parameters (such as the density and degree of saturation), and the long-term interactions with the soil. Consequently, the response of the HEs may vary significantly.
A methodology for early-stage thermal performance design of EWs was proposed. It has a sound theoretical basis that helps to account for the multiphysical phenomena interacting with one another (thermodynamics, fluid dynamics) at different scales. Once the basic hydro-thermal characteristics of a site are known, the proposed flowchart can be used to determine the power extraction/injection rates expressed in

This methodology will help designers to perform a preliminary quantification of the energy achievable by equipping an infrastructure with EWs during the early-stage design phases. Moreover, it may impact the decision-making process when the question is whether or not to install thermo-active elements on a planned infrastructure project. The data included in this design tool represent a conservative estimation of the power rate because of the definition of steady flux conditions with respect to the selected thermal input.

1
Introduction
Increasing energy demands and the pressing need to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from fossil fuels has led to a focus on finding alternative renewable energy sources. Geothermal energy is recognised as a clean and renewable energy source which can greatly contribute towards meeting our future energy needs.
1
 Ground Source Heat Pump (GSHP) systems, also known as shallow geothermal energy systems, utilise the ground as a heat source or heat sink to provide efficient space heating and cooling. In GSHP systems, a primary circuit embedded in the ground is linked to a secondary circuit installed in the user space with both circuits connected via a heat pump.
2–6
 Ground Heat Exchanger (GHE) is the major component of the primary circuit and comprises of absorber pipes with circulating heat carrier fluid (typically water) embedded in the ground. Taking advantage of the relatively stable and moderate ground temperature at shallow depths (up to 200 m) as well as the considerably large heat capacity of the ground, GSHP systems can achieve 40%–60% higher efficiency, 30%–40% average operating cost savings and over 40% reductions in pollutant discharges compared to conventional heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems.
7
 Despite the well-known advantages, the primary drawback of the traditional GSHP systems is the high capital investment associated with the drilling and trenching required to install GHEs, which impedes the uptake of this technology.
8


Energy geo-structures are considered as innovative alternatives to traditional GSHP systems, as geothermal piping is incorporated into foundation structures (such as piles, retaining walls, tunnel linings), allowing them to function as GHEs in addition to serving structural purposes as foundations.
9–17
 This approach eliminates the necessity for drilling or trenching purpose-built GHEs, substantially reducing the required capital investment and furthering the economic viability of GSHP systems.
10

,

18–20
 On the other hand, energy geo-structures bring new challenges to geothermal system design. The geometrical properties and thermal conditions of energy geo-structures have significant disparities with the thoroughly studied traditional borehole systems, suggesting that the available thermal design methods for traditional borehole systems could hardly be adopted, nor adapted, particularly for certain energy geo-structures.
11

,

21–24
 In addition, the operation of GSHP systems induces thermo-mechanical loading on the structures, thus further complicating their structural and thermal analysis and design.
25–28
 Moreover, the design of ground heat exchanger (GHE) is greatly restrained by the structural design, which limits the system’s ability to fulfill the entirety of the thermal demand for the end user, thus requires further guidance and better management of the design thermal load.
In recent years, there is growing interest among scientific and industrial communities in the application of shallow geothermal technology to retaining walls. Some experimental and numerical investigations have been undertaken to further understand the thermal and thermo-mechanical performance of energy retaining walls.
22

,

28–36
 The importance of the boundary conditions of the excavation space and the pipe configuration on the thermal performance of energy retaining walls have been specifically addressed. However, most of the energy retaining wall studies have focused on diaphragm walls, while limited works have dealt with piled walls. Brandl
18
 reported a thoroughly instrumented energy bored piled wall installation in the Lainzer tunnel as a part of heating and cooling system of the railway stations, administration and residential buildings. The measured temperature and strain data demonstrated that the temperature variation from the energy system operation is smaller than those due to natural fluctuations and the temperature-induced deformations are significantly smaller than those induced by the excavation. Suckling and Smith
37
 described an installation project of energy piles and a bored pile retaining wall at Keble College, Oxford, the first energy pile project in the United Kingdom. Ground loops were casted in piles and subsequently connected to the heating and cooling system of the building above. However, this study has little discussions in the thermal design of these structures, the followed thermal performance of the system in operation has not yet been reported and discussed. Bourne-Webb and da Costa
38
 presented a high-level study on the effect of differing conditions in the tunnel on the thermal response of the wall using a 2D steady state numerical model. The study emphasised the importance of evaluating tunnel environment in assessing the thermal performance of energy wall systems. Despite these studies, the available literature on energy piled walls is still relatively limited, the experimental data on the thermal performance of energy piled walls are even scarcer, limiting the undertaking of a broader analysis. It should be noted that the diaphragm wall is a continuous wall constructed in-situ panel by panel, while piled walls are formed by constructing a series of piles to support excavation activities and retain soil laterally, the differences in the geometries and construction methods require different thermal design considerations.
It is well recognised in the literature
31–33

,

39

,

40
 that the manner in which the GHE is constructed greatly impacts the thermal performance of GSHP systems. Unlike diaphragm walls, in which the pipes can be placed throughout the panels that comprise the wall, pipes in piled retaining walls are likely to be clustered in the piles, potentially resulting in higher concentration of heat and raising concern of thermal interference between closely spaced pipes and piles. Thus, it is important to consider the thermo-active pile spacing into the geothermal design. This paper aims to provide insights and further understanding of the effect of pile spacing on the thermal performance of energy piled walls and contribute to an easily adoptable thermal design approach. Although in real-world applications pile spacing is principally dictated by geotechnical design and unlikely to be affected by geothermal concerns, a comprehensive understanding of the thermal effect of pile spacing can greatly assist in the design and decision making regarding how many piles should be thermally activated in wall systems. Of key interest is the balance between the system thermal performance and the associated material and installation costs of geothermal pipes.
In this paper, the effect of pile spacing is evaluated by experimental and numerical studies. A pilot soldier piled wall within an underground metro station, located in Melbourne, Australia, has been thermally activated by embedding geothermal pipes into three adjacent soldier piles in which the pipes were connected in parallel above the ground surface. The wall section has been instrumented, tested and monitored by the University of Melbourne to provide full scale data. The collected data were not only used to investigate the role of thermo-active pile spacing on the thermal performance of the energy soldier piled wall, but also formed important datasets for the validation of numerical modelling approaches of energy piled wall. Detailed finite element modelling is utilised to simulate the thermal performance of the system under different thermo-active pile spacings. In addition, a comprehensive sensitivity study is performed to understand the effect of the pile spacing under various system designs and ground conditions.


2
Methodology
Experimental investigations and finite element modelling are utilised in this study to understand both the short and long-term performance of energy piled walls, focusing on the effect of pile spacing. Section 2.1 presents the experimental study on an instrumented pilot energy soldier piled wall installed within an excavated metro station in Melbourne, Australia. Section 2.1.1 introduces the experimental site in detail and Section 2.1.2 describes two in-situ thermal response test (TRT) set ups conducted on the pilot energy pile wall, covering two different thermo-pile spacings. The experimental investigation concerns the real thermal response of the energy piled wall and enables to provide key insights on the effect of pile spacing on the thermal performance of the system. This is particularly valuable as no such data is currently available for energy piled walls in the literature. To further understand the effect of pile spacing on the thermal performance of energy piled walls for a wide spectrum of cases in real life scenario, a numerical simulation approach described in Section 2.2 is also utilised in this study to perform numerical analyses of energy piled wall systems adopting the metro station as a case study. Section 2.2.1 presents a short overview of the numerical model, while Section 2.2.2 describes in detail the model geometries and boundary conditions adopted in simulating TRT1 and TRT2 for validation purposes. Furthermore, the parameters used to simulate the long-term thermal performance of energy piled walls for assessing the effect of pile spacing are also detailed. To investigate the effect of some other important design parameters on the energy wall design and the thermal performance of the wall, a parametric analysis is introduced in Section 2.2.3. Finally, Section 2.2.4 describes the significance of the effect of pile spacing in the real-world design applications with respect to the energy potential and costs.




2.1
Experimental study

2.1.1
Pilot energy soldier piled wall
This body of work utilises the unique opportunity to work with the Melbourne Metro Railway Authority (MMRA) and the well-known Melbourne Metro project to add field testing and data monitoring on a real-scale energy piled wall. The experimental section of energy piled wall was installed and instrumented in one of the underground station’s shafts of the Melbourne Metro project, which is currently under construction. The main geological formation in the study area is Melbourne formation, which consists of sandstone and siltstone, much weathered close to the surface. Current literature and research indicates that the thermal conductivity of the Melbourne formation is expected to be 2.68 

±
0
.
62

 W/(m K).
41–43
 This serves as an excellent material for geothermal projects. The water table was found to lie approximately 15 m below ground surface before the excavation took place, and no ground water flow is observed according to the project record. Prior to the time of the field tests, an acoustic shed had been constructed to cover the excavation space and a temporary ventilation system was installed for dust extraction and thermal comfort during the construction.
As seen in Fig. 1, the station is about 15 m in width and 40 m in length, supported by soldier piled walls, formed by 68 bored cast in-situ piles with shotcrete walls in between the piles. Each pile is 1.05 m in diameter and 40 m in depth, with the final embedment depth being 5 m at the completion stage. The centre-to-centre spacing between adjacent piles is 1.8 m, and the thickness of the shotcrete wall applied between the piles is 0.15 m. Four U-loops made of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) pipe with an outer diameter of 25 mm, were connected in series, and attached to the reinforcing steel cages within P49 and P50, and two U-loops were connected in series and attached to P51 (Fig. 2
). These pile loops have been connected in parallel through a manifold system installed above the surface, resulting in a common joint inlet and outlet. The application of the manifold system allows for activation of different combinations of pile loops depending on study purposes. Amongst these three piles, P50 and P51 have been instrumented with temperature sensors built in strainmeters located at various positions and depth (Fig. 1a). One multi-channel Vibrating Wire datalogger was connected to these sensors to collect pile temperature (and strain) data with an additional temperature sensor embedded in the datalogger indicating the ambient station temperature. These measurements are very valuable for assessing the thermal aspects of the response of the energy soldier pile wall.





2.1.2
In-situ TRTs set up
In-situ thermal response testing (TRT) involves heating fluid using electrical heating elements at a constant power and circulating the fluid in the pipe loops within a GHE. The inlet and outlet fluid temperatures are recorded over time, as well as the flow rate and power consumption. This test is considered to be the most accurate method to estimate ground thermal parameters, including undisturbed ground temperature, ground thermal conductivity and GHE thermal resistance, as it enables researchers to capture the in-situ ground conditions such as local geology, ground water flow, and states of stress.
44–46
 TRTs have been considered as a standard test for geothermal projects. However, TRTs have mainly been performed on borehole heat exchangers. Over the last few years, the applicability of this test has been extended to energy piles, which share similar geometry and conditions as borehole heat exchangers.
46–53
 TRT data and relevant case studies for energy retaining walls are very scarce, perhaps due to the absence of easily adoptable analytical approaches for data interpretation, the complexity of the test execution, and in certain cases the difficulties of performing the test due to the wall construction methods.
54


To experimentally investigate the effect of pile spacing as well as to broaden TRT studies on energy retaining walls, two in-situ TRTs, namely TRT1 and TRT2, have been performed on the experimental site in this work under the same excavation level of approximately 32.5 m. In both tests, a pile with 4 U-loops, and a pile with 2 U-loops were connected in parallel via the manifold system (Fig. 3). The spacing between the two pile loops was varied between TRT1 and TRT2 to serve the study purpose. Specifically, TRT1 was conducted on P50 and P51 with a centre-to-centre pile spacing of 1.8 m, while TRT2 was conducted on P49 and P51 with a pile spacing of 3.6 m (Fig. 3). Note that P51 pipe configuration is different from than that of P49 and P50, however given that P51 is involved in both tests, the only major variable involved is pile spacing, all other parameters being approximately equal, including total and individual pile flow rates. To ensure that proper testing conditions had been met, a series of pre-tests were conducted, including bench testing of the TRT unit to ensure its functionality, flushing and purging of the ground loops and manifold system to eliminate air bubbles, and pressure testing to ensure that there was no leakage in the pipe system.
During TRT1 and TRT2, a heating power of 5.5 kW was constantly supplied to the system for a duration of three weeks. A flow sensor was placed inside the TRT unit near the point where the fluid entered the pile loops from the TRT unit. Between the two tests, all heating elements were switched off and only the circulation pump was left running for approximately 3 weeks to help the ground dissipate the remaining heat. The TRT fluid temperatures and flow rate were measured in 10-minute intervals during both tests. In addition to the relevant TRT data, ambient pile and station temperatures during the tests have also been monitored and collected to help further understanding the heat transfer process as well as assessing the effect of thermo-active pile spacing on the thermal response of energy soldier piled walls. A temperature sensor was placed within P50 towards to the station side at a depth of 23.1 m from the ground surface (P50-S) and another two pairs of temperature sensors were placed towards to the ground side of P50 at a depth of 9.0 m and 19.7 m (P50-G). Temperature was also monitored within P51 at a depth of 9.0 m and 19.7 m in both the ground side (P51-G) and the station side (P51-S). The monitored pile temperatures were measured in 5-minute intervals. The pile temperature measurements can contribute to the investigation on the effect of pile spacing, as well as help in differentiating the thermal influence from the ground and the station and provide an understanding of the heat exchange within the different piles at different depths.






2.2
Numerical modelling

2.2.1
Overview
The numerical modelling and analyses performed in this work are conducted using a detailed 3D finite element model developed by the University of Melbourne
40

,

55
 and implemented in COMSOL Multiphysics. The model couples and solves the governing equations of heat transfer and fluid flow characterised by the conservation of momentum, mass, and energy equations. The 3D model considers both heat conduction and convection. The conductive heat transfer primarily occurs in the solid elements such as the ground, the concrete pile, shotcrete wall and the HDPE pipe walls, and partially in the heat carrier fluid inside the pipes, whereas the convective heat transfer mainly occurs in the heat carrier fluid circuiting inside the pipes. For the fluid flow within the pipes, 1D elements are used to model the pipes considering the fluid flow is fully developed. The continuity and momentum equations for impressible fluid flow and the energy equation for conductive–convective heat transfer in the carrier fluid are employed in the 1D pipe element, and the results of the temperature of the pipe wall are coupled to the 3D heat transfer elements in the remaining geometry. Detailed information and the complete governing equations can be found in Refs. 40, 55, 56. The effect of groundwater flow, including the dewatering process, is not covered in this numerical study, which is considered as a conservative approach since the presence of groundwater flow enhances the heat exchange between the absorber piles and the surrounding ground and thus improves the thermal performance of GSHP systems. The numerical model is firstly built to simulate the experimental site under the TRTs conditions to increase the confidence in the numerical model and to further investigate the heat transfer process occurred in the wall during the TRTs. Then the model is modified to investigate the long-term performance of energy retaining wall under operational conditions. Calibrated soil conditions and concrete properties are adopted, and the relevant material properties are listed in Table 1.

Readers will note that the fluid inlet temperatures collected from the in-situ experiments were used as one of the inputs to replicate the TRTs in the numerical simulations as the data are readily available and are able to account for the uncertainties encountered during the actual field tests, such as power fluctuation. On the other hand, GHEs design relies on the building thermal load profile estimated typically by mechanical engineers. Thus, a prescribed thermal load profile is employed to assess the long-term performance of energy walls in terms of resulting fluid temperatures in the long-term numerical simulations under realistic operational conditions, further details are included later in Section 2.2.5. It is noted that in the general literature the thermal performance of GSHP systems are customarily assessed by employing a constant fluid inlet temperature over time.
24

,

28

,

32

,

57
 This approach reports a heat exchange power value expressed in W/m or W/m2 that is simple to use for comparison and often used in nominal mechanical design. However, under real operating conditions, the GSHP systems operate under varying and complex inlet temperature over time, in response to varying thermal loads only available in the design stage when detailed building energy models are undertaken. In this work, the long-term operational simulations use the latter approach, with the provision of time-varying thermal loads as input rather than nominal constant inlet temperatures.

Results

3.1
Experimental observations
As explained in Section 2.1, two TRT tests were undertaken and monitored within this study, the results of which, in terms of the measured inlet and outlet fluid temperatures, are shown in Fig. 7. The flow rates for TRT1 and TRT2 were also measured during the test, with the averages being 22.0 L/min and 22.3 L/min respectively. Given that P51 incorporated less pipe length than P49 and P50 do (recall Fig. 3), the flow rates in the individual piles differ, being approximately 12.7 L/min for P51 and approximately 8.8 L/min for piles P49 and P50. TRT1 involved P50 and P51 (
∼
1.8 m apart) and TRT2 involved P49 and P51 (
∼
3.6 m apart), given the P51 is involved in both tests, the only major variable in the tests is pile spacing, all other parameters being approximately equal, including total and individual pile flow rates.

As shown in the figure, both tests have displayed similar trends for the first two weeks, increasing sharply at the beginning and becoming steadier and steadier which are very much typical thermal response curves for traditional borehole systems, but the fluid temperatures in TRT2 is maintained slightly higher than TRT1. It should be noted here that the starting inlet temperature for TRT2 is 19.7 °C, which is 1.3 °C higher than the starting temperature for TRT1 (18.4 °C). This suggests that there was residual heat at the beginning of TRT2 resulting from the running of TRT1. Moreover, it is interesting to observe that the fluid temperatures in TRT1 start to rise again after the second week, while the fluid temperatures in TRT2 remained rather steady. A possible reason for this would be that there was stronger thermal interference between the closely spaced P50 and P51 piles after the second week, causing the somehow unexpected temperature build up in TRT1. On the other hand, P49 and P51 in TRT2 are spaced further apart, and thus in TRT2 less thermal interference was observed. Another possible cause for this would be the rising temperature in the station air space might be due to change in the weather or operation of ventilation systems.

Temperatures along the piles in both the ground (G) and station shaft (S) sides were also measured during the TRT. Fig. 8 shows the pile temperatures and ambient station temperatures during TRT1 and TRT2 measured by the temperature sensors embedded in the strainmeter bars (Fig. 1). First, it is observed that the ambient station temperatures fluctuate during both testing periods. There is a noticeably increase in the ambient temperature in the 15th and 16th days in TRT1 and 2nd and 3rd days in TRT2. The measured temperatures of the piles are more stable than the ambient station temperature since the beginning of the tests due to the facts that the ground and concrete can hold heat better than air does (higher heat capacity coefficients), and the thin layer of the shotcrete wall and concrete pile cover may also provide additional thermal buffer to the ground. Looking at the temperature sensors placed closer to the station side (S-sensors) of the piles, all of them have shown more fluctuating records than the ground side (G-sensors) of the piles. This is not surprising, since S-sensors were placed close to the station shaft air, thus heavily affected by the airflow and temperature conditions in the station. On the contrary, the G-sensors placed approximately one meter away from the wall surface but close to the ground loop placements. Thus, the temperatures are minimally affected by the station conditions but instead are largely affected by the heating tests, showing similar increasing thermal response trends to the fluid temperatures in Fig. 7. In TRT1, the pile temperature measurements (both G-sensors and S-sensors) captured the temperature build-up after two weeks in both activated piles (P50 and P51), which correlates with the fluid temperature build-up observed in Fig. 7. It should be noted that the temperatures in the excavated station have also increased in this period, thus the build-up temperature at later stages of the test may result from the thermal interference or the change in the testing conditions or the combined effect of both factors. In TRT2, the sensor in the thermally inactivated pile (P50) has recorded a very gradual temperature rise after two days of the test commencement, indicating a lack of thermal interference and an appropriate pile spacing to avoid it. Regardless which side of the wall is being considered, it is observed that there is little temperature variation with respect to different depths of the wall. The small temperature variation in P50-G-9.0 and P50-G-19.7 may be due to the variable pipe separation along the length of the pile
68
 or sensor calibration difference.
In summary, field observations suggest that activating every adjacent pile in the present soldier pile wall may introduce some thermal interference, which can impact energy efficiency over long-term operation. The monitoring results also highlight the importance of thermal condition of the excavation space on the heat transfer process of the energy wall, which suggests that the boundary condition of the wall should be carefully considered in the thermal analysis and system design. Despite the insightful observations from the thermal response of the real soldier pile wall since, the collected data is still limited and fails to capture the complete response of the wall. Moreover, these tests are considered short-term compared to typical geothermal system operational time (e.g., 25 to 50 years). The results of numerical simulations are presented in Section 3.2 to further evaluate the thermal significance of pile spacing on energy piled walls under long-term operation.

3.2.1

The final calibrated ground thermal conductivity is close to the upper range of the reported values in 59 for saturated Melbourne siltstone and sandstone. The final calibrated concrete thermal conductivity also falls in the thermal conductivity range of reinforced concrete reported in Ref. 69. The temperature build-up after the second week of TRT1 commencement is also successfully captured in the simulation. The simulated pile temperatures have also demonstrated very good agreement with the experimental results in both TRT1 and TRT2 as illustrated in Fig. 9(c) and (d) yet some disagreement can be noticed. The simulations are further explored to understand the thermal response of the energy wall during the TRTs. In Fig. 10 it is observed that there is a strong thermal interference between the thermo-active soldier piles at the end of TRT1 commencement and is more pronounced for the excavated part. Meanwhile in TRT2, the thermoactivated piles are placed far enough apart to mitigate thermal interaction between the heating piles. These observations further support the conclusion drawn from the measured experimental data in Section 3.1. Furthermore, it is observed that the heat above the excavation level is concentrated in the ground side while when looking below the excavation level, the ground on both sides is activated, which highlights the thermal difference between energy retaining walls and the traditional borehole systems/energy piles. 3.2.2
The long-term effect of pile spacing
The next analysis of this work investigates the thermal performance of an energy soldier pile wall at a pile spacing of 1.8 m, 3.6 m and 5.4 m over 25-years operating period, while adopting the standard thermal load shown in Fig. 6. The results are presented in Fig. 11, where the right figure summarises the maximum and minimum mean fluid temperatures during the operational period shown on the left, with respect to the operational limits of the system and the undisturbed ground temperature. It can be seen that the larger the thermo-active pile spacing, the lesser the extreme temperature responses resulting a narrower range of mean fluid temperatures, and consequently the better the performance of the energy piled wall. The significance of thermo-active pile spacing is particularly evident for the change from 1.8 m (thermally activate all piles) to 3.6 m (thermally activate every second piles). In addition, it is noted that the variation between years is very minor for all three cases, suggesting minimal heat accumulation in the ground and highlighting the contribution of balanced thermal loads.

3.2.4
Design application
As discussed and shown, larger pile spacing results in a better performance in the energy piled wall. The downside of increased pile spacing, and hence fewer thermally activated piles is the reduction in the overall amount of piles that can be activated (since the total number of piles is finite) and therefore the thermal potential or yield of the system. The maximum energy potential of each design case is taken as the modified design thermal load which results in a

The maximum energy potential was computed by employing the linear relationship between computed fluid temperature and the thermal load found in this study (a simple predictive method consistent with published literature

The relative energy potential for thermally activating every other pile and every other second pile, where the number of thermal piles is reduced to 1/2 and 1/3 of the total piles respectively, are compared to thermally activating all piles in the piled retaining walls system, and the results are summarised in Fig. 14.
Among the studied parameters,

On the other hand, varying

This study found that thermally activating all piles provides the maximum energy potential from the energy wall systems. Thermally activating 1/2 of the piles can provide more than 70% of the maximum energy potential for all studied cases and thermally activating 1/3 of the piles can provide more than 50% of the maximum energy potential in the majority of cases analysed due to the lower inter-pile thermal interference. In terms of the energy provided per pile, this value increases to between 140%–156% and between 147%–180% when activating 1/2 and 1/3 of the piles respectively. Like many other engineering projects, GHE design decisions are largely influenced by capital costs. Thermally activating less number of piles reduces the associated material and labour costs in equipping a pile with necessary piping, the cost saving may be however modest.

,

71
 The fact that activating every pile in the wall system provides the highest total energy potential accomplish this design option to be most favourable.







4
Summary and conclusion
The effects of pile spacing on the thermal performance of GSHP systems have been thoroughly studied through both experimental investigations and numerical simulations. A soldier piled retaining wall system within a deep excavated metro station in Melbourne, Australia was used as a case study. A segment of the wall has been thermally activated by incorporating absorber pipes in three adjacent soldier piles. Temperature sensors were also incorporated in these piles to further provide data during the experiments. Two in-situ thermal response tests have been conducted on this experimental site, aiming to investigate the effect of pile spacing on real energy piled walls. The collected testing and monitoring data provide important insights regarding the thermal response of energy piled walls and established important databases for the validation of analytical and numerical models. To gain a comprehensive understanding on the effect of pile spacing on the thermal performance of energy piled walls under long-term operation, finite element modelling was utilised. This effect has been further explored under different geotechnical designs (represented herein by retaining wall depths), ground conditions (represented herein by the ground thermal conductivities) and thermal designs (design thermal loads). Considering the real-world application of energy piled wall design, the effect of pile spacing on the energy potential of the system is studied to assist the design and decision making, such as on the number of wall piles that should be thermal activated. The key findings of this work are highlighted below:



(1)
The experimental results demonstrate that the thermal interference between closely spaced piles can occur in a relative short time (2 weeks in this case), resulting in a temperature build-up in the circulating fluid. This could disadvantage the thermal performance of the energy wall system.


(2)
A 3D finite element model has been validated against the experimental results which proves its representativeness and validity in simulating the thermal behaviour of the energy piled wall system.


(3)
The simulation results from the validated model show that separating thermo-active piles at a greater distance diminishes the effect of thermal interference between the piles, benefitting system performance to a certain extent. The degree of the performance improvement decreases with spacing as the thermal interference between the piles becomes less influential in controlling the fluid temperature. This conclusion remains true in all the studied design scenarios presented in the parametric analyses.


(4)
The parametric analyses suggest that the depth of the wall is the most influential factor on the thermal performance of the energy wall system as it controls the amount of ground volume that the GHEs engage. For shallower walls, the effect of pile spacing becomes more pronounced. On the other hand, the thermal conductivity of the ground shows a lesser impact on the thermal performance of the wall. Moreover, it was found that the circulating fluid temperatures responded linearly with the change in design thermal load. This finding is particularly valuable in determining the maximum energy potential of the system by controlling the desired fluid temperature.


(5)
This study recognises that actual design pile spacing is unlikely to be affected by the geothermal design but understanding the effect of pile spacing can help in justifying how many of the piles may be thermally activated. Compared to activating all piles (which naturally has the highest thermal energy provision potential), activating every other pile (one-half of the piles) to double the thermo-active pile spacing provides 70%–80% of the maximum energy potential, while activating ever other second pile (one third of the piles) to triple the effective pile spacing, delivers 50% to 60% of the maximum energy potential. Overall, it is suggested that activating all piles in the wall systems is the most desirable option considering the modest capital cost savings of activating less number of piles.

2.4
Data acquisition and processing
Throughout each experiment, external Instron load, internal load, Instron LVDT position, Sangamo LVDT position, sample temperature and cumulative acoustic emission count were logged at an interval of one second. Applied axial stress and effective axial stress were calculated from the external Instron load and internal load data, using pore fluid pressure data where relevant. Friction between the top piston seal and vessel wall was considered negligible for all experiments (< 0.8 MPa – see above). However, comparison of external and internal load cell data indicated measurable sample-vessel wall friction. The difference between the external and internal stress was smallest in the experiments conducted with pressurised pore fluids, e.g. at 100 MPa effective stress, the stress measured by the internal load cell varying between 99.4 and 102.4 MPa. For experiments conducted at low-vacuum (dry) conditions or with aqueous solutions at atmospheric pressures, the internal axial stress measured between 94.5 and 98.4 MPa at 100 MPa applied stress. Taking the sample stress as the average of the internally and externally measured stress yields an average (effective) sample stress of 101.0 ± 0.9 MPa for samples employing pressurised pore fluids, and 98.4 ± 1.0 MPa for dry and vacuum-saturated samples. On this basis, sample-vessel wall friction is assumed to be < 2.6% of the applied effective stress in all cases.

3.1
Control experiments on unconstrained vs. constrained samples
The results of our control experiments performed on aluminium and sandstone samples to investigate if the FEP-sleeve approach would effectively constrain tight-fitting samples to (near) zero radial strain are shown in Fig. 2. In both the constrained and unconstrained experiments using aluminium dummies, the samples were loaded and unloaded in six cycles up to a maximum applied axial stress of 55 MPa under lab dry conditions at 80 °C. Both samples showed a highly compliant, non-linear stress–strain response (Fig. 2a) up to 
∼
10 MPa, followed by rapid stiffening in the range 10–20 MPa. This likely reflects stiffening of the machine related to increased alignment at higher stresses. Above 30 MPa (dashed horizontal line in Fig. 2a), the stress–strain response approached linear behaviour, which enabled us to determine the characteristic stiffness of the dummy samples for each stress-cycle in the range 30–55 MPa. This varied over the six stress-cycles applied (Fig. 2b), with the unconstrained and constrained aluminium sample showing a stiffness of approximately 70 GPa and 144 GPa, respectively.
The results obtained in the unconstrained and constrained control tests performed using Bentheim sandstone at low-vacuum (dry) conditions and 80 °C are shown in Fig. 2c and d. Only one loading cycle was applied in these runs. For reference, the loading data of experiment dry02 is added to these figures, because it had the same starting porosity and was conducted under the same conditions. Overall, the stress–strain behaviour of the sandstone samples showed similar characteristics to the aluminium dummy at axial stresses up to 
∼
60 MPa, with the exception that the stiffness was much lower. Between 30 and 60 MPa (dashed horizontal lines in Fig. 2c), the stress–strain response of the unconstrained and constrained samples approached linear behaviour, such that the characteristic stiffness of the sandstone samples could be determined in the range 30–60 MPa. The characteristic stiffness of the unconstrained sandstone samples was 7.0 ± 0.0 GPa, while the constrained samples had higher stiffness values of 10.1 ± 0.0 GPa (loadunload) and 7.9 ± 0.1 GPa (dry02, see Table 1). As can be seen, the unconstrained sample (grey line in Fig. 2c) failed at approximately 62 MPa applied stress, indicated by the rapid increase in strain and deviation from linearity of the stress–strain curve. This was accompanied by a surge in AE activity (Fig. 2d). The FEP-constrained sandstone sample did not show this type of behaviour, as evidenced by the much lower AE count (16,000 AE counts versus 65,000 AE counts when unconstrained).

The influence of porosity is also reflected in the strain rate data, as evidence by lower and higher strain rates for 3HCl01 and AMP01, respectively, compared to the samples in the porosity range 22.2–22.4% (Fig. 7c).
Unfortunately, a problem with the AE sensor was noted after the experiments with acidic aqueous solutions were conducted, suggesting that the AE counts may have been impeded due to insufficient contact of the piezoelectric resonator with the vessel. This may explain why the cumulative AE counts recorded in the experiments conducted with acidic aqueous solutions were lower than expected based on the creep strain data and compared with the number of AEs recorded in the dry and wet reference experiments (Fig. 7b – note that for these experiments the curves are lighter shaded). However, the AE data qualitatively matched the trends observed in the strain data, i.e. the highest number of AEs were seen in the higher porosity AMP solution-flooded sample, intermediate values were obtained for the lower porosity AMP solution experiment and AlCl 3-saturated sample, and the lowest number of AE’s was obtained in the pH 3.7 HCl solution experiment. In summary, the mechanical and AE data show the same trends, in that flooding of the Bentheim sandstone with acidic aqueous solution (HCl, AMP, AlCl 3 solution) inhibited compaction creep and creep strain rates (Fig. 7), compared to distilled water.

A single undeformed Bentheim sandstone sample was analysed using optical microscopy. Manual counting of the grains confirmed that 95% of the grains consisted of quartz. The remaining grains consisted of corroded feldspar (

Furthermore, the quartz grains contained fluid inclusions and occasionally pre-existing cracks, presumably resulting from its burial and diagenetic history (Fig. 8a). No bedding, laminations or grain sorting were visible.
One sample was loaded to 100 MPa and then directly unloaded (loadunload – see Table 1). Throughout this sample, more cracks were observed than in the undeformed sample (cf. Fig. 8a and b), however, cracks were not as abundant as seen in the samples that were also allowed to creep at constant stress (see Fig. 8c–g). Most cracks emanated from grain-to-grain contacts, both within grains (intergranular cracks, Fig. 8a–f), across grains (transgranular cracks, Fig. 8d–g), and along grain boundaries producing grain boundary breakage (Fig. 8c and f). Generally, cracks were oriented parallel or subparallel to the loading direction and not specifically related to the grain composition (quartz vs. feldspar). Though cracks were observed throughout the entire cross section of each sample, clusters of more severely damaged grains were also observed in samples AlCl301, AMP02, DI01, DI02 and wN201. These damage zones were a few grains wide and typically contained a large portion of crushed grains, in addition to cracked grains (Fig. 8e and f). These clusters of crushed grains formed circular patches and did not extend laterally to form bands.

4.1.1
The influence of applied stress and porosity on compaction creep
As shown in Fig. 4, creep strain, AE count, creep rates and AE rates strongly increase with increasing applied stress. At higher applied stresses, the stresses acting across grain-to-grain contacts are larger, in turn enhancing the stresses acting at crack tips, thereby promoting (subcritical) crack growth and compaction creep.
Our results also suggested that sample porosity exerted some influence on compaction creep behaviour. In samples saturated with dry supercritical CO2, the sample with 0.7% higher porosity (21.8 vs. 22.5% porosity) showed creep strain rates and AE rates approximately half an order of magnitude faster than the lower porosity sample (Fig. 6c and d). Similarly, in samples with AMP solution as pore fluid, the sample with a higher porosity by 0.9% (22.4 vs. 23.3% porosity) creep strain rates were approximately one order of magnitude faster in the higher porosity sample (Fig. 7c). Most likely small differences in contact area or contact structure/cementation can explain the effect of porosity on creep rates, as these would lead to differences in stress intensity at crack tips, as well as the stress distribution around the crack tip, hence affecting crack propagation. However, we did not systematically investigate the effect of porosity on creep behaviour, so cannot infer more at present.

4.3
Implications
The results presented in this study may have several implications regarding fluid injection into porous subsurface reservoirs at 2–4 km depth, where microcracking is likely to contribute to reservoir deformation, specifically when stress conditions are perturbed to provide a drive for compaction creep. We envisage that the life-time of a grain is controlled by the rate at which cracks grow, so that injection of supercritical or acidic fluids increases the time-to-failure of the material and therefore slows creep.
Firstly, our results suggest that fluid injection into depleted, quartz-rich hydrocarbon reservoirs where the vertical effective stress has been increased by production, may be a suitable mitigation strategy for reducing long-term reservoir compaction. Injection of pressurised fluids will lower the effective stress acting on the reservoir rock, thereby reducing the driving force for reservoir compaction. In addition to this mechanical effect, a chemical effect is expected as well. For example, injection of supercritical phases that are devoid of water or contain trace water will tend to desiccate crack tips when the original water content is low, thereby reducing reservoir compaction creep rates by subcritical crack growth. In addition, injection of acidic fluids is likely to decelerate compaction creep rates, as the concomitant change in quartz surface energy will reduce subcritical crack growth rates. However, more research is needed to investigate the effect of (acidic) fluids on the compaction of impure sandstones having a larger feldspar, carbonate and clay content. Depending on the load-bearing framework, dissolution of carbonate cements on the short-term and feldspar grains on the long-term, by acidification of the pore fluid, may weaken the reservoir rock.
123

,

135

,

136


Secondly, porous subsurface reservoirs, such as depleted hydrocarbon reservoirs, are envisioned as potential systems for permanently storing CO2 and for temporary storage of renewably derived energy in the form of synthetic fuels, compressed air and hydrogen.
11
 In the corresponding injection operations, it is important to avoid or minimise long-term reservoir compaction and creep effects, as these may cause induced seismicity and surface subsidence.
3

,

4

,

137
 For efficiency reasons, most fuels injected will be devoid of water or contain trace amounts of water. Our experiments employing dry and wet supercritical phases may be regarded as representative of these injection scenarios and would suggest that, in case of injection into quartz-rich reservoirs, reservoir compaction would be not be enhanced, or perhaps even inhibited, by the injection of fluids and concomitant further (local) drying of the reservoir. Furthermore, the injection of CO2 has the added advantage of contributing to reducing anthropogenic CO2 emissions.
138


Thirdly, geothermal energy production for renewable heat and electricity production also requires the injection of cold fluids that are in chemical disequilibrium with the receiving reservoir rock. These fluids would typically contain anti-scaling additives, such as AMP, or be acidic in nature,
139

,

140
 enhancing any disequilibrium effects. During geothermal energy production, the injected and produced fluid volumes are balanced to maintain an approximately constant pore pressure in the reservoir. However, as the injected fluid will be relatively cold, the reservoir rock will be cooled, resulting in contraction of the reservoir rock and a decrease in the lateral stresses. Consequently, the differential stress acting on the reservoir rock will increase, which could provide a driving force for stress corrosion cracking. In addition, the tendency for stress corrosion cracking may be triggered by the change in chemical environment. Our experiments employing acidic solutions, including AMP, suggest that the rate of stress corrosion cracking would decrease, thereby inhibiting compaction creep, compared to injection with pure water. However, as described above, our research focused on the compaction behaviour of relatively clean sandstone, i.e. 95% quartz, and more research is needed to assess the effect of (acidic) fluids on sandstones with a higher feldspar, carbonate or clay content. Acidification of the pore fluid may lead to weakening in impure sandstones through reaction of feldspars and clays,
123

,

135

,

136
 which could affect transport properties and, thereby, impact the performance of the geothermal reservoir.
Lastly, concerning the injection of fluids for energy storage, we only looked at the scenario of a fixed applied, or overburden stress. However, in an energy storage project, most likely pore pressure will fluctuate during production, decreasing when energy is produced and increasing when energy is stored. This would mean that such energy storage systems will go through many stress-cycles throughout their lifetime. In our current study, we did not investigate the effect of stress-cycling on creep or hysteresis. However, our stiffness data collected during active pre-creep loading may be representative of injection during the first stress-cycle. Sample stiffness displayed a small dependency on water concentration and no effect of fluid pH was observed, while sample porosity did influence sample stiffness. This implies that during the first phases of fluid injection and extraction, the porosity of the reservoir rock rather than pore fluid chemistry is likely to control reservoir compaction. After the first stress-cycle, additional permanent deformation is unlikely to develop, as, depending on the rate of the stress-cycle, only a small number of new cracks will form as long as the effective stress does not exceed the maximum previously achieved stress. With prolonged injection and extraction-cycling, time-dependent chemical processes such as dissolution and subcritical crack growth are likely to have a stronger contribution to reservoir compaction and pore fluid chemistry will have a more pronounced influence on compaction rates.



5
Conclusions
Uniaxial compaction experiments were performed using samples of Bentheim sandstone saturated with supercritical fluids and aqueous solutions of different pH and composition to investigate the effects of pore fluid chemistry on (near) 1-D compaction of reservoir sandstones, at realistic in situ reservoir conditions (80 °C, effective axial stresses of 35, 75 and 100 MPa). The tested pore fluid environments included supercritical 


N


2


, CO2, wet-


N


2


 and wet-CO2 at 10 MPa pore pressure, distilled water, pH 3.7 HCl solution, AMP-solution and AlCl 3-solution at atmospheric pressure, as well as, low-vacuum (dry) conditions. The following observations and inferences were made:



1.
During loading, the stiffness of Bentheim sandstone samples was independent of water content in the pore fluid and solution pH. On the other hand, sample porosity appeared to exert an influence, as more porous samples were more compliant.


2.
During the creep phase, compaction creep strain, AE count, creep strain rates and AE rates measured in low-vacuum (dry) and water-saturated (distilled water) samples increased with increasing applied stress. In addition, a clear effect of pore fluid chemistry was observed. Creep rate and AE rate increased moving from dry and wet supercritical 


N


2


 and CO2 phases, to low-vacuum (dry) conditions, to acidic aqueous solutions, to distilled water. Samples saturated with the same pore fluid but with different porosity had quantitatively different compaction behaviour. More porous samples produced more strain and AEs, which was accompanied by higher strain rates and AE rates.


3.
It was inferred that compaction creep in Bentheim sandstone was controlled by subcritical crack growth by stress corrosion cracking, which is rate-dependent on the intergranular stresses and pore fluid chemistry. In turn, the rate of subcritical crack growth controls the rate of grain failure and, hence, compaction creep. Increasing the applied stress leads to larger stress concentrations at crack tips. In addition, in the more porous samples, grain-to-grain contacts were likely smaller or possessed a different structure or lower degree of cementation, such that the intergranular stresses were larger, promoting crack growth. Whereas saturation with the supercritical 


N


2


 and CO2 phases was inferred to actively dry crack tips and inhibit crack growth, saturation with distilled water fully wetted the crack tips, reducing the energy required for Si-O bond breakage and facilitating subcritical crack growth. In the case of saturation of acidic fluids, pH-dependent fluid–rock interactions were inferred to lower the rate of stress corrosion cracking.


4.
Regarding fluid injection into quartz-rich, subsurface reservoirs characterised by ongoing reservoir compaction, the results imply that fluids devoid of water or with a minor amount of water, e.g. supercritical phases, may be injected to mitigate reservoir compaction. Injection of acidic fluids is also likely to inhibit reservoir compaction. However, this study focused on the compaction behaviour of relatively clean sandstone, i.e. 95% quartz, and more research is needed to assess the effect of fluids on sandstones with a higher feldspar, carbonate or clay content.
