3.2
Model description
At first, the common properties of both models are described and then the specific characteristics of each model are outlined separately.
The model represents a 2D vertical cross section through a reservoir section offset by a normal fault (Fig. 2). Although the model is generic, its dimensions and material properties resemble the basic characteristics of compartimentalized Rotliegend gas reservoirs in the North German Basin. The reservoir unit represents an aeolian sandstone with a thickness of 100 m. In the reference model the vertical offset of the reservoir across the fault is assumed to be half the reservoir thickness (50 m), but scenarios with offset equal to the reservoir thickness (100 m) and other amounts of partial overlap (75 and 25 m) as well as the case without offset (0 m) of the reservoir across the fault are also considered. The top of the reservoir in the hanging wall remains fixed at 4800 m depth, whereas the reservoir depth in the footwall is higher by the stated amounts. The fault offsetting the reservoir dips at 60°. The overburden is a sandstone shale succession, the underburden unit represents Rotliegend volcanics. The model ranges from the earth’s surface to 8 km depth and the horizontal extent of the model is 8 km as well in order to avoid stress perturbations and wave reflections from the model boundaries.
Rock parameters are given in Table 1 for both, the poroelastic model and the model used for simulation of dynamic rupture. The chosen values take log or core data from field operators into account but in view of the generic character of the model and since it consists of only three units the chosen values aim at representing typical values encountered in the Rotliegend sandstone reservoirs and the underlying volcanics.
40–44


The numerical problem is solved using the finite element software package Simulia Abaqus version 2016. The model geometry is discretized using 3.31 Mio. linear 2D plane strain quad elements. The element type used for the poroelastic model has an additional pore pressure degree of freedom (CPE4P), which is not the case in the model for dynamic rupture simulation (CPE4). Element size is about 1 m in the reservoir unit, becoming coarser towards the boundaries of the model with up to 12 m. In the vicinity of the fault elements have a constant width of 0.2 m.

3.2.1
Description of the poroelastic model
Initial pore pressure distribution in the model domain is hydrostatic above the reservoir, assuming a brine density of 1200 kg m−3. At the top of the reservoir on either side of the fault the initial pore pressure is 64.5 MPa, which implies a pressure step at the top of the reservoir. Below, initial pore pressure in the reservoir increases with depth at the hydrostatic gradient according to the density of gas which is assumed as 200 kg m−3. At the base of the reservoir pore pressure increases steadily again with the hydrostatic gradient of brine in the underlying Rotliegend volcanics.
The interface between the top of the reservoir and the overlying caprock as well as the base of the reservoir is assigned a pore pressure boundary condition to avoid pore pressure reduction in the reservoir due to fluid outflow from the reservoir into the over- and underburden. The same holds for the lateral edge of the reservoir where it borders the adjacent over- or underburden rock on the opposite side of the fault in order to prevent fluid flow into the sideburden. This implies that the fault separating the reservoir from the sideburden is assumed to be impermeable, which is an observation in many of the Rotliegend gas fields in Northern Germany.
Gravity acts as a body force. The nodes at the surface are not constrained, nodes at the bottom of the model are fixed for displacements in vertical direction to support the overlying rock mass but can move horizontally (Fig. 2). Nodes at the two vertical boundaries of the model are not constrained for vertical displacements and are assigned a horizontal displacement of 4 m towards the interior of the model to account for an appropriate ratio of horizontal to vertical stress (k ratio). To avoid strong contrasts of the stress field at the transitions between the lithologies the horizontal stresses are not only initialized through lateral shortening but also by a prestress which is incorporated from a model in which the Poisson’s ratio is homogeneous throughout all lithologies (

Before production starts, a balancing step is performed in order to establish equilibrium between initial porosity, initial pore pressure distribution, gravity, prestress and horizontal shortening of the model domain. Thereafter, production is modelled by pore pressure decrease assigned as boundary condition to the nodes located at 2000 m distance to the fault, which resembles a vertical well through the reservoir unit. Pore pressure decreases at a constant rate of 2 MPa per year and after the total model time of 22 years, it has been reduced by 44 MPa. Due to the relatively high rock permeability, pore pressure is reduced rather homogeneouslythroughout the reservoir and no distinct pressure cone develops near the ”well“. In the reference model production is from the reservoir in the hanging wall compartment only (Fig. 2) because typical gas fields under consideration often consist of one main compartment and some smaller neighbouring compartments which are not always under production or where production started later. However, additional scenarios also investigate production from the footwall block only and both compartments, respectively.
With ongoing pore pressure decrease stress is monitored after each time step (i.e. after every two years of production) along two lines parallel to and on either side of the fault at a distance of 0.2 m to the fault. The mesh at the fault is discontinuous i.e. nodes are split and undergo different pore pressures at either side of the fault during production due to the impermeable fault. As a consequence, effective normal stress builds up in a decoupled manner. The state of stress from the poroelastic model (Biot effective stress) is exported to the dynamic model at the time when a critical state of stress is reached. The dynamic model to which the effective stress is transferred thus considers and dissipates the decoupled production-induced effective stresses on either side of the contact fault that arise from its sealing properties.

4
Results of the poroelastic models

4.1
Reference model
The temporal evolution of the stress state in the vicinity of the fault resulting from the pore pressure decrease in the reservoir is shown for the reference model in Fig. 3a in terms of the SSR parameter. Thereby, positive SSR values indicate a sense of shear which ultimately results in normal faulting whereas negative SSR values have the opposite sense of shear leading to reverse faulting. For the reference model, SSR values are slightly positive (0.2) above the reservoir and remain so during the entire production history. In the depth interval of the reservoir in the footwall block, SSR values increase and reach a maximum value in the middle of the reservoir, at the depth of the top of the reservoir in the adjacent hanging wall block. In the depth interval of the producing reservoir section, i.e., between 4800 and 4900 m depth, SSR values decrease with depth and reach negative values at its base, where also the maximum negative SSR value is reached. Below the reservoir SSR values increase again towards zero.
During production, initially positive SSR values increase and initially negative SSR values further decrease. Critical SSR values defined as values equal to or above 0.6 and equal to or below −0.6 are reached in the course of production in the lower half of the reservoir in the footwall block, whereas in the hanging wall block critical positive SSR values are not reached during the production period. A sharp spike of negative SSR values develops on both sides of the fault at the depth of the base of the reservoir in the hanging wall block. The SSR values on both sides of the fault differ slightly because of the different pore pressures across the impermeable fault. As a consequence, critical SSR values are reached for different amounts of pore pressure decrease i.e. different production periods on either side of the fault, if at all. The changes of the SSR parameter during production are greater in the opposite footwall block than in the hanging wall which is under production.

Fig. 3b and c show how the SSR value can be understood in terms of its constituents, shear stress and effective normal stress on the fault. Shear stress is basically the same on the hanging wall and footwall side of the fault, except very locally at lithological interfaces. With production absolute shear stress increases over the reservoir interval. Above and below the reservoir the change in shear stress becomes smaller. The effective normal stress before production however is the same on both sides of the fault only in the overlapping section of the reservoir (4800–4850 m) as well as above and below the reservoir. Normal stress is different on either side of the fault in the depth intervals where the reservoir is juxtaposed against the over- and underburden, respectively (4750–4800 m and 4850–4900 m). Production then increases effective normal stress on the hanging wall side of the fault over the entire reservoir interval (4750–4900 m) with changes being largest in the section where the two reservoirs overlap (4800–4850 m). On the footwall side of the fault normal stress increases only in the upper half of the reservoir in the footwall (4750–4800 m) and decreases over the depth interval of the reservoir in the hanging wall (4800–4900 m).

Regarding the production time and the pore pressure drop in the reservoir at which the stresses from the poroelastic model are transferred to the dynamic model the following approach was pursued. Given the different production periods after which SSR values of >0.6 are reached on each side of the fault and in view of the issue of whether this value should be reached on just one or on both sides of the fault (e.g. Fig. 3), the effective stress from the poroelastic model was transferred to the dynamic model after each pore pressure drop (every two years or every 2 MPa of pore pressure decrease, respectively) to examine at which production time the rupture actually initiates. Not in every case the rupture initiates at the time at which the SSR parameter exceeds the value of 0.6 for the first time and more depletion is required until the rupture occurs, depending on local stress conditions and friction. In the reference model SSR 
=

However, the fault section experiencing this critical value is too small for the rupture to commence. After 18 years of production the fault section with SSR>0.6 has become large enough for the rupture to nucleate. In case of the reference model a critical fault section of 
∼

Regarding the initiation of the rupture in the dynamic model, there is a small amount of overstress on the fault which arises from the discrete pore pressure steps during depletion in the poroelastic model. This overstress fulfils the conditions for the onset of slip on the contact surface. Transfer of stress from the poroelastic to the dynamic model after subsequent steps of pressure decrease shows that this overstress has negligible effect on the size of resulting ruptures.

5.1
Reference model and production configurations
The temporal evolution of coseismic displacement on the fault is shown in Fig. 7 for the reference model with production from the hanging wall only (Fig. 7a) and for production from both compartments (Fig. 7b). For production from the footwall block only no rupture occurs after 22 years of production. Numerical simulation results are presented in terms of the fault-parallel displacement on the fault for various time increments after the rupture initiated.
Both cases presented in Fig. 7 show common characteristics. The rupture initiates at the top of the reservoir in the hanging wall block. The rupture propagates faster and more far to the downside than upward. The rupture arrests earlier at the lower end of the rupture than at its upper termination. The maximum displacement is reached 20–30 m below the hypocentre, which is in the middle of the section at which the two reservoirs are in contact. The upper termination of the rupture is near the top of the reservoir in the footwall block but not extending above it. The lower termination is 20–30 m above the base of the reservoir in the hanging wall, thus below the reservoir in the footwall block.
While in both cases SSR

6
Discussion

6.1
Discussion of results
The pore pressure depletion during production leads to an increase in effective vertical stress which in turn leads to reservoir compaction. As a consequence shear stress on the fault increases, also above the producing reservoir section (Fig. 3b). Changes in shear stress are positive (i.e. towards normal faulting) above the producing reservoir due to subsidence and negative (i.e. towards reverse faulting) below the producing reservoir because there is a slight uplift of the basement due to the vertical shrinkage of the reservoir (Fig. 3b). Effective normal stress increases in the producing reservoir interval on the hanging wall side of the fault, whereas it decreases on the footwall side. This is associated with horizontal shrinkage of the producing reservoir which lowers horizontal stresses in the adjacent footwall block
8

,

10
 (Fig. 3c). Since the shear stress is basically the same on both sides of the fault, the difference in the SSR values between hanging wall and footwall comes from the differing pore pressures and effective normal stresses on either side of the fault (Fig. 3). In the overlapping depth interval SSR values hardly change with production on the hanging wall side because the increase in shear stress and the increase in normal stress nearly cancel out each other. On the footwall side however, shear stress increase is accompanied by reduction in effective normal stress, which leads to a significant increase of the SSR value (Fig. 3). This explains why temporal changes of the SSR parameter are larger in the sideburden not under production than in the producing reservoir section (Figs. 3 and 4).
A common characteristic of the modelled dynamic ruptures is that coseismic displacements are primarily in a normal faulting sense as expected for production-induced earthquakes,
4
 and which is in agreement with observations from North German gas fields e.g. Refs. 16, 21. Deformation associated with pore pressure decrease, particularly shear stress increase because of reservoir compaction and reduction of effective normal stress on the adjacent side of the producing reservoir facilitates fault reactivation.
A further characteristic of all model variants is that the rupture extends over the depth interval in which the two reservoirs are juxtaposed (Figs. 7, 9, 11, 12). In some cases, the rupture extends towards the top of the reservoir in the footwall but it never reaches the lowermost section of the reservoir in the hanging wall block, except for the case with very low 


k


0


 ratio (Fig. 12a). The hypocentre, i.e., the depth at which the rupture nucleates, corresponds to the depth of a positive peak in the SSR value (Figs. 3–6). If above and below that depth the SSR value decreases with a strong gradient so does the coseismic displacement. The rupture extends into adjacent sections of the fault which are conditionally stable, i.e., where SSR values are lower than the static coefficient of friction. The termination of the rupture corresponds to the depth where the SSR value decreases below the value of the dynamic coefficient of friction, apart from local overshooting. Although SSR values in the overburden are only little below the dynamic coefficient of friction, the peak of small or negative SSR values at the top of the reservoir in the footwall block prevent ruptures from extending to shallower depths (Figs. 3–7, 9, 11). For the same reason the negative peak in the SSR at the base of the reservoir in the hanging wall block which also extends into the lowermost section of the reservoir prevents ruptures from propagating further down-dip into the underburden. Both factors are favourable with respect to seismic hazard but it cannot be excluded that other model configurations exist where ruptures may reactivate deeper fault sections in the crust e.g. with a less stiff underburden and lower k ratios in the underburden. Up-dip extension beyond the top of the reservoir was found for low 


k


0


 ratios (Fig. 12a,b).
The configuration of production affects the temporal changes of the SSR parameter in the over- and underburden in different ways and this is where operational measures come into play. For production from the hanging wall only the SSR value increases in the overburden and decreases in the underburden (Fig. 3), which holds for all offsets considered (Fig. 5). For production from the footwall block only it is vice versa (Fig. 4b) and for production from both blocks the SSR value decreases both in the over- and underburden (Fig. 4a). The changes of the SSR value in the over- and underburden are rather small but nevertheless they may matter depending on the prestress conditions. Regarding potential extension of ruptures to the upside the creep behaviour of evaporates which are occasionally present in the overburden could reduce shear stress during production and thereby represent an additional safety factor.

The case with offset equal to the reservoir thickness shows the earliest reactivation but smallest rupture length, whereas ruptures are postponed for smaller offsets but reach larger rupture lengths (Fig. 9). In contrast to rupture size, the relation between timing of rupture initiation and fault throw is coherent among different modelling studies. The amount of depletion necessary for fault reactivation is smallest for fault throws in the order of the reservoir thickness and becomes larger with decreasing fault throw,

Stress drop for 75 m offset is similar as for 50 m offset and about three times as large as for 25 and 100 m offset (Table 2). It is known that the high-frequency ground motion (e.g., peak ground acceleration or peak ground velocity) is controlled by the stress drop of an earthquake, thus, besides the higher magnitude for these cases, the higher stress drop will produce more intense ground motions.

,

55
 In this respect the choice of 50 m offset for the reference model represents the most critical case with regard to seismic hazard among the considered cases.
From an operational point of view, it has been argued that production from both compartments separated by an intra-field fault is disadvantageous with respect to seismic hazard in comparison to production from one block only.
7
 The results presented in Fig. 7 support this view as the rupture with production from both compartments initiates earlier compared to if production is only from the hanging wall block and in spite of this produced a larger rupture length, displacement, magnitude and stress drop (Table 2). However, this may not be a general rule and can depend on the specific material parameters, initial conditions and geometry as Zbinden et al. 
9
 found a smaller seismic moment of an induced earthquake in this case even though shear stress on the intra-field fault is higher if both of the adjacent reservoir compartments are depleted. Disregarding the numerous factors affecting fault reactivation, the latter essentially depends on an interplay of effective normal stress and shear stress. On the one hand effective normal stress on the fault reduces more rapidly if production is from both compartments adjacent to the fault due to lateral shrinkage of the adjacent reservoir sections, which reduces fault stability. On the other hand, shear stress increases slower if at all since differential compaction is smaller compared to if production is from only one compartment, provided that there is sufficient overlap of the reservoir at the fault.
An important point in this issue is the assumed pore pressure in the fault. In this study, pore pressure undergoes a step across the fault if production is only from one compartment as the fault is assumed to be impermeable and thus effective normal stress is different on both sides of the fault as production proceeds. If a continuous transition in pore pressure was assumed across the fault effective normal stress on the fault would represent an average value of the pore pressure in the two compartments. Regarding fault reactivation our approach is considered a conservative one as rupture initiation depends primarily on the SSR value on that side of the fault that reaches critical values first, as a comparison of Figs. 3–6 with the timing of rupture initiation for the respective models shows.

However, due to a lack of data the actual initial stress state in both the over- and underburden is not known. The anti-correlation of smaller earthquakes and longer production obtained for higher horizontal prestress indicates that a significant amount of released seismic energy comes from the tectonic prestress besides the stress build-up from the production.


6.2
Implications for additional earthquakes after an induced earthquake
In the following, we interpret our findings as to whether, in the case of continued production after an induced event, subsequent earthquakes besides aftershocks may occur in a gas field. We approach this issue from three different perspectives.
First, the tectonic component in stress drop and plastic mechanisms during reservoir compaction. Ongoing production after an earthquake leads to further compaction of the reservoir and as a result shear stress resumes to accrue on the fault. While we do observe in our results that the SSR parameter increases with ongoing production (Fig. 3) we also find, that seismic moment does not increase in a systematic way if an earthquake occurs after a longer period of production compared to if it occurs earlier, i.e. after less pore pressure draw down (Figs. 7, 9, 11, 12). Other factors such as geometry, the configuration of productions wells, frictional properties and pre-production stress dominate in this respect. This indicates that a significant portion of the shear stresses released during the earthquake does not necessarily derive from production-related compaction but has been stored in the host rock from tectonic movements in the geological past. Fig. 8a shows that coseismic stress drop in a wide portion of the rupture width is larger than the shear stress increase during production. Although this tectonic component of stress drop likely becomes smaller if the prestress were chosen more uniform, this finding is supported by the observation that particularly in the deeper subsurface of the North German Basin there is a tendency for normal faulting tectonics.
45
 This indicates that the induced earthquakes relief in part tectonically induced strain energy, but the trigger to release those stresses is the pore pressure reduction due to production. If this is the case, there is no real argument against prolonged production after an induced event in which tectonic stresses have been reduced. The portion of tectonic stresses of total stresses released during a potential future earthquake is then likely smaller than in the previous event. This is particularly expectable in areas of very low tectonic deformation rates such as the North German Basin. However, in seismically active producing gas fields it has been observed that once compaction exceeds a certain critical level, seismicity increases significantly irrespective of operational measures to reduce seismicity such as production rate cuts, total production volume cuts and field shutdown.
29
 Pore pressure reduction and associated increase of effective stress leads to porosity decrease which accelerates, once confining stress exceeds the stress during consolidation of the sediment.

The permeability decrease associated with the porosity decrease requires an increasing pore pressure gradient to achieve economic flow rates which can additionally weaken the rock.

(1) The German gas fields are at much greater depths than the Dutch fields which implies higher normal stress on the faults which in turn hampers fault reactivation although this is compensated to some extent by larger shear stress, which generally increases also with depth. However, ground motions at the surface should be smaller if the hypocentre is at larger depth due to attenuation and geometric spreading of the wave field. Accordingly, ground motion recordings from earthquakes in Northern Germany tend to be lower than those predicted by empirical ground motion equations based on data from the Groningen field for comparable earthquake magnitudes and epicentral distance.

(3) In contrast to the Dutch gas fields, German gas fields have in many cases not many neighbouring compartments under production which can postpone fault reactivation and reduce rupture size (Fig. 7).


6.4
Discussion of model assumptions and limitations
In this section we summarize the main limitations of the model and what could be improved. The usage of two different models for production and rupture modelling puts some constraints on the precision on rupture initiation as time steps in the poroelastic model correspond to steps of 4 MPa pore pressure decrease. This ultimately leads to a certain amount of overstress at the beginning of the rupture. However, model runs of ruptures with consecutive steps of pore pressure decrease as initial stress showed only small changes of a few percent in the resulting coseismic displacement and do not change the presented basic findings. Time steps in the poroelastic model could be decreased but a better way would be the usage of one model in which implicit computation is automatically switched to explicit once the state of stress reaches a defined criterion.
34


More advanced modelling approaches could include specific fault-related aspects like potential plastic deformation nearby the fault due to local stress peaks evolving during the dynamic rupture,
71
 rock strengthening and weakening effects due to pore pressure decrease and increase in the dilated and compressed areas during rupture
72
 as well as pore pressure diffusion and poroelastic relaxation subsequent to the earthquake
73

,

74
 which were not the scope of this analysis. It has been shown that the fluid effect on dynamic rupture can be substantial as the style of coseismic rupture and the wavefield can be altered including higher rupture speed and stronger amplitudes of the waves compared to if the fluid effect on dynamic rupture is neglected.
75
 Analyses of dynamic rupture considering plastic off-fault yielding showed that coseismic slip rates become smaller, ground motions are less variable and slip is locally higher but concentrated on a smaller area compared to if rock is assumed as elastic.
76
 As a result, moment magnitudes are comparable with and without plasticity.
76
 Rupture transfer across geometrical barriers is hampered when off-fault plasticity is assumed.
In the model it is assumed that the fault is truly impermeable since pressure data from the gas fields under consideration indicate this. This implies that effective stresses on the reservoir side of the fault are determined by the pore pressure in the reservoir and on the adjacent side of the fault by the pore pressure encountered there, i.e. a step in both pore pressure and effective stress is present at the fault plane. In a more general analysis the fault would need to be assumed as a zone rather than a plane and be characterized by a permeability which would determine how the pore pressure changes through the fault zone depending on how fast the pressure decreases during production on the reservoir side of the fault. At a high fault permeability a gradual or even linear change of pore pressure would develop through the fault zone which would alter the effective stresses transferred to the dynamic model.



7
Conclusions
Modelling of dynamic rupture of depletion induced earthquakes in an intra-graben setting typical for North German gas fields yields several key characteristics. We find normal faulting rupture on the fault in the depth interval of the reservoir where there is partial overlap of the reservoir in the adjacent compartment. Displacement does not reach the lowermost 
∼
20 metres of the reservoir in the hanging wall except for low horizontal stresses prior to production and only occasionally reaches the top of the reservoir in the footwall or slightly above. The rupture propagates into fault sections not critically stressed prior to the onset of rupture. Rupture nucleates near the top of the reservoir in the hanging wall where the largest SSR values have accrued. The rupture propagates in most cases to the downside where also the maximum displacement occurs. Down-dip width of the rupture, magnitude, maximum displacement as well as stress drop are larger for a reservoir offset at the fault equal to half its thickness compared to if reservoir offset is smaller or larger. However, the fault is reactivated earlier if offset is large. Production from both compartments results in earlier and larger earthquakes than if only the compartment on one side of the fault is under production. Among the parameters investigated, frictional properties on the fault and pre-production stress have the strongest impact on coseismic displacements. Particularly the stress state prior to production reflecting the tectonic stress field plays a crucial role as it primarily controls how long production can occur or how much pore pressure decrease can be sustained until a critical state of stress is reached. The pre-production stress is not only characterized by its ratio of effective horizontal to vertical stress (


k


0


) that has a major influence on fault normal stress but also stiffness contrasts between lithologies affect the stress state which subsequently can be important for nucleation and/or arrest of a rupture. Thus, the earthquakes represent an interplay of tectonic stresses and depletion induced stress changes that both drive the earthquake but pore pressure draw down during production advances the time of earthquake occurrence, which is especially true for areas of low-deformation rates such as Northern Germany.

Introduction
Deep geological disposal concepts for radioactive waste are generally based on a multi-barrier system, which comprises the engineered barrier system (EBS) and host rock formation. The Swiss concept for disposal of spent fuel/vitrified high-level waste (e.g., as defined in Ref. 1) is based on horizontally emplacing cylindrical disposal canisters in the middle of an emplacement drift excavated in the Opalinus Clay. The canisters are placed on pedestals of highly compacted bentonite blocks. The remaining void space between the canisters and tunnel wall is filled with granulated bentonite mixture (GBM). The most important safety function of the bentonite is to protect the integrity of the canister for at least one thousand years.
2


Bentonite is a clay material consisting mostly of montmorillonite. Bentonite-based buffer materials of the EBS will saturate over time with groundwater from the host rock. This results in a swelling pressure, a decrease in hydraulic conductivity and an increase in thermal conductivity (e.g., Ref. 3). Aside from stabilizing the canisters, the bentonite buffer provides the safety functions of containment (e.g., by limiting advective transport and reducing microbial activity) and retardation (e.g., by filtering colloids and sorbing radionuclides), thereby fulfilling long-term safety requirements, which are specified, e.g., in the “Long-term Performance of Engineered Barrier Systems” (PEBS) project.
4


Bentonite blocks and GBM are engineered to fulfill key safety requirements (e.g., Ref. 5). Typical engineering parameters are water content, grain size and dry density (DD). Besides the long-term aspects of bentonite performance, the emplacement techniques also must be considered. During emplacement of the GBM, overall grain size distribution and water content can be controlled to retain the original production properties. Therefore, DD is the crucial parameter for GBM emplacement. In addition, DD after emplacement controls the thermal, hydraulic and mechanical properties of the bentonite (e.g., Refs. 6, 7). In the Swiss concept, screw feeders will be used to convey the GBM and fill the spaces around the canisters. The required DD of the GBM after emplacement is currently aimed to be a minimum of 1,450 kg/m3 (e.g., Refs. 8, 9).
The emplacement of GBM using screw feeders was tested and optimized in several mock-up experiments as well as in large-scale underground experiments in the Mont Terri rock laboratory in Switzerland.
9
 The mock-up experiments carried out within the framework of the EU project “Engineering Studies and Demonstration of Repository Designs” (ESDRED) showed that the overall GBM DD of >1,450 kg/m3 can be reliably achieved using screw feeders.
10


Moreover, the in-situ experiments in the Mont Terri rock laboratory, namely the Engineered Barrier (EB) experiment under isothermal conditions (e.g., Ref. 11) and the HE-E experiment on the behavior of the engineered barriers under the influence of heat (e.g., Ref. 12), showed that the average DDs of 1,360 kg/m3 (in a horseshoe-shaped tunnel section 2.9 m wide, 2.65 m high, 6 m long) and 1,457 kg/m3 (in a circular tunnel section 1.3 m in diameter and 4 m long), respectively, could be achieved using screw feeders under repository-like underground conditions. In both experiments, only the average DDs were determined by means of mass-balance methods. Any potential spatial variation in the initial DD was not measured due to the different aims of these experiments and the lack of measurement techniques that could reliably resolve heterogeneities in the GBM after emplacement.
Some attempts were made to capture variations in the DD. Sampling methods were employed in some mock-up tests of the EB experiment (e.g., Ref. 11) and the HE-E experiment (e.g., Ref. 12). The results revealed low DD spots, e.g., at locations where the GBM flow was obstructed or a significant segregation of the granulated material occurred. It should be noted that destructive sampling is not always possible and could only be performed in those mock-up tests where the emplaced GBM could be accessed. The gamma–gamma method and a penetrometer were also employed in the Full-scale Seal (FSS) experiment performed by Andra in France.
13
 These two methods captured qualitative changes in the DD, but it was concluded that further development was needed. Time domain reflectometry (TDR) was also tested in the FSS experiment to monitor the DD along the side and end walls of the full-scale mock-up concrete vault for intermediate-level waste (ILW), and changes in the DD due to segregation and local voids were detected. Observation windows used in the mock-up tests were helpful to visually confirm segregation 
12

,

13
 and local voids.
13


The lack of measurement techniques for investigating spatial variations in the GBM after emplacement was addressed in the recent Full-scale Emplacement (FE) experiment in the Mont Terri rock laboratory.
14
 The FE experiment consists of three full-sized dummy disposal canisters with electrical heating systems emplaced in a horizontal tunnel with an inside diameter of approximately 3 m and a length of 50 m. The primary aim of the FE experiment is to investigate the thermo-hydro-mechanical (THM) coupled effects on the host rock. Additional aims, from an engineering perspective, were to demonstrate the technical feasibility of constructing a disposal tunnel, to optimize the production of bentonite buffer material, and to validate the on-site bentonite buffer emplacement procedures (e.g., Refs. 8, 15). The FE experiment was densely instrumented with conventional sensors, prototype sensors and fiber-optic (FO) sensors. The FO sensors were used for various measurements in the FE tunnel such as the longitudinal spatial DD variations of the GBM at the time of emplacement as described later in this study, as well as spatial and temporal changes in the temperature, strain and water content (not discussed in this study).
To emplace the GBM in the FE tunnel as densely and homogeneously as possible, a prototype backfilling machine (BFM) consisting of five screw feeders was constructed. The required minimum DD of the bulk GBM as emplaced was 1,450 kg/m3. A 1:1-scale mock-up backfilling test was performed prior to the actual backfilling of the FE tunnel to investigate how the new prototype BFM would perform, to ensure that the required DD was achieved, and to optimize the backfilling procedure. The mock-up test was densely instrumented with dielectric sensors to capture variations in the DD of the GBM over the tunnel cross-section.
To ensure the performance of the bentonite buffer, the minimum target DD set as the key parameter (e.g., Ref. 16) was tracked by the bulk values averaged over the backfilled volume. This was, however, based on an ideal assumption that any heterogeneity in the buffer would eventually decrease and reach the average DD after a sufficiently long saturation period 
17
 and that the radiogenic heat from the canisters would decay. Regarding the DD variation in the buffer, information on saturation will generally be limited to the duration of the experiment and will become available only by dismantling the in-situ experiments. In the EB experiment, where a dummy canister was placed on highly compacted bentonite blocks (initial DD 
=

=

=

=

As noted above, however, very little information is available on the variation in the DD of GBM at the time of emplacement. To the authors’ best knowledge, this is largely due to the lack of measurement methods. The heterogeneity at the time of emplacement, which depends on the types of materials and emplacement methods used, would provide a better understanding of the temporal evolution. Some of the heterogeneity, induced either at the time of emplacement or through hydraulic and thermal regimes, could persist for a long time period.
20


In the present study, an attempt was made to quantify the DD distribution in the GBM at the time of emplacement by screw feeders in large-scale setups. The full-scale mock-up test in which cross-sectional variations were quantified is described first, followed by a description of the in-situ FE tunnel backfilling including the longitudinal variation of the DD.


2
Granulated bentonite mixture and backfilling machine
The GBM used for the mock-up and in-situ backfilling tests is referred to as Mixture 3.
8
 The raw sodium bentonite material mined in Wyoming, USA, was first compressed to pellets with a DD of 2,180 kg/m3. The pellets were crushed in an industrial blender, and fine particles were added to have a grain-size distribution known as the Fuller curve 
8

,

21
 with a maximum grain diameter of 6 mm (Fig. 1a, b). The initial water content was 5.5–6.0 wt% and was selected to achieve the highest DD possible. Preliminary tests have shown that the Fuller-like grain-size distribution and high pellet DD yielded a satisfactory GBM DD when emplaced (e.g., Refs. 10, 22). More details about the GBM can be found in Ref. 8.

For the mock-up and in-situ backfilling tests, the GBM was emplaced using the above-mentioned prototype BFM. The BFM consisted of five horizontal screw feeders (0.2-m diameter) and a feeding wagon as shown in Fig. 2. To achieve a homogeneous emplacement, the five screw feeders were distributed to uniformly cover the void space around the heaters and pedestals.
9
 The length of the screw feeders ranged from 6.6 m to 8.5 m 
23
 to fit the GBM slope with an angle of repose of about 35 degrees when emplaced in the test tunnels.
24
 The rotation speed and torque of the screws were computer-controlled to yield an optimum discharge of the GBM through the distribution box between the five screw feeders and the hopper on the feeding wagon.
To achieve the required DD, up to approximately 1 m of the tips of all screw feeders were driven into the GBM slope. The BFM was held in place by hydraulic brakes on steel rails to maintain high backpressure. The thrust from the screw feeders resulted in a compression of the GBM, leading to an increased emplacement DD. As a result, the repulsive force reached up to 32 kN. More details about the BFM can be found in Refs. 14, 23.





3
Mock-up backfilling test
Backfilling of the mock-up tunnel was performed twice; the first test was conducted in May 2014 with the main objective of checking the BFM’s technical functionality. In contrast, the second test focused on optimizing the procedure to achieve a high emplacement DD to ensure that the target DD would be achieved; it also focused on assessing the degree of heterogeneity, if any, in the GBM.
9

,

14
 This paper reports only on the second test.

3.1
Mock-up test setup
A full-scale mock-up tunnel with dimensions of 2.52 m (inner diameter) 
×
 8.0 m (length) as shown in Fig. 3 was used. The mock-up tunnel was located in a warehouse of the tunnel machinery company Belloli SA in Grono, Switzerland. The tunnel consisted of a bent sheet of metal with a thickness of 8 mm. Inside the mock-up tunnel, a cylinder (4.6 m in length, 1.05 m in diameter) simulating a disposal canister was placed on a pedestal, both of which were made of the same sheet metal.
25
 The back end of the tunnel was closed with a slope slanted at an angle of 46 degrees. Although this exceeds the GBM’s angle of repose of 35 degrees,
24
 this slope was installed so that backfilling was conducted as if in continuation from the previous slope. The front end was left open to provide access for the BFM.

The mock-up tunnel configuration allowed for the construction of several holes at the top and windows along the sides for visual observations. Another major advantage was that the instrumentation tools could be installed from outside the tunnel, i.e., through the tunnel wall. A set of dielectric tools described in the following section was installed radially through the sheet-metal wall to quantify cross-sectional variation in the DD.
Backfilling was performed from August 12 to 13, 2014. Using the BFM, GBM Mixture 3 was filled as continuously as possible, except when new bags of bentonite had to be loaded onto the feeding wagon.
23




3.2
Dielectric profile probe PR2 and dry density calibration
The DD of the emplaced GBM was measured using a commercially available soil moisture profile probe (Model PR2/6, Delta-T Devices, UK, Fig. 4), which was originally designed for various environmental and agricultural applications. The probe has six pairs of electrodes, each of which forms a dielectric sensor to measure water content at depths of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, 0.6 and 1.0 m. A 100 MHz signal is applied along each pair of stainless steel ring electrodes and the electrodes transmit the electromagnetic field extending up to about 0.1 m into the material of interest as indicated schematically based on a cylindrical sampling volume in Fig. 4, and the sensor outputs a DC voltage (in mV) which is a function of the water content.
26



As noted above, the GBM was produced to have a water content of 5.5–6.0 wt%. It was assumed that the water content would remain constant during the backfilling procedure because there was no water inflow into the mock-up tunnel, and the GBM was not exposed to extreme environmental conditions that would cause the moisture to evaporate. Under these conditions, a dielectric moisture sensor functions as a density measuring tool as follows: with a fixed water content by weight, the moisture sensor detects more water by volume within the sampling volume shown in Fig. 4 when the density is higher. The dielectric sensor readings respond to the volumetric amount of water in the material and therefore reflect the DD of the GBM (e.g., Ref. 22).
The manufacturer provides a calibration to convert the mV readings into soil moisture.
26
 However, it is necessary to establish a new calibration that relates the mV readings to the DD of the GBM. To do this, the PR2 probe was placed vertically in the middle of a bucket with a diameter of around 0.3 m to enclose the sampling volume of the sensor. The bucket was first filled with the GBM as gently as possible to achieve the lowest density and the first set of measurements was taken. The density was increased in steps by tapping the bucket wall until no further increase was achieved.
The mV outputs ranged from 650 to 835 mV for the varying DD conditions to which a linear function (Eq. (1)) was fitted. A high

Kriging was used for interpolation.

Along the tunnel wall: Point-wise measurements of DD along the wall

At the screw feeders: The sampling results from the in-situ backfilling were used. During the FE tunnel backfilling described above, DD at the tip of the screw feeders was periodically measured for quality control purposes. The BFM was pulled out, the GBM samples were collected from the tip of each screw feeder, and the sampled volume was estimated based on 3D laser scanning before and after sample collection.

 The obtained mean DD values were 1,612, 1,753, 1,574, 1,714, and 1,560 kg/m3 for screw feeders 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5, respectively (see Fig. 5 for screw feeder numbers).

Behind the heater (section B-b only): DD measured using the gamma–gamma method along the blue dashed line denoted as “gg” shown in Fig. 5(ii) was used. More details about the measurement can be found in Ref. 25.

The estimated as-emplaced DD in Fig. 7 showed a distinct heterogeneity over the tunnel cross-section ranging from around 1,300 to 1,700 kg/m3. The blueish colors in the contours indicating a DD below the target DD of 1,450 kg/m3 were observed locally near the tunnel wall and between the screw feeders. Nonetheless, the cross-sectional average exceeded the target DD in all sections. The high densities closer to the screw feeders were expected as the compression force generated at the tip of the screw feeders decays as the GBM flows farther away from the screw feeder. This observation was consistent with the preliminary backfilling test with a single screw feeder in a two-dimensional tank.
22
 The results indicated that the thrust force from the screw could be transmitted only over a certain distance, e.g. roughly 0.3 m. It was also observed that the top half of the tunnel with three screw feeders showed slightly higher densities compared to the bottom half with two screw feeders. This implies that, in addition to the GBM specifications, conditions such as the number of screw feeders, their positions as well as the optimum GBM supply from the distributor to each of the screw feeders could be key design parameters when refining the backfilling procedure to achieve dense and homogeneous emplacement.



4
In-situ backfilling test

4.1
Backfilling of the in-situ tunnel and dry density based on the mass-balance method
The Full-scale Emplacement (FE) experiment was designed to simulate the Swiss disposal concept for spent fuel/vitrified high-level waste (Nagra, 2016) in a 50-m-long tunnel (referred to as the FE tunnel) excavated in the Opalinus Clay in the Mont Terri rock laboratory. The FE tunnel was constructed from April to July 2012 
28
 with an average diameter of approximately 3 m. Shotcrete was applied as the tunnel lining. The resulting inner diameter of the tunnel, although not perfectly round, ranged from approximately 2.5 m to 2.7 m. The back portion of the tunnel (not discussed in this paper) was supported only by steel rings without shotcrete. Within the shotcrete interval, three heaters (dummy disposal canisters made of steel, 4.6 m in length, 1.05 m in diameter) were placed on pedestals made of highly compacted bentonite blocks as shown in Fig. 8. More details about the FE tunnel can be found in Ref. 14.

The BFM shown in Fig. 2 was used to fill the void spaces between the canisters and the tunnel wall as well as the spaces between the canisters. Backfilling of the FE tunnel was conducted in twelve steps from September 2014 until February 2015 (Fig. 9). The deepest section (the right-most trapezoidal section in Fig. 9) was filled first to generate the slope of section 1. Backfilling was then repeated for sections 2 through 11 based on the procedure described earlier. The last section immediately behind the concrete plug was filled differently, i.e., the GBM was filled during the stepwise construction of the retaining wall with a reduced number of screw feeders as needed (for more details, see Ref. 14). For each backfilling step, the mass of the filled GBM was recorded, and slopes 1 to 11 were scanned with a 3D laser scanner. Based on the scanned slopes, the newly backfilled volume was computed for each step. The backfilled bulk DD was then calculated for each section using the mass and filled volume.
The average DDs obtained for the twelve sections are shown at the top of Fig. 9. The graph shows the profile of the average DD in each section plotted along the coordinates of the tunnel crown. The DD in section 12 immediately behind the concrete plug was only 1403 kg/m3 and therefore lower than in the other sections. This was likely due to the challenging backfilling procedure with the retaining wall being built in steps at the plug location. The average DDs in the other sections varied from 1,444 to 1,555 kg/m3. The overall average DD was 1,490 kg/m3, which exceeded the target DD of 1,450 kg/m3. The DD in section 10 was slightly lower than the target value. The bentonite in this section was re-used from the mock-up filling test described earlier, and the lower density was believed to result from changes, although not confirmed, to, e.g., the grain-size distribution. Therefore, emplacing the GBM in the FE tunnel using the BFM and the optimized procedure has proven to be successful.





4.2
Dry density measurement using heated fiber-optic cables near the GBM-shotcrete interface
This section describes another in-situ DD measurement campaign in the FE tunnel based on an actively heated fiber-optic (FO) cable combined with distributed temperature sensing (DTS) referred to as active DTS (or a-DTS) throughout this paper. Conventional DTS is passive measurement of the temperature distribution along the FO cable (e.g., Ref. 29). The a-DTS method has been receiving much attention recently in soil science for measuring soil moisture (e.g., Refs. 30–32). This method was applied as a tool for monitoring the conditions of GBM 
33–35
 and was validated as the density measuring tool.
35



4.2.1
Heatable FO cable in the FE tunnel
In the FE tunnel, various types of FO cables were installed as described in Refs. 9, 14. Among these, a heatable FO cable was installed at the 00:30 and 11:30 clock positions of the tunnel cross-section, i.e., the tunnel crown (see Fig. 8). The crown area was chosen for testing the a-DTS method because the DD variability in this area may be the most critical, i.e., with low DD as observed in the mock-up experiment (including possible detection of unfilled voids). Note that a single FO cable was routed in a unicursal manner along the crown in the lined section and along the perimeters in the unlined section as shown in Fig. 8. To cover the entire length of the FE tunnel (including the unlined sections not discussed in this paper) and the niche where the measuring units were placed, the total length of the FO cable was 250 m. Along the FE tunnel crown, the FO cable was loosely fixed to the surface of the shotcrete with plastic clips at intervals of approximately 0.6–0.7 m. The shotcrete surface was undulant and, although not accurately measured, the FO cable was generally positioned at a distance of 0.01 to 0.05 m from the shotcrete surface.
The heatable FO cable used in this study was the multi-component cable BRUsens LLK-BSTH 85 °C (Fig. 10) manufactured by Solifos AG, Switzerland. With an outer diameter of 4 mm, the cable consisted of optical fibers, a gel-filled stainless steel tube, stainless steel and copper wires, and polyamide sheaths for protection and strength. Only one of the multi-mode fibers for Raman spectra DTS was used.

In the a-DTS method, the FO cable is electrically heated, and temperature responses along the cable are measured by the DTS unit. The measured temperature changes with time dT(t) are strongly affected by the thermal properties of the material surrounding the FO cable. Heat transfer from a line source is well understood and described, e.g., in Ref. 36, and the thermal conductivity (K) of the surrounding material can be estimated using the following equation:

Under such conditions, the temperature changes along the FO cable recorded by the DTS unit indicate the variation in the initial DD. In addition, any remaining voids due to imperfect backfilling would be detected as spots with a substantially lower thermal conductivity (e.g., Ref. 40). Although observation windows such as those adopted in the mock-up experiment cannot be installed on the wall of the real tunnel, the a-DTS method also provides a way of looking along the tunnel wall and detecting unfilled voids.

5
Discussion and conclusions
GBM is an element of the EBS in the Swiss disposal concept for spent fuel/vitrified high-level waste. To demonstrate the full-scale emplacement of GBM by means of a prototype BFM consisting of five screw feeders, an 8-m-long mock-up tunnel in a warehouse and a 50-m-long tunnel in the Mont Terri rock laboratory were backfilled. To ensure the successful emplacement of the GBM in these tests, the DD of the GBM was investigated based not only on conventional mass-balance averaging but also on other methods, namely the dielectric and a-DTS methods. The key results from the different measurements are summarized in Table 3.

In the mock-up test, advantage was taken of the opportunity to install instrumentation from outside the tunnel (i.e., through the tunnel wall), and dielectric tools were installed to capture the DD variation of the emplaced GBM over the tunnel cross-section. This confirmed that the as-emplaced DD varied between 1,275 and 1,684 kg/m3, generally with higher DD near the screw feeders and lower DD near the tunnel walls, including the crown area. The average cross-sectional DD estimated based on the variations was 1,530 kg/m3, which corresponded well with the average DD of 1,502 kg/m3 for the entire mock-up tunnel based on the conventional mass-balance method. It has to be emphasized that, to the best of our knowledge, the variation in DD over the tunnel cross-section had not been quantified in the previous mock-up or in-situ experiments elsewhere. As noted above, installing the tools through the tunnel wall is not feasible in a real tunnel.
The full-scale 50-m-long FE tunnel at the Mont Terri rock laboratory with three dummy disposal canisters was backfilled with GBM using the same BFM. In this test, the longitudinal DD distribution was measured with two methods: 1) slope-wise mass-balance averaging in twelve steps, and 2) a-DTS using a heatable FO cable at the crown along the entire lined section of the tunnel.
The slope-wise mass-balance average DD ranged from 1,403 kg/m



3


 to 1,555 kg/m3, with an overall average of 1,490 kg/m3 for the entire tunnel backfilled with the GBM (TM 15.0 to 44.65). The FO cable installed in the vicinity of the GBM-shotcrete interface at the tunnel crown yielded a DD ranging from 1,297 kg/m



3


 to 1,498 kg/m3, with an average of 1,385 kg/m3. The DD at the crown was generally lower than the required target value of 1,450 kg/m3. This was consistent with the results of the mock-up tunnel backfilling test that showed that the DD tended to be lower near the tunnel walls, including the crown area.
The DD of the GBM backfilled with the prototype BFM quantified in two separate full-scale tests (mock-up and FE tunnels) using three different methods (dielectric, mass-balance averaging, and a-DTS) showed variations at different scales in different directions. Combining all the findings, the overall DD of the emplaced GBM was shown to exceed the required target minimum value of 1,450 kg/m3. The longitudinal and cross-sectional variations, however, indicated that DD could locally be lower than the required minimum of 1,450 kg/m3. Interfaces between the GBM and shotcrete liner recurrently showed low DDs. To what extent these findings are safety-relevant is being investigated within the framework of the European Union’s Horizon 2020 BEACON Project (e.g., Ref. 17).
Future experiments should consider the following improvements to further refine the measurement quality:



•
Future mock-up tests should consider monitoring areas that were not well covered at this time, i.e., near the canister surface, near the pedestals, and, for multi-canister cases, the spaces between the canisters.


•
For the ongoing in-situ a-DTS test, some setting parameters can be refined in future active heating tests. Due to relatively noisy dT(t) data with a low heating power of 0.41 W/m, the heating power should be increased to, e.g., 2–4 W/m to obtain dT(t) data with a good S/N ratio. A higher heating power may be necessary in some cases for more thermally conductive materials such as wet bentonite. The spatial sampling resolution could also be refined. Sampling time should also be reduced to, e.g., 30 s or shorter. More details about these improvements are provided in Ref. 34.


•
For future in-situ experiments, the separation between the FO cable and shotcrete could be refined to optimize the accuracy of the DD estimation. In the FE experiment, due to constraints in installing the FO cables (i.e., to avoid damaging the cables during backfilling), the cable was installed near the shotcrete-GBM interface roughly 0.01–0.05 m from the shotcrete. Although the undulant shape of the tunnel wall makes it hard to consistently achieve the same separation between the FO and the tunnel wall, the minimum separation of 0.01 m was periodically confirmed in the FE tunnel, mostly at the positions where the FO cable was fixed to the wall using a plastic clip. The remainder of the FO cable was installed with a larger separation. Although the FE experiment revealed that the shotcrete had a limited influence, for future experiments it would be advantageous to install the FO cable with a clearly defined minimum separation to the tunnel wall to ensure minimal influence of the shotcrete on the estimation of thermal conductivity of the GBM. Although a continuous separation of at least 0.02 m was recommended as an example value, this may vary depending on conditions (e.g., heating duration, thermal conductivity of the tunnel wall, etc.). Further study is needed on this issue.



The overall results presented in this study provided fundamental but novel information regarding the potential range of DD variation within the as-emplaced GBM volume (longitudinal and cross-sectional) using the screw feeder-based BFM at full scale. Different methods yielded the DD of the GBM at different locations and at different spatial resolutions. A major advantage of the a-DTS method over other methods, i.e., the dielectric method and mass-balance averaging method, is the ability to yield a large number of measurements spatially (e.g., more than 40 DD values over three canisters presented in this example) with minimal disturbance due to the physical presence of the FO cable with a 4-mm diameter in the GBM.
Lastly, it has to be emphasized that the a-DTS method offers multiple features including (1) observation windows for detecting potentially unfilled voids, especially near the crown area (which used to be possible only in mock-up tests via observation windows/holes), (2) a density profile measuring tool at the time of emplacement, which was the main scope of this study, and (3) a moisture profile measuring tool for later stages (which was not within the scope of this study but is discussed in, e.g., Ref. 34. When the FO cable is not heated, the ambient temperature can be measured in passive mode, thus providing a tunnel-scale evolution of temperature resulting from the heat from the dummy disposal canisters. While generating a large amount of data along the FO cable with the least disturbance to the field, the a-DTS method offers the capability to monitor multiple quantities, thus functioning as an all-in-one monitoring tool.

Introduction
Rock formations in the Earth’s crust are subject to stresses generated by the weight of the rock column itself and that are also influenced by plate tectonics.
1

,

2
 The magnitude and orientation of the in-situ stress field can vary distinctly with depth, tectonic environment, rock type, and fabric.
3

,

4
 The deformation that rocks inevitably undergo due to the imposed stresses can be assumed to be elastic up to the point at which the rock is unable to sustain further load. When stresses exceed the intact rock’s strength or the remaining strength of a preexisting structural discontinuity, such as a fault or fracture, failure and irreversible deformation occurs in various forms. Numerous empirical criteria have been established over the years that describe this threshold for the onset of failure in different complexity using components and invariants of the second rank tensor describing the state of stress in the rock.
5


Any underground operation changes the state of stress of the subsurface to some degree. During some operations, significant stress field changes are unwanted and are often minimized to avoid any or unmanageable rock failure. Examples for such operations include the stable drilling of wells with an optimized mud weight and maintaining reservoir pressure via injection during hydrocarbon production.
6
 Other operations actively impose and rely on stress changes as part of the procedure. One prominent example is hydraulic stimulation applied in conventional and unconventional hydrocarbon reservoirs,
7
 but also in deep geothermal reservoirs to create the fracture connectivity required for economic flow while keeping induced seismicity to a minimum.
8

,

9
 Many other subsurface operations will inevitably change the stress field significantly, therefore planning procedures much account for the rock mechanical behavior to mitigate risks. Examples include early production from hydrocarbon reservoirs and end-of-field life procedures,
10
 underground gas storage,
11
 long-term nuclear waste disposal,
12
 and underground engineering such as tunnel construction.
13


To start understanding the state of stress at a given location, measurements can be performed in boreholes and underground facilities,
14
 and indirect analyses can give insights, for example, by analyzing seismic focal mechanisms from earthquakes.
15


This punctual information alone, however, is not sufficient to provide operational advice. Instead it is best used as calibration and verification data within numerical simulations that model the 3D geomechanical behavior of the subsurface.
16
 Such simulations solve constitutive equations to provide insights into the 3D stress field of a selected part of the subsurface in its present state and predict future changes due to changing conditions.

1.1
Current landscape in numerical reservoir geomechanics
3D geomechanical models based on the FE method as a numerical tool have been applied in the oil and gas industry for almost 30 years.
17

,

18
 These numerical models integrate structural information of the subsurface with experimental data from laboratory testing and field measurements and observations. For several decades now, these models help to understand the mechanical behavior of the reservoir, its surroundings and structural discontinuities before and after field development and are invaluable for operational guidance to improve safety and economic viability of hydrocarbon reservoirs.
6

,

19–21


The standard workflow to produce a 3D geomechanical model starts by generating a grid that discretizes the portion of the subsurface of interest. In the E&P industry, that would be the reservoir and its surroundings. This grid is constructed using the structural information gathered from seismic interpretation. Spatial resolution and geometrical complexity of these grids vary depending on the size of the field and the purpose of the model.
The mechanical and petrophysical rock properties are typically derived from sonic borehole measurements, lab experiments, and empirical correlations and are distributed across the grid. In recent years, seismic inversion is increasingly complementing or even replacing geostatistical methods to describe the property distribution in the inter-well space.
22–24
 The governing material laws are defined, i.e. the elasticity model and failure criteria best suited to describe the rocks involved, and the pore pressure is described throughout the model.
In addition to gravity, lateral boundary conditions are imposed to reflect the far-field tectonic situation, which is often taken from the World Stress Map.
25
 The FE solver then computes the equilibrated steady state solution of the in-situ stress field across the model (Fig. 1).

Faults and fractures can be included following different approaches. However, all approaches share the fact that properties of these structural discontinuities can only be assumed and very rarely measured. Therefore, the assumed strength and compliance has to be adjusted so that the fault’s influence on the stress field and reactivation behavior matches field observations or at least does not oppose them (Fig. 2). For examples on fault modeling strategies in reservoir geomechanics, the reader can refer to Cappa and Rutqvist
26
, Haddad and Eichhubl
27
 and Treffeisen and Henk
28
.
Following an iterative calibration with field measurements focused mostly on the boundary conditions, the model’s predictive value is verified using separate field data in blind tests. In many cases the present-day stress field is only the starting point for coupled simulations, in which the stress changes over time are computed as induced by pressure, temperature, and saturation changes during field development.
29


The application of 3D geomechanical models in the E&P industry stretches across the life cycle of reservoirs form exploration to abandonment and across multiple technical domains including geology and geophysics, reservoir engineering, and drilling.
16
 Application examples include analyses for fault seal capacity during exploration, wellbore stability for well construction, long-term well integrity and cap rock integrity, fault and fracture stability, solids production, compaction and subsidence, hydraulic stimulation, and many more (e.g. Refs. 6, 19, 21, 30–33).
The first order measure for the size of the numerical simulation is the number of elements or cells of the model, since that translates via nodes and their constraints to the number of degrees of freedom that are solved for. Within the last decade, the average size of regular 3D geomechanical models has increased from roughly 2–8 million to 10–15 million elements (e.g. Refs. 34, 35). Some operator’s geomechanics teams are now routinely running simulations with 30–60 million elements, with a few studies already crossing the 100 million element threshold.
36
 The run time for models generally depends on their size, the complexity involved from the structural side and the material model, and the computing environment. Most models that are built to assess risks and advise operations are typically run on local HPC clusters or in the cloud.
Although the precise workflows might differ from the one outlined above, many other industries outside oil and gas that operate underground are also applying 3D geomechanical simulations mostly based on finite elements, but also using finite difference or finite volume methods. In deep geothermal reservoirs, understanding the stress field is crucial for successful stimulations that allow economically viable operations.
9

,

37
 In carbon capture and sequestration projects, understanding the criticality of faults within or bordering the depleted reservoirs into which CO2 is injected is key for success.
26

,

38

,

39
 In the site selection and construction of long-term nuclear waste disposals, understanding the stress field and predicting changes, e.g. due to thermal loads over long periods of time is an important factor to ensure safe storage.
40–42
 Last, but not least, geomechanical models are regularly applied to guide and optimize underground engineering projects such as tunnels.

1.2
Old and new challenges
Geomechanics experts in the oil and gas industry face many challenges. Some modeling challenges are inherent to the input data, such as the typically sparse data available for rock mechanical properties from laboratory experiments and for in-situ stress measurements, which complicates the calibration and verification of models. In addition, the variability in data quality can be large for all different types of data involved, including experimental data, field measurements, logs, and seismic data. Both, the limited availability and varying quality of data, in combination with the fact that model calibration is inherently non-unique, make new workflows using uncertainty and inversion techniques for model parameters so essential and powerful.
43


One of the most significant challenges in geomechanics studies is the demand to generate numerical models covering large volumes in the subsurface in high resolution to capture all available data. This increase in required model size stretches across orders of magnitudes with teams going from 10 million element models to 100 million and even planning for over 1 billion elements. This study is based on this challenge that the industry is facing, which is to work with large-scale models in feasible turnaround times.

There are many reasons for this increase in geomechanics simulation size. One reason is the growing size of fluid flow models using high-resolution reservoir simulators, which often represent the basis for corresponding geomechanical models.
44

,

45
 In other cases, the use of seismic inversion data to assist and even drive the mechanical property modeling often comes with the ambition to preserve the 3D seismic resolution across large volumes to be able to screen for geomechanics-related risks, e.g. Ref. 46.
A common modeling approach to increase spatial resolution locally in a full-field simulation are so-called sector models (Fig. 2). Sector models can be solved either simultaneously using local grid refinements or explicitly using precomputed solutions. In the explicit case, the sector models with higher resolution than the full-field simulation use pre-computed displacement results of the encompassing model to define Dirichlet boundary conditions of the sector simulation.
Although this approach helps to focus the solution in an area of interest, local grids cannot fully substitute the need for higher resolutions in large-scale simulations for two reasons. Firstly, the surrounding “coarse” mesh should still be able to capture the behavior to provide a sufficiently accurate boundary condition for the sector model. Secondly, large changes in adjacent cell sizes can introduce numerical artifacts in the sector model. These artifacts can arise because of numerical instabilities of the simultaneous solutions (e.g., low condition numbers) or because of the low-resolution boundary conditions.
There are also practical challenges in pre and postprocessing large geomechanical models. Generating grids with multiple hundreds of millions of cells and populating properties across such grids can become very time consuming because of memory and visualization requirements. The main practical challenge, however, is solving the linear system of equations. Most commercially available FE simulators offer parallelization mechanisms. However, simply distributing the simulation over an increasing number of processors using message passing interface (MPI) tasks will not be enough to make it work on this scale. While the memory demand per MPI decreases with more MPI tasks, it will most likely still be substantial and more than a single standard HPC compute node offers, especially when more than one MPI task is running per compute node.
In addition to storing a very large stiffness matrix, this high memory demand is also related to the fact that in geomechanical simulations, the solver must be able to include as many material sets as elements are in the model. This is because the 3D property distribution is typically at least guided by seismic inversion data, if not directly derived from it, and thus the mechanical property values are varying on a cell-by-cell basis within and across formations. Assuming representative but constant sets of mechanical properties for each formation will allow to reduce the related memory requirement drastically and allow even unoptimized solvers to run large simulations. However, the predictive value of the resulting models would suffer significantly from such simplification. To guide and ensure safe and sustainable subsurface operations, geomechanical investigations must not constrain the fidelity of input data, instead numerical tools should cope with the computational requirements.



2
Seismic geomechanics on a new scale
This study explores the notion of how the appropriate combination of the modeling approach, compute environments and optimized FE solvers can address the need for geomechanical models with hundreds of millions to over a billion elements.
A new way of generating the geomechanical model directly from seismic data was applied on a case study dataset from the Gulf of Mexico. This more direct approach allows to bypass classical gridding and modeling constraints to generate numerical simulations for the subsurface volume of interest faster and more efficiently for both, pre and postprocessing. Multiple models were built to the seismic resolution and exported for simulation on the original seismic grid.
The main part of the study focused on the developments and improvements for the numerical solver. While most commercial FE solvers allow multimillion element simulations, several problems arise when approaching simulation sizes of a billion elements with strongly heterogeneous material models as is standard in seismic geomechanics. The FE solver used in this methodology was improved especially in its memory efficiency and parallelization to be able to solve geomechanical simulations on such new scales on state-of-the-art HPC infrastructures.
Both methodological advances, the modeling approach and the improved solver, as well as the HPC compute environment, would independently facilitate large-scale stress modeling, but are combined in this study for optimal results.

2.1
Direct modeling approach
Whenever seismic inversion results provide sufficient input and quality, those are directly used as basis for the mechanical property model and complemented with log data. This approach is increasingly applied in the E&P industry due to the higher predictability of the resulting model in the inter-well space. In the pursuit of speeding up the model-building process and making it more efficient for large simulations, this approach is taken one step further, and the seismic volumes are utilized directly to generate the simulation input and the generation of new grids is avoided. Instead the seismic volume itself is used as the perfectly structured grid it already represents.
The seismic data on which the two main case study models are based describes a total subsurface volume of 34.2 km 
×
 28.3 km 
×
 5.5 km (Fig. 3). The seismic inversion volumes start from the seabed and attributes are quality checked before being used for the setup of the mechanical property model. In the same way seismic properties and derived attributes are mapped in the seismic volume, such as velocities and acoustic impedance, the static elastic properties are calculated including Young’s modulus or Poisson ratio. Common 3D modeling platforms typically offer enough flexibility for seismic calculations, so empirical correlations can be applied to provide the full range of input properties for standard geomechanical simulations as seismic volumes.

The depth-converted vertical resolution of the seismic was 5 m with a horizontal resolution of 25 m in both directions. Two main numerical models were generated with 1,068,546,976 and 522,576,600 elements in total (Fig. 3), with grids identical to the structure of the utilized seismic volumes. The mechanical properties for the geomechanical model are derived from seismic cubes of compressional and shear wave velocity and density provided by a deterministic seismic inversion. The static and dynamic elastic properties are assumed to be identical as a first approximation, but empirical correlations could be used to modify properties accordingly. The range of values for all properties is given in Table 1.

The mechanical behavior of the salt bodies is approximated by a high Poisson ratio of 0.5 and a low Young’s modulus of 0.3 GPa. This suppresses deviatoric stresses in the salt and results in the boundary of a salt body acting as a principal stress plane. While more elaborate salt behavior and properties could be accounted for including creep, such complexity is beyond the scope of this study. The pore pressure in this model is also derived from seismic and shows substantial variations and overpressured zones. Below a depth of 4 km beneath the seabed, the pressure gradients reach over 0.17 bar/m. In shallower zones, the pressure gradient is close to hydrostatic. Inside the salt body, the pressure is set to zero.
Seismic volumes describing mechanical properties and pore pressure are exported directly as simulation deck for the numerical solver. In addition to gravity, Dirichlet-type displacement boundary conditions are imposed on the model to reflect the far-field tectonic influence. Since the main target of this study was stress initialization, no additional embedding was imposed as there were no internal loads applied, such as pressure or temperature changes, that could have been affected by their proximity to the boundaries. In any case, the model size would have allowed load changes in the interior within a reservoir-sized region with sufficient distance to the boundaries as to consider the model to be effectively embedded. The case study models are also aligned with the far-field stresses and displacements were applied normal to the boundaries to minimize edge effects. Including the applied displacement constraints, the largest numerical model reflected over 3.2 billion degrees of freedom to be considered when computing the elastic, steady-state stress solution.
This approach has multiple significant advantages when pushing the scale of geomechanical simulations. Firstly, the seismic grid is perfectly structured, i.e. the cells (hexahedra) are of equal shape and size as given by the seismic resolution (25 m 
×
