×
 5 m). This uniformity allows to convey the grid information to the simulator as ‘instruction’ rather than ‘description’. In other words, instead of writing classical element and node files with coordinates, the simulator is told the absolute grid size and the element spacing in all dimensions and is then able to calculate the coordinates when required. This saves disk space and time for creating, exporting, and reading files, which can range from tens to hundreds of gigabytes for the targeted scale of simulation.
Secondly, seismic volumes regularly have hundreds of millions of cells and even multiple billion cells. 3D subsurface modeling platforms can visualize such seismic cubes and intersections on common workstations very quickly and offer many display options for 2D and volume rendering. However, most platforms would struggle with arbitrary grid visualization on the same scale.
In addition, time is also saved by the lack of property modeling operations, which can become very time consuming for large models. The 3D seismic data is also preserved throughout the volume of interest and not downscaled when resampled into a separate grid with potentially lower horizontal resolution. Despite some disadvantages that are discussed later, this workflow facilitates significantly the pre and postprocessing for geomechanical models on the targeted new scale.


2.2
FE solver improvements
The key factor for running large-scale stress simulations in high resolution is the numerical solver. The objective of this study was to optimize an existing solver
1


1
The optimized iterative solver is part of the VISAGE simulator. VISAGE is a mark of Schlumberger.
 to be able to run such models in time frames acceptable to industry workflows. An iterative solver based on the conjugate gradient method was used as iterative solvers are highly parallelizable, which is paramount for feasible turnaround times of large simulations.


2.3
Parallelization and memory efficiency
Most advanced numerical simulations are solved nowadays in parallel on multiple processors, either on a single machine or on clusters with many connected compute nodes. By distributing the computational load, this allows significantly faster solutions. MPI is widely adopted as standard communication protocol for such distribution. Multiple communicating MPI tasks are running on separate processors and are each solving a part of the numerical problem independently.
With an increasing number of MPIs, the problem size for each task reduces and therefore the associated memory required. However, the decrease in memory required per MPI with an increasing number of tasks is limited by the need for an overlap between the computational domains and the fact that MPI tasks do not share memory. Therefore, parts of the data need to be duplicated among some or all of the MPI tasks.
Numerical solvers commonly use three main types of arrays, which are element arrays, degree of freedom (DOF) arrays, and solver arrays. To reduce memory demand, these arrays must be reduced in size and split as much as possible across all MPI tasks. This work represented the core of the solver improvements in this study. While element arrays are distributed perfectly between MPI tasks and solver arrays describing all nonzero terms, as well as working arrays are split with only a minor overlap of less than one percent, the improvements focused on the split of DOF arrays with an overlap of less than five percent.
For a simulation with one billion linear hexahedral elements with approximately three billion DOF, roughly 22 GB of memory are required per DOF array when stored either as double precision real arrays or 64bit integer arrays. Depending on the simulation, there are between 10 to 15 arrays and even with 10 arrays about 200 GB of memory could be saved per MPI task.
In addition, several arrays are removed to reduce the memory demand and improvements were also required for the broadcasting of material data across MPI tasks to avoid spikes in memory demand.
The memory requirements of the improved solver for stress simulations with heterogeneous​ material models are plotted in Fig. 4 as the relationship between the number of MPI tasks and the memory required per MPI task for four examples of simulation size. The plotted memory requirement is given for arbitrary grids, be those structured or unstructured in nature. For the perfectly structured grids as the seismic volumes used in this study, the memory demand is about further 5% lower.

While the memory demand decreases significantly per MPI task with higher degree of parallelization, it approaches asymptotically a minimum memory limit required per MPI that depends on the simulation size (Fig. 4).
To solve the targeted large-scale stress simulations on powerful, yet common HPC clusters, the number of MPI tasks running on a single compute node must be limited. Even with improved memory efficiency, multiple MPI tasks would swiftly exceed available memory. In other words, pure MPI-based parallelization is inadequate for the objectives of this study.
A hybrid approach using MPI and OpenMP (OMP) is adopted to achieve more memory-efficient parallelization. OpenMP stands for Open Multi-Processing and allows shared memory multithreading of applications. With MPI, each individual processor has a copy of the data it needs to run. While most data can be split across the tasks evenly, there are some parts of the dataset that need to be duplicated. With the shared memory assumption that can be made with OMP, this duplication can be cut down considerably, as each processor can access the same store of memory where this data exists. As such the memory efficiency of pure OMP is higher than that of pure MPI, but with the limitation that OMP can only be applied within a single compute node. The hybrid parallelization approach uses both MPI and OMP, such that OMP threads are used for parallelism within a multi-core compute node, while MPI is used for parallelism between nodes.

This hybrid approach enables a far more efficient use of processing power on the HPC cluster available. Fig. 5 illustrates the memory required per compute node with an increasing number of CPUs being used. This example assumes 16 compute nodes being available with 16 processors each. By distributing every additional MPI task on a separate node, the memory required per compute node decreases until all 16 nodes are involved. From this point onward, adding additional MPI tasks per node to utilize more processing power significantly increases the memory demand for each node (Fig. 5). It becomes likely that while reserving the full compute nodes for their memory, only a fraction of CPUs can be utilized to solve the numerical simulation before violating the memory constraints.
The hybrid approach allows the CPUs within each node to be utilized via OMP threads, which results only in a minor overhead in memory demand per compute node (Fig. 5). This hybrid parallelization is key for solving stress simulations on the scale targeted in this study.

3
Results
The simulations performed for the two models outlined in Fig. 3 show that with an optimized numerical solver and a suitable compute environment, feasible runtimes for large-scale high-resolution geomechanical models can be achieved.
The model with roughly 500 million elements and 1.5 billion DOF was solved in multiple hybrid parallelization setups. With the provided HPC configuration, an optimal runtime of 3 h and 36 min is achieved with 96 MPI and 32 OMP tasks per MPI utilizing 3072 cores in total. This runtime is well within the timeframe required in the oil and gas and other industries for the operational use of such models. Fig. 6 shows the reduction in runtime for the 500 million element simulation as it is decreased from several days to only a few hours.
The largest model generated for the case study area with over one billion elements and 3.2 billion DOF could be solved on only 16 compute nodes with extended memory capacity in 48 hours. These results demonstrate that with an optimized solver and suitable compute infrastructure, the runtimes of such large models are not a limiting factor for their wider application across industries.
For this study, the generated simulation results are postprocessed and visualized as seismic volumes and on related cross-sections. The simulation results reflect the model complexity and show the stress field being perturbed by the salt diapirs in terms of stress orientation and magnitude as expected (Fig. 7). Close to the salt, the maximum principal stress is oriented perpendicular to the surface of the salt body. This is expected with the almost fluid-like behavior of salt and is in agreement with other numerical studies, e.g. Refs. 47–49. With increasing distance from the salt body, the magnitude of the stress rotations decreases, while the magnitude changes are largely driven by the heterogeneity of the material model.

With either a high stress anisotropy or a highly fractured area at these locations, any well being drilled through such region is likely to experience problems of wellbore stability. Such considerations are typically included in the planning of directional drilling through salt to ensure safe operations when entering and exiting salt bodies, e.g. see Ref. 50.

The direct application of the simulation results for preliminary drilling risk analyses is illustrated on two cross-sections through the modeled area (Fig. 9). Stress perturbations around the salt bodies highlight potential impacts on safe drilling window estimates and depict how far these effects can reach into the surroundings. For example, the minimum in-situ principal stress is commonly used as the fracture gradient and describes the upper limit of the safe mud weight window, i.e. mud losses are likely to occur whenever the equivalent circulating density of the drilling mud reaches this limit. In this example, reductions in the fracture gradient below the main salt body suggest the potential for losses of drilling fluid that are very costly and risk safe operations (Fig. 9). Prior knowledge of these fracture gradient reductions can help to plan wells with improved casing plans and/or detailed contingency strategies. Similarly, increased stress magnitudes toward the flanks of the salt body can serve as indicators of possible overpressures in adjacent shale formations due to undrained loading.
Other simulation results can provide insights into more advanced wellbore stability topics. For example, the selection of optimum drilling directions can be a function of the relative orientation of the borehole with respect to the in-situ stress orientation. Under certain conditions, salt bodies can influence both the azimuthal and vertical orientation of the principal stresses. In this example, the presence of excess shear stress (shown for the ZX plane) is a direct consequence of the salt presence, and it signals a vertical tilt of the principal in-situ stresses (Fig. 9). This information, along with the rest of the stress tensor, provides very important information when designing optimal well orientations near salt structures.
These results illustrate that simulating the 3D state of stress in the subsurface allows to assess and quantify the depth and extent of areas that are posing risks to drilling, production or other subsurface operations. Simulation results obtained with the applied direct modeling approach can be interrogated and displayed as usual for geomechanical studies. Despite the extraordinary size of the geomechanical model, postprocessing, and visualization is managed in normal turnaround times. This modeling approach has proven to be particularly useful when it comes to large-scale screening for subsurface geomechanical risks in high resolution.


4
Discussion
The applied modeling approach directly using seismic volumes and the underlying perfectly structured seismic grids has been proven suitable to solve the problems related to pre and postprocessing of large-scale geomechanical models. While this approach also has its merits for certain types of projects, there are drawbacks for other studies. Geomechanical models are commonly based on grids that are aligned with subsurface geometry including horizons, geobodies and faults, and often vary in local resolution and element shape as required by the data, the project scope and for computing efficiency. The current approach lacks this flexibility and is thus limited for arbitrary application. Along irregular boundaries of geobodies with a significant contrast in mechanical properties, for example salt bodies, small-scale stress perturbations can be observed as artifacts on an element-by-element level. These perturbations were considered sufficiently small for the scale of this study. However, it is possible to include vertical adjustments in the adopted seismic grid to account for horizons, for example, without sacrificing the computing benefits of the structured seismic grid entirely. Even local grid refinements using multipoint constraints could be realized.
Faults could be included on such structured grids by identifying the respective elements and then either following an equivalent material approach or by applying other discontinuity modeling techniques, such as extended finite element methods.
51

,

52


The scale of the structural features that a seismic survey is able to resolve can be also several times coarser than the sampling rate of the seismic grid. Hence, to optimize the geomechanical model following this direct approach, one could also adjust the resolution of the seismic cubes used for the numerical model according to the known resolution of the particular seismic survey. However, the objective of the case study was to build a large-scale geomechanical model of the size and resolution as required by the data without the need for compromises in simulation size or sector modeling approaches, and therefore the given resolution was assumed to be required.
Another drawback of this direct modeling approach is the limited modeling capability on seismic volumes. While general calculations are available for seismic attributes on 3D modeling platforms, there is no functionality to upscale logs, for example, or run geostatistical methods. This limits the modeling approach significantly whenever the data situation would require such procedures.
While the numerical solver was optimized to take advantage of input provided on perfectly structured grids, such as seismic volumes, it is not limited to this type of grid for running large models. Structured grids help to reduce file IO and memory consumption additionally, but the solver has been optimized in terms of efficiency also for partially structured and unstructured grids. This is crucial since 3D modeling platforms are improving visualization and rendering techniques so that the current pre and postprocessing limitations are most likely resolved in the upcoming years and arbitrary grids will be used on this new scale.
The case study models were solved in one linear elastic initialization load step. Although more sophisticated formulations could have been applied, for example, fully coupled poroelasticity and plasticity, such considerations are more applicable to reservoir-scale geomechanical simulations rather than to the large-scale models that this study targets for regional geomechanical screening workflows.
When it comes to the final memory requirements for numerical models above half a billion cells, those are still considerable and a few years back that would have posed a serious problem (Fig. 4). However, chip technology is progressing fast and the latest processor technology can provide up to 2TB of memory per CPU. While such chips are admittedly rare to have in a standard cluster, compute nodes with 512–786 GB of memory are not rare for newly built HPC clusters. Moreover, the uptake of cloud computing offers entirely new possibilities, which makes memory just another parameter to request when provisioning cloud resources for simulations.


5
Conclusions
This study shows how a commercial FE simulator for 3D geomechanical modeling is optimized in multiple aspects to solve numerical simulations on a large scale of hundreds of millions of elements and more. The new capability is demonstrated using a real-world dataset from the Gulf of Mexico to generate geomechanical models to the original data resolution, in this case seismic inversion data. The models comprise a fully heterogeneous material distribution and are built directly from seismic data following a new direct modeling workflow. Using state-of-the-art HPC infrastructure, these stress simulations can be solved in about 3.5 h using over 3000 CPUs, which demonstrates feasible turnaround times for this new scale of stress simulations. While a local compute cluster was used in this study, equal and larger compute capacity can be accessed in cloud environments. This new scale of numerical FE models enables geomechanical investigations of the subsurface in unrivaled detail and resolution to improve operations in the energy industry for safe production of hydrocarbons, but also provide mechanical safety constraints for geothermal reservoirs, CO2 sequestration, nuclear waste disposal, and underground engineering in general.

Introduction
Geotechnical engineering in deltaic areas is challenging due to the peculiar nature of soft soils, including loose sands, soft clays and peats. Design and assessment procedures for geotechnical works in these areas have been developed based on shared valuable expertise, with little attention on comprehensive constitutive approaches. However, accurate description of the pre-failure behaviour and better understanding of failure modes, which cannot be accurately predicted by simpler approaches (e.g. Nova and Hueckel
1
; Nova
2

,

3
), require advancements in constitutive modelling capabilities. Besides the application in geotechnical engineering problems, constitutive modelling efforts are inherently valuable in underpinning comprehensive understanding of soil behaviour and guiding further improvement of experimental testing, theoretical understanding and numerical modelling.
The constitutive approaches developed in the last decades for loose sands and soft clays seem satisfactory to understand and predict the geotechnical response of these soils (Lade et al.
4
; Yoshimine et al.
5
; Lade
6

13

14
; Sivasithamparam et al.,
15
 among others). On the contrary, constitutive modelling for peats lags behind, due to apparently contradictory information coming from classical laboratory tests. The observed inconsistencies are attributed typically to the natural heterogeneity and to the contribution of fibres, which are claimed to hinder significance of laboratory tests and advanced comprehension of the mechanical response of peats. As a result, empirical paradigms have often substituted comprehensive modelling attempts.
Most of the modelling effort in the past has been directed towards the time dependent compression behaviour, which received a lot of attention due to the engineering consequences of unusually high compressibility (Berry and Poskitt
16
; Edil and Mochtar

26
; Yang et al.
27
; Muraro et al.
28
).
To start filling the gap towards comprehensive modelling approaches, an extensive experimental investigation was designed and performed at Delft University of Technology 
29–31
 on natural and reconstituted samples of Dutch organic clays and peats. The aim of the research effort is better analysing the pre-failure deformation behaviour of these soils, tackling the apparently contradictory results and providing reliable information to advance the development of constitutive models for engineering purposes. The effort was supported by a parallel numerical investigation, aimed at highlighting bottlenecks in the interpretation of the data.
Paradigmatic data from laboratory tests performed on reconstituted and natural samples of peat are presented and discussed in view of their significance in the development of constitutive models. Numerical analyses are presented to support the use of the laboratory data in the development of a constitutive framework. It is shown that the results can be better exploited if they are interpreted as the response of a small-scale boundary value problem, instead of as the pure evidence of material element behaviour. The role of distinct fibres levels, having different length, spatial distribution and interaction with the peat matrix is addressed, in an attempt to encompass the differences between reconstituted and natural peats.

In the Netherlands, peats are found consistently in the upper subsoil, especially in the central and western provinces of the country. Geotechnical engineering in these areas is tackled often with simplified approaches, relying on traditional shear strength criteria, or on one-dimensional models for compression and creep. Finite element analyses are run in more delicate cases, typically requiring a soil–structure interaction analysis. In these cases, appropriate constitutive models must be chosen. In the current practice, in the absence of constitutive models specifically developed for peats, available proposals for soft clays are typically adopted,
33–35
 which may result in poor description of the response of these soils at working strain and stress conditions.
Lack of appropriate constitutive models for peats has an impact already on simple limit equilibrium calculations, which suffer from uncertainty in the choice of shear strength parameters, due to the results of laboratory tests being contradictory. Fig. 1 shows data from standard undrained triaxial tests (TxCU, Fig. 1a) and undrained direct simple shear tests (DSS, Fig. 1b) on homogenous natural samples of peat from the Leendert de Boerspolder (NL).

The comparison between the two data sets suggests a difference of about 10 degrees in the friction angle whether inferred from TxCU or DSS. If the dramatic difference in the friction angle from TxCU and DSS were an intrinsic characteristic of peats, it would imply a non-convex shear strength surface in the deviatoric plane, which could hardly be accepted. Alternatively, it would suggest that an unstable mode of failure is systematically reached in DSS, still in the hardening regime and well below the limit strength surface of the soil. However, data from DSS tests do not show any sign of instability and controllability of the response is never lost.
The relevant difference between ultimate shear stress in TxCU and DSS of peats has been consistently observed in previous experimental investigations. In the literature, this difference has been conjectured to come from horizontally aligned fibres, which can stretch in a triaxial stress path and provide additional confinement to the sample, while keep inactive in DSS due to elongation being prevented from null radial displacement. This assumption led to various proposals for correcting triaxial tests data to match DSS ultimate strength, which are schematically displayed in Fig. 2.
These include identifying failure with arbitrary thresholds for axial strain

,

40

41

42

22
 (Fig. 2d). The rationale behind these suggestions is that the data have to be cleaned from the effects of fibres stretch, if a prudential evaluation of the available shear strength in the field is sought.
The previous choices are supported by the following three assumptions on the response of peats: (i) DSS better mimics the deformation mode expected at failure in the field; (ii) the fibres are horizontally aligned, which gives the peat an inherent anisotropic fabric; (iii) no fibres elongation is expected along the stress path mimicked by a DSS test. In reality, all these assumptions can be disputed based on laboratory and field evidence.




2.1
Constant volume simple shear in the field?
At the field scale, it is not proven that the mode of failure of peat layers is simple shearing. On the contrary, field tests on various embankments founded on peat 
35

,

43–45
 suggest that lateral bulging is more likely, due to high compressibility of the peat layer and reduced lateral confinement. A recent full scale stress and failure test on a historical dyke, performed at the Leendert de Boerspolder site, north of Leiden in the Netherlands, confirmed that failure in peats may occur with appreciable volume change, with a deformation mode quite different from that expected in a constant volume simple shear test.
30


The dyke stress test was part of a large research project supported by various provinces and water boards in the Netherlands and financed by the foundation for research on regional dykes, STOWA, and the national Dutch organisation for scientific research, NWO. Details on the test design and monitoring, as well as detailed analyses of the results, are given by De Gast

Fig. 3 sketches the final cross section of the dyke, which was brought to failure by excavating and decreasing the water level at the toe of the original section in steps, until the final rapid drawdown triggered the failure of the system along the schematic mechanism described in the figure.

The dyke had been instrumented with a number of piezometers, inclinometers and extensometers to track as well as possible the coupled hydro-mechanical response of the system, in the pre-failure and the failure stages (Fig. 4). In Fig. 5, the deformation mode is plotted over the final stage of the test, as reconstructed from relevant inclinometers and extensometers data. The data clearly show that failure in the peat layer was approached with a dominant bulging mode, which is better reproduced in triaxial tests, rather than under DSS constraint.






2.2
Horizontally aligned fibres?

Fig. 6 shows images of the fabric of peat at various scales. The peat fabric is organised in organic peds composed by partially decomposed leaves, roots and stems together with inorganic sand grains (visible in Fig. 6a and b as white spots). In the fibrous network reconstructed from micro CT scan in Fig. 6c fibres with different orientations and curvatures are visible. The experimental information suggests that, in general, the fibres do not show an initial preferential orientation and that inherent anisotropy might be rather limited in peats.

Lack of horizontal alignment also implies that the fibres will be able to stretch over simple shear deformation, in all the directions which are not constrained from zero elongation. Clear evidence of fibres stretching was given by Den Haan and Grognet
47
 on samples tested in a large DSS box and tracked by Particle Image Velocimetry. The results of the analysis, reported in an illustrative on-line video, clearly highlight fibres stretching and pull out along variable directions of the samples, in a more diffused and randomly oriented way than usually assumed.

Evidence of an anisotropic response?
As shown in Fig. 6, peats are made of an organic matrix containing inorganic elements and fibres of different length. These fibres are able to sustain tension, but they become inactive over compression due to bending and warping. To better discuss the evidence of anisotropy on the response of peats, the results of an isotropic compression test are presented. Over isotropic compression, the fibres network is almost inactive and the response of the matrix can be isolated. In addition, isotropic compression is the stress path which better identifies initial anisotropy and its evolution rate at increasing stress.

3.1
Isotropic compression
A simple analysis was performed to replicate the results reported in Fig. 8. The sample was subjected to isotropic compression, either assuming perfectly smooth top and bottom platens or perfectly rough ones. The deformed mesh reported in Fig. 10a resembles the visual observation in Fig. 8a, showing the shear deformational component introduced by the kinematic constraint. In Fig. 10b, the results of the analyses are compared with the previous experimental data and with experimental results from Yamaguchi et al.
54
 on a similar peat. The numerical results were elaborated from the external quantities (total volume change and total axial displacement) replicating the common practice in the elaboration of laboratory data. The comparison shows that part of the offset between the results and the theoretical isotropic response is due to the effect of end restraint, and not to inherent anisotropy due to fibres orientation, which was advocated by Yamaguchi et al.,
54
 among others, to explain the unusual response. At this stage, it is worth noting that the result does not prove that peats are not anisotropic. Instead, it enlightens that only a careful analysis of the results allows quantifying the effects of material anisotropy, and that the specimen response should not be acritically confused with the evidence of the intrinsic material behaviour.





3.2
Undrained deviatoric compression
The vast majority of experimental studies on the deviatoric behaviour of peats is performed by means of standard undrained triaxial tests TxCU. Over undrained deviatoric compression, end restraint is expected to play a significant role because the sample needs to expand laterally in order to comply with the constant volume global constraint. Limiting the lateral expansion at the top and bottom will generate spurious shear strains and modify the whole stress and strain states. The expected response is schematically indicated in Fig. 11. If a uniform strain mode were allowed, the resulting excess pore pressure would be uniform over height and in the radial direction, together with the effective radial stress (Fig. 11a). With end restraint, a less deformed zone, named dead wedge in the literature,
55
 is expected to develop at the bottom and the top of the specimen. In spite of closed drainage at the ends, pressure gradient will be generated inside the specimen, which will slowly equalise depending on the hydraulic conductivity, allowing for local volumetric strain. The excess pore water pressure at the base is expected to be higher than that at mid height of the sample (Fig. 11b). These effects are expected to introduce an error on the apparent stress path of the sample, if this is calculated based on the global available external measures.

To demonstrate the interpretation error in elaborating data from standard undrained triaxial compression, a deviatoric stress path was simulated, including rough end platens and radial displacement restraint over a 10 mm height (from visual detection during the experimental tests). The results of the numerical analysis are shown in Fig. 12. In Fig. 12a the isotropic effective stress and deviatoric stress at the bottom of the sample over the radius of the specimen are compared to the values derived from the external measurements (global quantities).

The results clearly indicate that the elaboration from global measurements both underestimates the isotropic effective stress p’ and overestimates the deviatoric stress q. The difference reduces to a large extent if reference is made to the distribution at mid height of the specimen (Fig. 12b), although some bias still remain, especially at its outer boundary. As a consequence of these non-uniformities, the excess pore pressure at the bottom of the specimen, where standard pore pressure transducers are connected, is higher than that at the centre of the specimen, where the effects of end restraint are smaller (Fig. 12c). The consequence of using a pore pressure transducer connected to the bottom of the sample, and evaluating strains and stresses from global measurements is highlighted in Fig. 12d by the difference between the expected and the estimated ultimate stress ratio, with the latter clearly overestimating the shear strength of the soil.
The deformed shape of the specimen at 20% axial strain, reported in Fig. 13a, shows the influence of end restraint on the strain mode and the pore pressure gradient. Lateral bulging of the central portion of the specimen produces a non-equalised pore pressure gradient over the volume of the sample. The deformed shape of a peat specimen sheared in undrained condition with rough end platens is shown in Fig. 13b for comparison. In spite of the absence of external drainage, local volumetric strains compensating each other are allowed during the compression stage, which was demonstrated experimentally by the non-uniform final profile of water content detected on the tested samples.
56



In Fig. 14a, the apparent stress path, calculated with global external measurements is compared to the theoretical one. Smooth platens obviously guarantee better observation of the material response in the triaxial test, however, reasonable information could be deduced too from standard tests with rough end platens, provided the pore pressure were measured at mid height of the sample. On the contrary, with pore pressure measurement at the bottom, besides substantial overestimation of the shear strength, a dramatic error in plotting the entire stress path is introduced, which is exacerbated by the radial constraint introduced at the bottom and top ends of the specimen. The error propagates in the evaluation of the deformation mode, which requires to be carefully evaluated in the development of constitutive approaches. 
52


In Fig. 14b, the difference is shown from the experimental results on two identical samples of reconstituted peat tested with smooth and rough platens, respectively. Although the trend of the difference is similar to the theoretical one, a dramatic change in the ultimate shear stress ratio can also be appreciated, which cannot be reproduced approaching the material behaviour with a MCC type model, and requires a more advanced modelling approach. An operative criterion to correct data from standard triaxial tests and obtain reasonable values for either the friction angle or the undrained shear strength was discussed recently by Muraro & Jommi,
56
 in an attempt to re-establish the usefulness of standard triaxial tests on peats in the engineering practice.






4
Summary of experimental findings underpinning an elastic–plastic constitutive approach
To start filling the gap between engineering needs and currently available models, an extensive experimental programme was performed on reconstituted samples of peat. The choice for reconstituted samples was motivated by the need for repeatable sets of tests, on which the main features of the material behaviour could be investigated. The samples were collected at the Leendert de Boerspolder to support the design and the interpretation of the stress test. The entire experimental investigation is reported by Muraro,
30
 and has been discussed in previous works together with the criteria for the development of the constitutive approach.
32

,

52

,

56

,

57
 Details on the soil classification, triaxial equipment and testing protocols can be found in Jommi et al.
32
 and Muraro & Jommi.
56


In the following, a brief summary of selected results is presented, which guided the development of a constitutive framework for peat. A strain hardening elastic–plastic approach was chosen, although different approaches have been also proposed in the last years.
27

,

28

,

6
Conclusions
Peats and fibrous organic fine grained soils are challenging from the constitutive modelling perspective due to some concomitant factors, which have hindered the development of comprehensive modelling frameworks. Contradictory experimental results have been tackled in the past in a rather empirical way, typically bringing to over-conservative approaches in the engineering practice. Advancing the understanding and the modelling of these soils will help in better addressing geotechnical solutions in soft deltaic areas and reducing the associated costs. To this aim, a combined experimental, theoretical and numerical effort was started at TU Delft, which could explain the physical reason for apparently inconsistent results, and underpin the development of a possible modelling framework, which includes present knowledge and traces a possible path towards future developments.
The experimental tests highlighted that well known defects of standard triaxial equipment are exacerbated when testing peats, because of their unique combination of extremely high compressibility and shear strength. Rough end platens and membrane restraint effects were found to be responsible for the large difference in ultimate shear strength detected from triaxial and simple shear tests. If the end restraint is limited by the use of smooth platens, experimental data provide a consistent picture of peat response. Also, the results indicate that the distributed network of small fibres in the peat matrix is seldom preferentially oriented, and will equally play a role in any deformation mode, including simple shear.
Rough platens and membrane restraint effects bias the entire stress paths and the strain measures derived from global external measurements. This aspect does not hinder the use of standard triaxial data in the characterisation of peats, but strongly suggests that the data must be carefully elaborated to derive model parameters from raw data. This becomes evident when analysing the response of a peat specimen in the triaxial equipment as a boundary value problem, rather than a perfect test on a material sample. Numerical analyses are extremely valuable in this respect, and they can be used as an aid to assist data interpretation from tests run with non-optimal equipment setup. For various reasons, including proper tracking the deformation of the fibres network, finite kinematics is recommended in the analysis of the data, to avoid introducing unnecessary bias in the interpretation.
Limiting the attention to an elastic–plastic framework, the results collected on reconstituted peat samples indicated that two ingredients, namely non-associated plastic flow and a hardening law depending on both deviatoric and volumetric plastic strains, are rather crucial features of peats, which had been seldom considered in the past. The transition from peats through organic clays towards soft clays is continuous. Therefore, it is not surprising that some of the general markers of the response of peats are shared with the broader category of soft clays.
Anisotropy is one of these markers. However, the true anisotropic response of peats can be identified only after spurious effects from the test setup have been cleaned for. The results collected suggest that the fibrous matrix including small fibres, typically few millimetres long, is not inherently anisotropic, but will suffer from induced anisotropy depending on the stress and strain history of the soil. On the contrary, when natural peats contain bigger and longer fibres, these may have a preferential orientation due to the formation environment of the material.
Including these big fibres in a homogenous model is not unfeasible; however, this might be not an ideal approach. A more effective constitutive approach can be developed if the distribution of the initial orientation of big fibres is explicitly introduced, and a finite kinematics approach is adopted to accurately follow the fibres deformation modes, their stretch and their interaction with the peat matrix.

Introduction
In the last few decades, experimental geomechanics has experienced a tremendous leap forward, thanks to a number of major technological advances along with a matching computational power. Besides the development of new and powerful tools (e.g., Broad Ion Beaming (BIB),
1
 rheography,
2
) a number of techniques which had been well established in domains neighbouring that of geomechanics have permeated into soil and rock mechanics. Some notable examples are nanoindentation 
3
 and diffraction.
4–6
 Non-contact measurement techniques, which over the last two decades have passed from relatively niche to well-established tools (e.g.,  Refs. 7, 8) are of particular interest. Such techniques are often referred to as full-field, in contrast to more conventional “point-wise” or “bulk-averaged” measurement techniques, which are based on the use of transducers positioned at the specimen boundaries. In conventional material testing, in fact, the measured response can at best be seen to represent an overall, averaged material response.
Consequently, only in the case of a perfectly homogeneous material undergoing perfectly uniform deformation, the response measured from the test will reflect the true material (i.e., constitutive) behaviour. Geomaterials are never perfectly homogeneous at the scale of a laboratory specimen, nor are boundary conditions perfectly applied. Furthermore, even when starting from “perfectly” homogeneous conditions, processes (e.g., deformation) can eventually localise into more or less narrow zones (shear and compaction bands, tensile and shear cracks or fractures) at some stage of a test. In the presence of localised strains, it is clear that the meaning of stress and strain variables derived from boundary measurements of loads and displacements is only nominal, or conventional.
Measuring a strain field within a specimen is therefore the only way in which test results can be appropriately interpreted. A number of full-field techniques (thermal, wave-based, optical) have been – and are being – used in laboratory testing of soil and rock: ultrasonic tomography (e.g.,  Refs. 9, 10), electrical resistivity tomography (e.g.,  Refs. 11, 12), magnetic resonance imaging (e.g.,  Refs. 13–15), infrared thermography (e.g.,  Refs. 16–18) – to mention but a few. A remarkable example is represented by the techniques based on ionising radiation: X-rays and neutrons.
X-ray attenuation is a function of atomic number and density. Conversely neutrons interact with the nuclei. Due to different interactions with matter, neutrons attenuation of light elements such as hydrogen (and its compounds such as water and hydrocarbons) and lithium is several orders of magnitude higher than their X-ray attenuation. Furthermore, metals such as aluminium and titanium are hand far more transparent to neutrons than to X-rays, facilitating the construction of in-operando testing apparatus for high confinement pressures. These are but a few of the advantages of neutrons, which will be explored in this paper and whose potential in geomechanics has so far been only partially exploited – which may perhaps be explained by its comparative rarity.

X-rays have established themselves as a reference technique for the non invasive study of micro-mechanical processes in geomechanics such as grain rearrangement (e.g.,  Refs. 22–28), crushing (e.g.,  Refs. 29–35) and creep

2
Elements of neutron imaging
Neutrons were discovered in 1932 by James Chadwick, while trying to understand the origin of the theoretical imbalance of the energy necessary to contain the electrons in the atom, which could not be justified by the protons alone. This discovery came nearly four decades after the discovery of X-rays by Wilhelm Röntgen in 1895.

2.1
Interaction with matter
Unlike X-rays, neutrons interact with the nucleus of the atom, which is why they are sensitive to the different isotopes of matter.
59
 A relevant example is provided by hydrogen and deuterium: they are both composed by one proton and one electron, but the latter also contains a neutron in its nucleus. As a result, their interaction with neutrons is an order of magnitude different, while being chemically and physically similar. Like X-rays, neutrons interact with matter in a variety of ways, but the dominant ones, in the context of geomaterials, are scattering and absorption. X-ray attenuation increases proportionally with (the fourth power of) the atomic number of the material, as highlighted in Fig. 1, where the grey value for each element represents its opacity to X-rays. From the same figure, it is clear that the neutron interaction is far less monotonic. One interesting example is hydrogen (and its compounds, such as water and hydrocarbons), which weakly attenuates X-rays while being highly opaque to neutrons. Similar considerations can be made for some salts (e.g., the Chlorine in NaCl is highly visible) or lithium (for battery applications). Conversely, metals such as Lead or Gold are far more transparent to neutrons than to X-rays. A relevant example of neutron transparent metals are aluminium or titanium, which makes them ideal to build sample environments imposing extreme conditions (e.g., high pressure) on realistic-size samples without affecting the outcome of the imaging experiment.
Besides the aforementioned sensitivity to light elements, and transparency to metals and isotope sensitivity, neutrons are also generally far less invasive than X-rays in terms of radiation damage.

The Beer–Lambert law is generally employed to describe attenuation for both X-rays and neutrons. This 1D approximation describes the absorption of the ionising radiation but it does not, in its strictest definition, account for other processes at play such as diffraction and refraction. When scattering is a significant component of the attenuation, then a non negligible fraction of the scattered radiation can hit the detector, causing a deviation from this law. This is of course more pronounced when we have large amounts of scattering (e.g., for neutrons in the presence of large amounts of water) as well as when the object is very close to the detector (which unfortunately is essential in order to achieve high resolutions in realistic times). To account for this effect, two approaches can be broadly followed: limitation and correction. It is of course possible to limit studies to low water amounts (hydrogen being a strong incoherent “scatterer”, as opposed to for example lithium where absorption is the predominant attenuation process); Refs. 68, 69 indicated that in some cases, errors due to secondary scattering could be higher than 40% for water thicknesses of 4mm. These scattering-induced errors are not unique to neutrons but in the specific case of water they are particularly important, justifying the extensive attention dedicated to it in the literature. The tomographic acquisition, reconstruction and data processing algorithms developed for X-rays and neutrons are otherwise identical, as further detailed in Section 2.6.


2.3
Neutron sources
Neutrons are fundamental particles which have mass (unlike photons such as X-rays) and, as the name suggests, carry no electric charge. One of the most common ways to produce neutrons is through nuclear fission, e.g., by bombarding with one neutron an Uranium 235 atom, which splits into a Barium and a Krypton atom plus three neutrons, with a net gain of two neutrons and about 180MeV of energy.
Alternatively, spallation can be adopted: protons are magnetically accelerated to 
≈
96% of the light speed (around 1GeV) onto a heavy metal target (e.g., lead, mercury, tantalum) which releases about 20 to 30 neutrons per nucleus. This is generally a far more costly way of producing neutron beams and the beam has a “pulsed” nature (which can be used to distinguish the faster, more energetic neutrons from the slower ones).
The energy of neutrons is in both cases usually too high for imaging purposes, which is why they are typically slowed down by making them pass through “moderators” – often hydrogen or hydrogenous materials at low temperatures. Analogously to how X-rays are often divided in higher and lower energy subcategories, respectively named hard and soft, neutrons are rather loosely assigned to bands of energies associated with characteristic moderator temperatures. For imaging purposes generally cold and thermal neutrons are used, the colder ones being less energetic and therefore having lower penetration power but allowing higher contrast.
Producing neutrons generally requires large-scale nuclear reactors (e.g., Institut Laue-Langevin, ILL, in France, the Neutron Beam Split-Core Reactor at the National Institute of Standards and Technology, NBSR-NIST, in the USA and Technische Universitat Munchen, TUM, in Germany) or spallation sources (e.g., European Spallation Source, ESS, in Sweden – under construction – and Paul Scherrer Institut, PSI, in Switzerland), whereas laboratory sources are still too low flux to be useful for most applications. A selection of the more prominent neutron imaging facilities and some of their key features is given in Table 1 and Fig. 2.






2.4
Detection and collimation
For imaging applications, both X-rays and neutrons are usually detected by employing special chemical compounds, named “scintillators”; these are luminescent materials that, when excited by an incident ionising radiation, re-emit the absorbed energy in the form of (visible) light. This light can then be captured by a scientific imaging detector, which generally has a cooled chip to improve the signal-to-noise ratio, such as charge-coupled devices (CCD), Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductors (CMOS) or amorphous silicon detectors. There are different varieties of scintillation compounds but, for those used in most neutron imaging applications, the thicker scintillators generally yield more light but a lower resolution. Additional optical focusing elements are often employed to achieve virtual pixel sizes better suited to the application at hand.
While in laboratory X-ray scanners the generated beam is usually conical (i.e., divergent), neutron beams are sub-parallel, with a beam divergence of generally less than one degree and mostly a few tenths of a degree. Conical beams have the advantage that the resolution/field of view can be modified geometrically by adjusting the relative distance between the sample and the source/detector and that the more efficient “flat-panel” type detector can be employed. Parallel beams generally require additional optical components to vary the resolution. In many types of neutron detectors, the camera is mounted on a rail allowing the variation of its distance from the scintillator, to modify the field of view. Multiple lenses (generally having a fixed focal length, because of their higher optical quality and efficiency) are typically available at neutron beamlines, and the combination of camera/scintillator distance, lens chosen and camera pixel size determines the field of view. In some kinds of high-resolution detectors, a combination of fixed lenses is employed to maximise the optical efficiency at the cost of the loss of variability of the field of view (e.g., for infinity corrected optics-based detectors.
83
)
For static measurements (i.e., excluding motion blurring), two categories of features influence the resolution: the detector system unsharpness, i.e., detector details such as pixel size, optics and scintillation, as noted above, and the geometric unsharpness. This identifies the loss of resolution caused by the slight conicity of the neutron beam. This effect is limited by moving the object closer to the detector, moving away the source and limiting its size (e.g., employing an aperture/pinhole). The object–detector distance, generally identified as l, reduces the geometrical unsharpness at the cost of an increased fraction of scattered neutron impacting the detector. On the other hand lower apertures D and higher aperture-object distance L decrease the geometric unsharpness at the cost of reduced flux (decreasing with the square of both), see Fig. 2. 2.5
From radiography to tomography
The elements detailed in the previous sections (sources, collimators, and detectors) allow acquiring two-dimensional projections of the attenuation to neutrons/X-rays of the object, named radiographies in both cases. To acquire then a tomography, several hundred projections are acquired over a range of relative angles between object and imaging system, obtained rotating around the acquisition axis which is parallel to the imaging plane. So-called “reconstruction” algorithms, based on the inverse of the Radon transform, are then employed to obtain a 3D matrix of attenuation values, which are representative – as aforementioned – of the material density and its cross-section coefficient 


σ


a


 (see for example Ref. 86 for a thorough description of the technique). It should be noted that the same reconstruction algorithms can be used for both X-ray and neutron imaging. The main difference is that, while, laboratory X-ray scanners often employ conical sources, neutron beams are generally assumed parallel despite their slight paraxiality. This assumption is generally considered realistic given the small beam divergence, and is particularly true for small samples. The ensuing reconstruction algorithms rely on the same mathematical foundations (e.g., the Radon transform) but differ in practical aspects (notably, the influence of reconstruction parameters such as the sample/source distance) and their computational efficiency.


2.6
Elements of image processing
Several operations are generally performed on acquired images to extract quantities describing the process(es) of interest. This is a vast topic as testified, for example, by the numerous dedicated books 
87–90
 on the matter. In this short overview we aim to highlight some of the main classes of algorithms belonging to typical workflows in geomechanics, focusing on the similarities and differences between X-rays and neutrons. Some of the more commonly employed classes include: denoising, segmentation, quantification and analysis of incremental displacement and strain.
Even with optimal acquisition parameters, noise is present in virtually any image. Common to both X-rays and neutrons is the family of operations improperly named “noise removal”. The noise in reality is not removed, but rather smoothed, to the detriment of the spatial or temporal resolution of the image.
91
 There are numerous denoising techniques, the most common one being perhaps low-pass filtering, with common kernels including uniform (mean), and Gaussian.
92
 Median 
93
 and bilateral 
94
 filters are also frequently employed, albeit in recent times non-linear procedures such as anisotropic diffusion 
95
 are becoming more common. The aforementioned deviation from the Beer–Lambert law caused by scattering could be argued to also belong to this category. Some strategies to compensate for it are detailed in Section 2.2. Besides this, neutrons tend to suffer from another source of noise less pronounced in X-ray imaging: gamma radiation. Gamma rays can come from the neutron source itself or be a by-product of nuclear reactions (e.g., produced by the decay of common elements such as aluminium or iron that have been exposed to neutrons). Gammas can pollute neutron images by adding brighter spots and streaks, which are often removed by median filtering or by taking the minimum of multiple images with time. They can also be partially removed by comparing the pixel value to its neighbours (e.g., employing “remove outliers” algorithms).
Another central aim in image analysis is to discern the components that constitute an image. This process can be seen as twofold: classifying voxels of the image into classes, e.g., grains, cement, voids, etc., and partitioning them into meaningful subsets, such as the individual grains. The process of voxels classification is generally named image segmentation and, because of its pivotal importance in a number of fields (e.g., medicine, physics, artificial intelligence), several approaches have been and are continuously being proposed. The latter operation of subdividing them into meaningful subsets will be here referred to as labelling.
Three categories of approaches proposed in the literature to segment images of geomaterials can be broadly recognised
96
: histogram based, iterative pixel classification, and edge detection methods. Methods belonging to the first group divide the histogram of the greyscale into classes, defined by threshold grey values, which can be defined arbitrarily or established through an a priori criterion (e.g.,  Refs. 97–100). Methods in the second class share the use of iterative procedures to infer the probability of a voxel to belong to a class based on spatial and grey scale information. With each iteration the probability of a voxel to belong to a class is updated, for example based on the amount of neighbouring voxels belonging to the same class, the grey value and its local gradient.
101–103
 Edge detection methods, finally, focus on the detection of the changes in greyscale associated with body edges, which can be detected with gradient operators as variance, Laplacian and Sobel. Their nature makes them ideal for separating individual bodies, rather than classifying them (e.g.,  Refs. 104–106). All the above methods can in principle work equally well in neutron and X-ray images.
The product of the above operations is an image where each voxel belongs to an user-defined number of categories. Labelling algorithms attempt to separate them into meaningful subsets, which is highly application-dependent. Two main classes of labelling can nonetheless be broadly identified: connected components labelling 
107
 and basins labelling through watershed.
108



Quantification is here used as a broad term including both the analysis of the features and process by some form of reversal of the Beer–Lambert law as well as the quantification of features from the segmented/labelled images. The former includes for example the estimation of fluid absorbed or evaporated from porous media (e.g., in radiography in,
69

,

109

,

110
 as detailed in Section 3.3). Once the images are segmented it is also possible to extract continuous properties such as the porosity and the saturation (e.g.,  Refs. 111, 112). Once labelled, the size and shapes of individual features can also be estimated by a range of possible metrics (e.g., principal moments of inertia, Feret diameters.
113
) This step is extremely dependent on the nature of the processes and features of interest, more so than on the nature of the radiation (X-ray or neutron) used to acquire the image.
Another noteworthy category of algorithms is Digital Volume Correlation (DVC). Introduced in the 1980s,
114

,

115
 the variety of methods falling under this category shares the maximisation of a “similitude potential” between images to track and register 2D and 3D changes. Notably for geomechanics, this method allows for measuring full-field displacement and strains. This method is frequently used in X-ray imaging (as reviewed for example in Refs. 116, 117) but can be equally well applied in neutron images as detailed in Sections 3 and 4.
The above is by no means a complete list or an unequivocal organisation of the panoply of image processing options available in the literature, but aims at providing an overview of some of the more common tools, highlighting the similarities and differences between neutron and X-ray image processing. Some of the algorithms presented above (and a few more) are detailed in the following sections, organised by application and chronology.

Only few years after the discovery of the neutron by James Chadwick, Hartmut Kallmann and Ernst Kuhn showed the first example of neutron radiographies. However, we need to wait nearly thirty years to see significant advances in this direction thanks to technological improvements in the film initially used to detect them.

The main issue with 3D+time neutron tomography is that the speed of the moisture profile requires matching acquisitions speeds. An important parameter is in fact the acceptable level of “blurring” for the data analysis. For example, in the case of a moisture front, if the speed of process is such that it covers multiple pixels during a tomography (which implicitly assumes that the first and last radiographies belong to the identical object), the ensuing artefacts in the reconstruction pollute a region which is often the one of interest. In Ref. 231, the recent advances in terms of high speed tomography detailed in the last section were taken advantage of acquiring 1min tomographies. Concrete samples heated at 500


°
C

 with different aggregate grading were tested, revealing a significantly different hydraulic response despite a nearly identical thermal profile (see Fig. 9). Additionally, indicators of moisture accumulation ahead of the heating front, so far only hypothesised as a possible origin of spallation, and not detectable in radiography, were identified.
Besides concrete, the drying of other geomaterials is of engineering interest. A notable case is wet sand, which can be used as a metal casting mould and where the extent of its dehydration determines the necessary amount of material.
232
 A few studies focus instead on clays,
233

,

234
 whose complex relationship between water content and shrinkage/swelling makes neutron imaging an ideal probe.

Environmental evaporation can also reduce the shear strength of soils, with important engineering implications, for example in slope stability. The radiographic studies of Refs. 235–239 tackled the moisture profiles for both homogeneous and layered soils. Some studies focused on this heterogeneous process in 3D 
141
 although relatively few did so in a discrete, and not spatially averaged, sense (although some study multiple “twin samples” undergoing this processes.
240
)


3.4
Testing in extreme mechanical conditions
Testing of geomaterials in extreme conditions is a broad domain in both geophysics 
241
 and geomechanics 
242
 since its early days.
243

,

244
 The value of imaging in this context is clear, yet the extreme conditions require large cells that are harder to penetrate. For very small (few mm) samples this is compatible with the more powerful X-ray sources available (e.g.,  Refs. 245, 246). While this is acceptable for a number of geomaterials, several have Representative Elementary Volumes (REV) far larger than that, whether because of inclusions (e.g., the aggregates of concrete) or natural/induced features (e.g., depositional planes, fractures). These larger samples require thick metallic walls to withstand the applied pressures, which are best suited to the higher transparency of neutrons to metals.
A notable application is fluid flow in concrete at high pressures, for example for understanding the durability and behaviour of dams and infrastructures. The high penetration capability of neutrons to metals allows the construction of high confinement vessels over sizes compatible with the intrinsic length scales of real concrete (and reinforcements), i.e., several centimetres. One such testing rig, capable of withstanding 50 MPa pressure over samples of up to 7cm in diameter, has been recently developed by Ref. 247. This allowed the water flow in a concrete sample cured in heavy water to be imaged, revealing the dominant influence of local heterogeneities even at very high confinement. Following studies 
248
 also explore the role of reinforcement bars and their geometry and orientation in 3D.
Comparably high pressures are for example also necessary to hydraulically fracture rocks, e.g., to enhance geothermal energy performances, for gas extraction, as well as to study the effect of fluid on the initiation of earthquakes.
249

,

250
 A recent example is provided by Refs. 251, 252, where shales were hydraulically fractured in site conditions (in plane strain a vertical stress equivalent to 3km depth) and rapid neutron imaging allowed for following the initiation process as well as the essential role of natural shale heterogeneities such as its bedding planes, few millimetres apart.
For temperatures below few hundred degrees and small samples, the required cells are generally X-ray compatible but as we move towards the in-situ study of magma, it might become necessary to use neutron imaging.
It should be observed that the above examples also take advantage of neutron imaging for fluid flow. Comparatively few examples use neutron imaging for solely mechanical purposes (e.g.,  Ref. 10), and the potential of this technique in this domain is only starting to be tapped.


3.5
Other applications
Most of the aforementioned examples focus on the capability of neutrons to detect hydrogen and to penetrate through metals. There are nonetheless a number of other unique properties that can reveal essential to many open problems in geomechanics. For example a number of environmental pollutants such as Cadmium are highly visible in neutron imaging and our capacity to “wash” them from a rock can be studied.
253
 Also salts play an important hydro-mechanical role in geomaterials by creating flow barriers or inducing fractures upon deposition. Several elements (Chlorine, Boron) are highly visible in neutron imaging.
254

,

255
 Conversely at times the opposite is true, and it is their transparency to neutrons (as opposed to X-rays) that may be of interest when a combination of the techniques is used 
256
 as it will be explored in more detail in the next section.
In some cases, water becomes part of the mineral structure (the so-called hydrous minerals), which are also well captured in neutron imaging.
55
 The full potential of this technique for geomechanics is likely to be as of yet untapped, notably because of its less pervasive diffusion and less known potential in this domain.



4
Neutrons plus x-rays
So far this paper has focused on the unique properties of neutron imaging. As highlighted in Fig. 1, a number of elements are far more (or less) visible in neutron than in X-ray imaging, making these two techniques profoundly complementary. This was acknowledged since the early days, also given the inspirational role that X-ray imaging has had on its neutron counterpart. Even the neutron imaging believed to be the first ever published, reported in Fig. 10, 
257
 already presented a comparison with photons (in the “gamma” energy range in this case). The earliest example of dual acquisition for geosciences is perhaps that of Lewis and Krinitzsky 
122
 for soils and rocks. Shortly after, Howdyshell 
133
 presented a comparative evaluation of water and cement content in fresh concrete. A broad-spectrum review of the application of their complementarity is presented in Ref. 54, although no geoscience example is reported.


Some early examples use X-rays for their capacity to capture fine details of the structure and neutrons to capture water uptake.
204
 In Ref. 259 and Ref. 260 initial neutron and X-ray tomographies are used to characterise in detail the microstructure (e.g., their porosity, tortuosity and zones of localised deformation) which is then used to interpret a series of neutron radiographies. In other studies, the same principle was used to characterise the capillary bridges of a given material state.
240

,

261
 Similarly, Ref. 148 used the combination of the two techniques to study the microstructure of a drying cement sample. The work detailed in Ref. 256 explores the aforementioned complementarity of X-ray and neutrons to study salt transport and crystallisation in porous limestones.

Another noteworthy example is concrete: Fig. 11 shows a scan of a concrete sample acquired with both ionising radiations. X-rays are clearly effective in distinguishing pores from the rest of the matrix but, because of their comparable density, aggregates and mortar are barely distinguishable. Conversely, the low neutron attenuation of the 


SiO


2


 aggregates makes them stand out with respect to the cement matrix, whereas it brings them too close to the average attenuation values of the pores to allow their straightforward segmentation.
The power of multi-modal imaging for image segmentation is also evident from Ref. 262 where the distribution of molecular and mineralogical heterogeneities of oil reservoir rocks is established at the pore scale, whose interpretation is helped by Monte Carlo simulations.
The combination of X-ray and neutron information allows the lower neutron flux to be compensated, as for example in the work by Ref. 69, which combined X-ray and neutron imaging to study the complex hydro-mechanical interactions in Callovo-Oxfordian claystone, used for the storage of radioactive wastes (see Fig. 12).
In all the above examples, the complementarity of these techniques could only be partially exploited: since the two images could not be acquired simultaneously, either a single state was multi-modally characterised, or the comparison was made at the level of analogy. In this case, multiple tests are performed in matching conditions and compared (e.g.,  Ref. 69). This approach can provide great insight and is often precursor to later studies as the technology advances (e.g., in the classic example of Ref. 263). The key limitation is in this case that the two informations can only be matched in an averaged or statistical sense.
In the last few years, three facilities have developed the capacity to acquire simultaneous neutron and X-ray tomographies : PSI in Switzerland in 2015,
264

,

265
 NIST in the USA in 2016 (the publication describing it dates to 2017 
81
 although abstracts showcasing its performance are one year older), and ILL in France in 2017 
215
 (less than one year after the entrance in operation of the instrument).
An early example is that of Ref. 266 where tomographies of shale samples were simultaneously acquired at 30 
μ
m (following an earlier non-simultaneous work from the same group
267
) allowing a richer and more rigorous segmentation of minerals and structures, as shown in Fig. 13. The first example of simultaneous vectorial 4D image acquisition (3D + a process + X/N) is perhaps that of 
268
 to characterise the dynamics of water absorption in Callovo-Oxfordian claystone by comparing material deformation as well as water arrival. Neutron and X-ray datasets are registered pairwise into a common coordinate system, which allows the data to become a vector-valued (reconstructed X-ray and neutron value) 3D field varying in time. Superposed X-ray and neutron 3D volumes allows an improved identification of mineral phases in this complex material. The strain field obtained from the application of 3D Digital Volume Correlation (DVC) on the X-ray time series data is locally compared to changes in water content available from the neutrons, and a model for the evolution of greylevels due to both water arrival and strain is presented, which could be applied to a number of other studies.

It is clear that, much in the same way early 4D datasets required the development of new analysis algorithms (for example DVC), new developments are also required to quantitatively interpret this data. One of the earlier works in this direction is the recent theoretical development in Ref. 269, which allows not only for accurately (and user-independently) aligning neutron and X-ray tomographies (with no need for dedicated markers), but also for automatic segmentation of the phases – by analysing the joint X-ray and neutron histogram. A recent paper by Ref. 270 presents the technical details of the algorithm proposed by Ref. 269 and applies it to neutron and X-ray tomographies of concrete (those shown in Fig. 11). This yields a registered neutron image that matches the X-ray image with sub-pixel accuracy (within 0.05 pixels displacement

5
Discussion and perspectives
This paper has hopefully highlighted the broad spectrum of applications and vast potential that neutron imaging has for our understanding of geomechanics. Notable areas of application range from the determination of key microstructural properties (moisture, porosity, mineralogy) to the multi-phase flow in geomaterials (whether homogeneous or within natural and induced features) and from drying process (whether at environmental conditions or at high temperature) to testing at extreme conditions.
Several of the reported studies were exploratory in nature, albeit several others have shown much advancement in the rigorous quantification of key processes underlying the hydro–chemo–thermo-mechanical behaviour of geomaterials.
Some notable cases of the less explored domains include the partial saturation of soils (explored at the level of the individual capillary bridges), the mechanical testing at extreme conditions and the high temperature behaviour of construction materials.
In the applications where broader experimental campaigns have been performed, the ongoing effort is in the rigorous quantification, for example, of moisture profiles, whether induced by wetting, drying or capillarity, as well as the underlying fluid flow transport parameters (sorptivity, diffusivity). Beside these problem-specific algorithmic developments, a key element in the rigorous quantification of fluids is the correction for scattering. Numerous approaches have been proposed, from beamline and problem-specific calibrations (to model for example the point scatter function, although more work in this direction is still needed).
Furthermore, as highlighted in Section 2.2, the attenuation coefficients are wavelength dependent, meaning that to improve our precision, the monochromatisation (i.e., capacity to discern wavelengths) options, now available at multiple beamlines, can play an important role. The potential of multispectral imaging is though much broader, for example allowing to discern liquid water from ice 
254

,

271
 based on the discrepancy of their attenuation at different wavelengths. An extreme case of wavelength-dependency of attenuation are the so-called “Bragg Edges” where the change is so sharp that when multiple narrowly selected monochromatic beams are selected, it is possible to obtain indications about the contained minerals. This is frequently used for metals (e.g.,  Ref. 272) but in rocks this appear to be limited to some preliminary studies in their X-ray analogues.
273
 Other emerging techniques that provide alternative contrast mechanisms, whose use in geomechanics is so far limited, are phase contrast 
274

,

275
 and dark field imaging 
276
 as well as neutron polarisation 
277
 which allows the study in 3D of magnetic field, which may be of interest for ferromagnetic geomaterials.
In classic “attenuation” imaging there are also promising new developments. Recently, the tomographic speed passed from the tens of second regime 
278
 to the second range,
209
 which opens new perspectives for the study of dynamic processes. Analogously, the resolution has recently reached close to 4µm,
279

,

280
 with an ongoing effort to reach 1µm, which opens new possibilities for a number of processes. Both of these efforts have been (and will be) facilitated by the opening of imaging facilities at high flux neutron sources such as the Institute Laue Langevin (ILL) in France, and, in the near future, of the European Spallation Source (ESS) in Sweden.
Even when the 1µm resolution will be attained, it will be insufficient to capture finer details such as the nanopores of some geomaterials. This is where the combination with X-ray imaging outlined in Section 4 becomes essential. Besides the possibility to acquire images of the same object at a better resolution, it is in fact envisaged to merge the images to achieve a superior spatio-temporal resolution with the less performant of the two (the neutrons, in this case). These are of course only some of the tantalising perspectives that the combination of neutrons and X-rays offers, thanks to the highly complementary information of the two which is only hinted in the pioneering works presented.
The continuous increase in performance of the facilities, the broadening of the contrast options, the expanding portfolio of quantification approaches and their improved rigorousness (e.g., through scattering correction and the use of monochromatic beams as detailed in Section 2.2 and by combining multi-modal information as outlined in Section 4) all delineate a bright future for the role of neutron imaging in geomechanics.
